What did you fact-check?: The word "coronavirus" used on various sanitary products suggest that the outbreak of COVID-19 is a planned operation.
Explanation: Term coronavirus describes a group of viruses known to man for decades.

What did you fact-check?: Gargling warm water with salt and-or vinegar kills SARS-CoV-2.
Explanation: No proof that salt and/or vinegar can kill the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A man is touching a push-cart with his tongue to spread the virus outside Lidl in Lithuania.
Explanation: The video is most likely shot in Lebanon and definately not in Lithuania.

What did you fact-check?: A train marked "COVID-19" spotted in the US.
Explanation: The photo was doctored.

What did you fact-check?: Giant hornets migrated to Europe due to the outbreak of coronavirus.
Explanation: The authors of the article stole older material on hornets and climate change and wrote headline about coronavirus

What did you fact-check?: A row of coffins in Italy. Claims that this is how Bergamo in Italy deals with the dead from the virus.
Explanation: The photo was taken in 2013, amidst the migration crisis.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that the outbreak of COVID-19 is not real.
Explanation: WHO, CDC, ECDC, Ministry of Health as well as multiple other agencies claim the outbreak is real.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that the outbreak of the virus was caused by 5G.
Explanation: No proof to link 5G network with the outbreak of the virus.

What did you fact-check?: Video showing police beating people in China, linked with the outbreak.
Explanation: The video shows police beating people in Hongkong. The video was shot on the last day of August 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Outbreak of the Wuhan coronavirus is a start of a depopulation programme. This, in turn, is based on Bill and Melinda Gates foundation links to the outbreak.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 was stolen from Canada by Chinese spies and accidentally released in Wuhan.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Authors of a tabletop exercise in Oct 2019 predicted that Wuhan coronavirus might kill 65 million people.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Outbreak of COVID-19 is a worldwide fake, fatality rate too low for an epidemic, WHO admitted causing SARS outbreak in 2003.
Explanation: Thousands of confirmed cases around the globe, virus confirmed in multiple labs, fatality rate greater than that of some of pandemics in the 20th century.

What did you fact-check?: A photo claimed that military vehicles are combating COVID-19 in Palermo, Italy.
Explanation: Sicilian media wrote that military was indeed driving through Palermo, but vehicles were comng back from a military exercise and had nothing to do with the virus as at the time there were a handful of confirmed COVID-19 cases in Sicily.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus was made in lab, with preexisting patents for a vaccine. The Bill and Melinda Gates foundation is involved in spreading the coronavirus.
Who said/posted it?: Ugnius Kiguolis, local antivaxer, a businessman
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: U.S. soldier stationed in Lithuania is the first confirmed case of coronavirus in the country.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 was caused by 5G antennas.
Link to the original piece: Facebook user, post is now deleted
Explanation: There is no proof that 5G network has anything to do with the outbreak of a novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A book by D.Koontz (The Eyes of Darkness) predicted covid-19 in 1981.
Explanation: The first edition of the book mentioned that the virus was invented by the Russians, rather then the Chinese. Moreover, real and imaginary viruses have almost nothing in common.

What did you fact-check?: A "Letter" from an uncle in Wuhan claims covid-19 can be cured with hot water.
Explanation: There is no evidence hot water can cure covid-19, other facts stated in the said letter are not accurate as well.

What did you fact-check?: Video showing Chinese officials detaining infected citizen, who refused to be checked.
Explanation: The video does not show a real event, but an exercise.

What did you fact-check?: A text post with instructions from "a Lithuanian doctor", giving advice to potentially infected with coronavirus
Link to the original piece: No link (posts deleted after debunking the claim)
Explanation: Text post is a false one since instructions to stay at home if infected were not given out by any authorities, some of the "facts" about the disease were straight up made up.

What did you fact-check?: A video showing chaos in a shop, claiming that people are panicking after a first confirmed case of coronavirus in Lithuania.
Link to the original piece: No link (videos deleted after debunking the claim)
Explanation: The video was made in May 2018 in Romania, during a sale at a supermarket.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is caused by snakes.
Explanation: There is no conlusive proof that snakes have caused the spread of the Wuhan coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: SARS-CoV-2 can be killed over 37 degrees Celsius.
Explanation: There is no confirmed information on what temperatures are dangerous to the virus. Local medical institutions confirmed to have no data on the issue.

What did you fact-check?: 200 new cases of COVID-19 registered in Lithuania. People are "cleansed with bleach" at the Vilnius international airport and are taken to a small tent-town nearby.
Explanation: 1 COVID-19 case is confirmed in Lithuania at this time. The has a English text photoshoped instead of the Lithuanian one. Officials claim there was no such "explosion" in cases and objective reality at the airport supports that.

What did you fact-check?: Elderly people are left to die in an Italian hospital near Milan.
Explanation: Information was based on an audio message circulating via WhatsApp. The message was posted by "Il Giornale", which later retracted the message. Niguarda hospital released a statement claiming that the information was false.

What did you fact-check?: Airports and train stations in Lithuania are being closed down.
Explanation: The article used a statement by the government which claimed that schools are being closed. Authors of the misleading article added information about airports and train stations in a headlines but used the governments statement as main text.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 is cured with hot water and baking soda.
Explanation: Mortality statistics indicate that seasonal flu is at least 60 times less deadly than COVID-19 (based on current data). Hot water and soda have no proven effects to help combat the novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A photo claimed that a Lithuanian town of Mazeikiai is being cut off from the rest of the country due to outbreak of COVID-19.
Explanation: An original photo shows a sign that informs of a road maintanance project. Whereas the fake one claimed that a city is being cut off.

What did you fact-check?: A facebook post claimed that a message from Stanford hospital gives advice to drink water every 15 minutes in order to prevent COVID-19
Explanation: A statement from the Stanford hospital distanced themselves from the fake message.

What did you fact-check?: An image on Facebook claimed that hundreds of infected people are hidden in Lithuanian hospitals, and were taken to crematoriums.
Explanation: The original message was published by a prank generating Facebook account and repackaged to look as if it was real.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that photos show dogs being killed in China as part of efforts to combat COVID-19.
Explanation: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the post to be partly false. While there are media reports concerning pets being killed in China because of fears over the spread of Covid-19, they remain unverified and have been denied by authorities. The photos accompanying the Facebook post are unrelated to Covid-19. It is true that World Health Organization’s advice is there is no evidence that companion animals/pets can be infected with Covid-19 despite a single case in Hong Kong of a dog testing “weak positive”.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that notes from an "uncle" who "graduated with a master's degree" and worked at Shenzhen Hospital is advice on COVID-19 symptoms and treatment.
Explanation: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the post to contain a mixture of true and false claims. A runny nose, sputum, dry cough and pneumonia can be symptoms of COVID-19 however not everyone infected with the disease will have them. Disease expert Prof Collingnon says temperatures around 26 to 27 degrees C won’t kill the virus however UV light from the sun can be effective in drying out the virus. Understanding of how long COVID-19 survives on surfaces is limited, with the WHO referring to previous studies of other viruses to estimate a range of a few hours to a few days. Drinking warm water, avoiding iced drinks and gargling warm salt water are not treatments or preventions, according to Prof Cunningham, however staying hydrated is important and gargling may relieve sore throats. The timeline for progression of COVID-19 symptoms is partly accurate but not everyone will experience all of these symptoms or in that order. Prof Cunningham also said it was not accurate to say infection will happen first in the throat, as the delicate tissues behind the nose are more likely starting points.

What did you fact-check?: A Saudi Arabian study for a MERS vaccine is linked to the outbreak of coronavirus.
Explanation: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be false. The Saudi clinical trial is investigating a vaccine for the MERS Coronavirus strain, not the 2019 Novel Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Post claims food products such as rice, fortune cookies, mi goreng noodles, ice tea and "Chinese red bull" are contaminated with coronavirus. Also some areas of Sydney are supposedly identified as contaminated.
Explanation: AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be false. A viral infectious diseases expert says there is no evidence of food being a source of any coronavirus transmission. The Facebook post also lists information from the “Department of Diseasology Parramatta” conducting tests showing “positive readings” for the virus at train stations in four Sydney suburbs. NSW Health confirmed to AAP FactCheck there is no such organisation as the “Department of Diseasology Parramatta” and there have been no “positive readings” at train stations.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that a "Wuhan super virus" originated in a Chinese biosecurity lab and has infected more than 100,000 in Wuhan.
Explanation: There is no evidence that the 2019 Novel Coronavirus came from a Chinese laboratory. The WHO says the virus most likely originated in an animal. The number of cases of infection with the coronavirus in Wuhan has not reached 100,000 as claimed in the video.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that the 2019 novel coronavirus (COVID-19) is more deadly than Ebola or HIV.
Explanation: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be false. The post’s claim that coronavirus is the most deadly disease in history is not correct. Global fatalities for HIV and Ebola are far higher, figures from the World Health Organization and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that pic of vegan food products left on otherwise bare supermarket shelf is related to COVID-19 outbreak and panic buying.
Explanation: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be incorrectly linking the supermarket shelf image to the 2019/20 COVID-19 coronavirus outbreak. The image of a supermarket shelf full of vegan foods while the shelves either side remain empty has nothing to do with the COVID-19 coronavirus outbreak. It was originally taken in 2017 in the United States when Hurricane Harvey hit the southern state of Texas.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that disease outbreaks and pandemics correspond with election years.
Explanation: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found no correlation between election years and virus outbreaks. The outbreaks of SARS, Bird Flu and COVID-19 do not line up with the dates claimed in the post. In the case of Zika virus, the disease has had multiple outbreaks since 2014 in parts of Oceania and in Brazil. Bird Flu, MERS and Ebola have not been reported in Australia and have not been a significant feature of local political discussion or debate. Considering overseas elections, such as US presidential elections, there is also no consistent pattern of outbreaks occurring in election years.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that football star Cristiano Ronaldo has converted his hotel chain into coronavirus hospitals.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Ancient herbal drink is an efffective remedy for the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Experts advise against using herbal remedies to treat coronavirus

What did you fact-check?: Photos showing well-stocked vegan shelf while other items are cleared out.
Explanation: Photo has circulated online since September 2017 in reports showing panic buying after hurricane Harvey in US.

What did you fact-check?: Health authorities say shaving beard protect form CoV.
Explanation: It's a 2017 graphic regarding how to wear tight fitting masks for professionals.

What did you fact-check?: People queing outside an ALDI supermarket in Germany, to buy food in fear of Cov.
Explanation: A 2011 video showing an opening of an Aldi.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese people convert to islam because of cov.
Explanation: It s an old video, not related to CoV.

What did you fact-check?: Sri Lanka eradicated coronavirus.
Explanation: One patient recovered but experts said its not enough to mention eradication.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus was created in lab and patented.
Explanation: The patents circulating are linked to other coronaviruses and a patent for a virus does not mean it's man made.

What did you fact-check?: There are several new confirmed cases in several French cities.
Explanation: Hospitals and authorities denied such claims in various cities.

What did you fact-check?: Saline solution can kill coronavirus.
Who said/posted it?: Multiple posts an weibo, Twitter and FB
Explanation: Doctor and WHO deny this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Food and locations are contaminated in Australia.
Explanation: Authorities denied those claims.

What did you fact-check?: Doctors said the entire Wuhan populaiton will die of the new CoV.
Explanation: Authorities never said that and US CDC said most people will recover on their own.

What did you fact-check?: This video shows the Wuhan market where the virus comes from.
Explanation: It's a market in Indonesia.

What did you fact-check?: This is the picture of the first new Wuhan coronavirus hospital.
Explanation: This is a stock picture of a modular construction from a Chinese import-export company.

What did you fact-check?: The post claims that yoy have to wear a disposable mark blue side out if you are sick and white side out if you are not.
Explanation: The only way to wear a mask is with blue face out, experts say to AFP.

What did you fact-check?: There is an herbal cure for CoV.
Explanation: Health experts in Sri Lanka say there is no evidence asafoetida or other herbal medicine can definitively protect people from infection.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese supreme court ok'd euthanasia of 20 000 people.
Explanation: The article was published on a site that has regularly produced hoax reports, and China has made no such announcement.

What did you fact-check?: A video claims to be showing an Eid prayer in China in dec 19.
Who said/posted it?: Multiple FB, twiter an YOutube posts
Explanation: This is a prayer in China in June 19, not related to Cov.

What did you fact-check?: Philippines has issued an order mandating a compulsory quarantine for all travellers returning from 23 countries.
Explanation: Philippine authorities did not issue this warning after the novel coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Boild garlic water can protect from Cov.
Explanation: Health experts refute false claims that drinking boiled garlic water cures novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Boiled ginger can cure cov.
Explanation: Doctors deny this.

What did you fact-check?: This photo shows a Japanese medical professional going to provide aid in Wuhan.
Explanation: This photo has circulated in reports about a Japanese medical team travelling to China in 2008.

What did you fact-check?: A video claims to show a plane carrying medical supplies to China.
Explanation: This video shows a plane in Kenya carrying humanitarian aid bound for China.

What did you fact-check?: This woman died of Cov.
Explanation: Family says no evidence of Cov.

What did you fact-check?: Hong Kong police are misappropriating face masks for personal use.
Explanation: Photo circulating since 2018.

What did you fact-check?: Crows are flocking to Wuhan.
Explanation: This video shows crows in the Chinese city of Xining -- 1,000 miles from Wuhan.

What did you fact-check?: Penjab autorities advised not to eat goat meat for 60 days.
Explanation: China coronavirus: Pakistani officials deny they issued warning over dangers of eating goat meat.

What did you fact-check?: Cannibalism in China has caused the outbreak of a new strain of the novel coronavirus. A Chinese man is preparing a dead baby for consumption.
Explanation: No, this photo shows a piece of performance art created by a Chinese artist in 2000.

What did you fact-check?: Tinospira crispa plants can treat cov.
Explanation: Philippine health experts dismiss misleading online claim that tinospora crispa plants can treat novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Video showing quarantined people in a building in Shanghai.
Explanation: This video shows tower blocks in Shanghai, not Wuhan – and the clip has been edited to include the audio

What did you fact-check?: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang had dinner in Wuhan during the epidemic.
Explanation: Photo taken in 2013 in Sichuan.

What did you fact-check?: Singapore closed a subway stattion after a case of COVID-19.
Explanation: Authorities denied.

What did you fact-check?: Thailnd cures CoV with anti-HIV drugs.
Explanation: Thai doctors say their treatment helped a coronavirus patient recover, but it was not a ‘cure’.

What did you fact-check?: Thai department of health published an infography on how to properly wear facemasks.
Explanation: MOH denied.

What did you fact-check?: USPS stops accepting items for China and HK.
Explanation: USPS told AFP on February 12 it would continue to accept items bound for China and Hong Kong but could temporarily not offer time guarantees on those shipments; it clarified that it will temporarily halt its transit service that ships mail from other countries to China and Hong Kong.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows people infected lying on the sidewalk in China.
Explanation: It was an artistic performance in germany in 2014.

What did you fact-check?: This is a snow artwork from Wuhan.
Explanation: It's in another city, Shandong.

What did you fact-check?: An Australian couple ordered wine by drone on princess cruise ship.
Explanation: The couple said it was a prank.

What did you fact-check?: Queensland issued travel warning for Wuhan and Chinese-populated areas in Australia.
Explanation: Queensland said they did not.

What did you fact-check?: 300.000 people are infected in China.
Explanation: Fewer cases according to China.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese spies stole the virus from a Canadian lab.
Explanation: Mix up with an investigation of Chinese scientist in Canada in 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Anti-malaria drug Chloroquine is a definitive cure for COVID-19.
Explanation: A study found the molecule showed 'apparent efficacy' in treating the disease, trials are still ongoing.

What did you fact-check?: Consuming coloidal silver can prevent or treat novel coronavirus.
Explanation: US regulators say consuming silver is not safe for use against any disease.

What did you fact-check?: Radio host Rush Limbaugh compres novel coronavirus to 'common cold'.
Explanation: Novel coronavirus is more deadly from the viruses that can cause a cold, according to experts.

What did you fact-check?: Ads selling masks protecting against CoV.
Explanation: US authorities don't recommend people to wear masks and the doctor does not speak about CoV.

What did you fact-check?: Costco recalls toilet paper because it's infected with the coronavirus.
Explanation: The notice is not authentic, according to a statement from the wholesaler, and the brand of bath tissue in question is not listed on official recall websites.

What did you fact-check?: The Dettol disinfectant label says the cov was tested.
Explanation: COv are a family of viruses

What did you fact-check?: Photo purportedly showing Tom Hanks holding a volleyball, claiming the hospital staff in Australia gave it to him as a tribute and to cheer him up while in quarantine.
Explanation: The image has been doctored using a 2015 photograph of Hanks and a stock photo of a hospital ward; the doctored photo emerged on a satirical website.

What did you fact-check?: Consuming boiled ginger can cure novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Health experts say there is no scientific evidence boiled ginger can definitively relieve people of the viral infection, and the World Health Organisation (WHO) advised those showing symptoms to seek immediate medical help, instead of testing home remedies.

What did you fact-check?: Donating blood in the US can get you a novel coronavirus test.
Explanation: The two organizations who collect the vast majority of blood in US said they were not testing for Covid-19

What did you fact-check?: Employer covered up part of a poster on virus prevention that advised people to stay home when sick.
Explanation: The part that was covered up on the poster advises people to avoid large gatherings.

What did you fact-check?: This photo shows a brothel in Europe where people have been quarantined.
Explanation: Claim originated on a satirical website based in Spain, the photo is of a nightclub in Marbella.

What did you fact-check?: False COVID-19 hotline number shared in Canada.
Explanation: 811 is not an official public health hotline in Ontario, and the provincial ministry of health is not organizing home visits, a spokeswoman told AFP.

What did you fact-check?: Case of cov in Alberta, Canada.
Explanation: Authorities denied it.

What did you fact-check?: The novel coronavirus is not new.
Explanation: This is false; coronaviruses affecting cattle or canines differ from the new virus strain affecting humans, for which no vaccine exists.

What did you fact-check?: Gargling warm salt water or vinegar prevents coronavirus infection.
Explanation: The claim is false; international health authorities and experts do not list gargling as an effective remedy or prevention method for COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: A graphic has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook alongside a claim it contains a quote from Philippine Vice President Leni Robredo that bats are the "enemy" in the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The claim is false; the graphic has been doctored from an earlier Inquirer.net post in which Robredo was quoted about confusion surrounding the government’s response to the coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Infographic claiming that the coronavirus pandemic fits a pattern of viral outbreaks that occur every 100 years.
Explanation: The infographic contains inaccurate information about historical viral outbreaks and ignores other epidemics that do not fit the assumed pattern; health experts told AFP that while certain viruses are seasonal in nature, there is no basis for the claim that viral outbreaks occur once every century.

What did you fact-check?: These are 7 'evil' things that COVID-19 is 'afraid' of.
Explanation: The claim is misleading; health experts say such practices are only effective when applied properly and can even be harmful if used incorrectly.

What did you fact-check?: These are measures that supposedly protect from novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Health experts refute new misleading claims about coronavirus prevention in Sri Lanka.

What did you fact-check?: Multiple allegations on how to protect oneself from CoV.
Explanation: Many of the practices detailed in the post are misleading and inaccurate.

What did you fact-check?: Chart compares COVID-19 with other longstanding diseases.
Explanation: The graphic is misleading and risks underplaying the danger of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, which is a new disease with a fast-rising mortality rate.

What did you fact-check?: Doctors in Japan advise people to drink water every 15 minutes to prevent an infection.
Explanation: WHO says drinking water does not prevent novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin helps against CoV.
Explanation: Health experts told AFP there is insufficient science to definitively say vitamin D can protect from the viral epidemic.

What did you fact-check?: Water used in an islamic ablution ritual can kill the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Health experts warn that water alone cannot kill the virus and recommend that people wash their hands with soap and water for effective protection.

What did you fact-check?: Israel has no cases of the coronavirus because it developed a cure.
Explanation: Official World Health Organization (WHO) data and Israeli media reports state at least 298 people have been confirmed to have contracted the disease as of March 16; Israel has implemented travel restrictions and closed businesses in response to the spread of COVID-19. Various countries have been working develop a vaccine for COVID-19 and WHO guidance currently states there is no "cure" for the virus to date.

What did you fact-check?: Report that Cristiano Ronaldo will convert his hotels into coronavirus hospitals.
Explanation: A spokesperson for the hotels said the claim was “inaccurate”; Ronaldo has also not mentioned any such plan on his social media platforms.

What did you fact-check?: Breathing air from a hair dryer or a sauna can prevent or cure COVID-19
Explanation: This is false; an expert in coronaviruses said these methods would not be effective, while a cell biologist said there is no evidence the virus can be treated via heat.

What did you fact-check?: An image has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that it shows China administering the "world's first new coronavirus vaccine" after the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
Explanation: The photos in this image have circulated in reports about China testing a potential COVID-19 vaccine.

What did you fact-check?: Monkeys are stealing food from a hospital in South Africa.
Explanation: The video was taken before the COVID-19 crisis in a different part of the country.

What did you fact-check?: A purported advisory has been shared repeatedly in multiple Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp posts that claims a disinfectant will be sprayed into the air overnight in India in an effort to kill the novel coronavirus, COVID-19. The posts urge residents to remain indoors during the spraying.
Explanation: The claim is false; Indian authorities said the advisory was "fake" and that no such measure had been announced.

What did you fact-check?: The indian government distributing free face masks.
Explanation: However, the claim is false; the Indian government said there is no such scheme in place and the linked website is not an official government site.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 case in east Indian state.
Explanation: Local health authority said that there are no confirmed novel coronavirus patients in the area at the time.

What did you fact-check?: Cov case in Uttar Pradesh district.
Explanation: Authorities denied.

What did you fact-check?: Indonesia has provided 1000 free tickets for nationals to return home from abroad.
Explanation: Foreign Ministry dismissed the reports as a hoax.

What did you fact-check?: A runny nose and sputum secretion are not symptoms of novel coronavirus.
Explanation: WHO listed those as possible symptoms.

What did you fact-check?: Israeli scientists have developed a COVID-19 vaccine.
Explanation: Israel's migal institute said it was still working to develop a vaccine, the photo is from a stock photo website.

What did you fact-check?: This Lysol disinfactant label says it's tested against the new cov.
Explanation: Covs a a family of viruses.

What did you fact-check?: Elections years in the United States coincide with major disease outbreaks.
Explanation: Several years of discovery or the associated spread of a disease do not match election years, national and international health organizations said.

What did you fact-check?: This map shows high sulphur dioxide in Wuhan now due to burning of corpses.
Explanation: Those are only forecasts based on past emissions.

What did you fact-check?: This map shows the global spread of cov.
Explanation: This map shows flight paths worldwide -- it does not show the movement of Wuhan residents.

What did you fact-check?: The Australian Prime minister is about to announce a national lockdown.
Explanation: The claim is misleading; the Australian Prime Minister’s Office refuted the details of the post; Australia's government told its citizens on March 18 not to travel abroad and warned those already overseas to come home but did not order a "lockdown"; AFP found the wording of the misleading posts was identical to Malaysia’s announcement of a nationwide lockdown.

What did you fact-check?: Airport in Karachi suspends all international arrivals during coronavirus epidemic.
Explanation: Pakistan's civil aviation authority confirmed international arrivals weren't cancelled at the time; photo corresponds with one that has circulated about flight suspended at the airport in march 2019

What did you fact-check?: Cov case in Ethiopia.
Explanation: No case at this date.

What did you fact-check?: This photo purports to show the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The photo is a magnified photo of a weevil.

What did you fact-check?: New cov comes from rhino horns.
Explanation: Origin is unknown and rhino horns could not hold any virus.

What did you fact-check?: You can steam face masks to reuse them.
Explanation: Experts warn against it.

What did you fact-check?: Cov infects chickens in Pakistan.
Explanation: Authorities say it's related to another disease.

What did you fact-check?: Purported government advisory claiming to list shopping malls and hotels in the Phillippines that the department of health advises against visiting during the novel coronavirus epidemic.
Explanation: The claim is misleading; the Philippine Department of Health said the purported advisory is "fake”.

What did you fact-check?: Clinics in the Philippines are turning away people with COVID-19 symptoms, because of a advisory from the department of health.
Explanation: The claim is false; the Philippine Department of Health denied issuing the advisory.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is a type of rabies.
Explanation: Authorities say it's a hoax, the two viruses are different.

What did you fact-check?: This photo shows a Sri Lankan airline pilot who tested positive for the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is false; the local health authority told AFP the pilot is not pictured in the photo; the man wrongly identified in the posts denied the claim.

What did you fact-check?: Man in hospital after eating bat.
Explanation: This photo has circulated in an online fundraising page for a man with a lung condition unrelated to the novel coronavirus

What did you fact-check?: Photo of Iranian officials visiting vice-president after she contracted COVID-19.
Explanation: The photo has circulated in reports since 2014, after one of Iran's vice-presidents was injured in a traffic accident.

What did you fact-check?: This photo shows a new case in New South Wales.
Explanation: Local autorities denied it.

What did you fact-check?: Red soap and white handkerchiefs are good against the coronavirus.
Explanation: But the recommended practices are misleading; health experts told AFP there is no scientific basis for many of the claims, which include using red-coloured soap and white handkerchiefs, as well as obtaining specific light bulbs.

What did you fact-check?: Authorities in the Philippines seize fake cigarettes that were spreading coronavirus.
Explanation: Video shows Phillippine customs seizing cigarettes in May 2018.

What did you fact-check?: Vatican says Pope Francis has been infected with the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The Vatican said the pope recently fell ill with a common cold..

What did you fact-check?: Russia said CoV is man-made.
Explanation: the Russian Ministry of Health said it did not make such a statement; the document cited in the misleading posts states COVID-19 is a “recombinant virus” which can form naturally.

What did you fact-check?: Israel allegedly developed a covid-19 vaccine
Explanation: The claim is misleading; the image used to illustrate a vial of the new drug is originally a stock picture while the MIGAL Research Institute in Israel, despite having a head start, continues to work on a vaccine for COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Smoking prevents you from getting infected with the coronavirus.
Explanation: The WHO says smoking does not protect a person from COVID-19 infection and warns it can actually cause health conditions that increase the risk of severe coronavirus illness.

What did you fact-check?: A man collapses in a staircase because of the CoV.
Explanation: The autorities and building management said he fainted for other reasons.

What did you fact-check?: Cannabis boosts immunity against CoV.
Explanation: There is no evidence to suggest that cannabis improves immunity against the virus.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that the coronavirus has been discovered in poultry.
Explanation: Sri Lankan authorities said the coronavirus has not been discovered in poultry; the photos were taken from various unrelated reports online and show chickens sickened with other diseases.

What did you fact-check?: A Nigerian taxidriver thereatens to spread Cov.
Explanation: The story originated from a parody account and has been denied by the man pictured in the claim and government officials.

What did you fact-check?: Infected taxi driver demands money from his government otherwise he'll infect others.
Explanation: Story originated from a parody account, no driver is threatneing to spread covid-19 across Nigeria.

What did you fact-check?: Green chiratta can prevent cov.
Explanation: No scientific evidence for that.

What did you fact-check?: 14 points that are expert advice on coronavirus, including symptoms, prevention and how it spreads
Explanation: Some points are outright false, some misleading -- there isn't enough research on the virus to make these claims.

What did you fact-check?: Photos showing empty shelves at supermarkets.
Explanation: The photos have circulated online since 2015.

What did you fact-check?: This photos show Indians bathing in cow dung to prevent infection.
Explanation: The photos show participants at an annual cow dung festival held in the southern region of India in October 2019, several weeks before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

What did you fact-check?: Mongolia donates 30000 sheep to china during the virus epidemic
Explanation: The videos circulated before Mongolia announced the donation on Feb 27, 2020.

What did you fact-check?: Ugandan president announces the postponement of elections.
Explanation: The claim is false; an electoral commission official issued a flat denial, labelling the claim “nonsensical”.

What did you fact-check?: The UNHCR said 'migrants and illegals' in malaysia were resisting covid-19 testing.
Explanation: The claim is false; UNHCR officials in Malaysia said the alleged statement is fake and condemned the erroneous claim for stoking “unnecessary fear and distrust”.

What did you fact-check?: UNICEF releases coronavirus prevention guidelines.
Explanation: Unicef has not released the advisory and many of the claims are contrary to health experts' advice.

What did you fact-check?: CDC issued facial hair recommendation for novel coronavirus prevention.
Explanation: Graphic is more than two years old and is unrelated to current outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese people flee to Vietnam due to cov.
Explanation: The video is from november 2019.

What did you fact-check?: A video viewed tens of thousands of times on Facebook and YouTube purports to show billionaire businessman Jack Ma praising China’s response to the outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
Explanation: But the video has been doctored; the original video shows Jack Ma at a meeting of former Alibaba employees in 2018, at least one year before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan; the voiceover in the clip has been taken from another clip which shows a different man speaking.

What did you fact-check?: This video purports to show body bags for virus victims in Italy.
Explanation: It has previously circulated in media reports about people who died after contracting COVID-19 in Iran; a man recording the video can be heard stating that he is inside a mortuary in the Iranian city of Qom.

What did you fact-check?: Shoppers in China storm supermarket after cov outbreak.
Explanation: The video has circulated in media reports since at least October 2019, two months before the viral outbreak was first reported.

What did you fact-check?: Video claiming to show a hotel collapsing in Chinese city of Quanzhou after it was used as a coronavirus quarantine facility.
Explanation: The video has circulated online since at least April 2017 about a hotel demolition in China’s Jiangsu province.

What did you fact-check?: Rainbow shimmers behind cov disinfectant truck in China.
Explanation: It's from March 2019.

What did you fact-check?: This video shows panic buying in the United States, during the outbreak
Explanation: But the video has been shared in a misleading context; it has circulated online since November 2019, weeks before the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

What did you fact-check?: People queue in Singapore for Halal food.
Explanation: They are queuing for masks.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows Wuhan residents lining up for death certificates.
Explanation: The video has previously circulated in reports about Wuhan residents gathering to collect free vegetables.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese people convert to islam because of cov.
Explanation: Video is from May 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Video showing Chinese officials detaining suspected coronavirus cases.
Explanation: The video shows a police drill in China during the novel coronavirus epidemic.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese official detainted a CoV case.
Explanation: It was an exercise.

What did you fact-check?: This video shows the cause of cov.
Explanation: The video has circulated online since at least July 2011 and actually shows repairs being made to the roof of a bat-infested house in the city of Miami in the United States.

What did you fact-check?: This is a video of alleged panicked shoppers storming a supermarket amid the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The claim is false; the video was in fact filmed in Germany in 2011, nearly a decade before the coronavirus pandemic broke out.

What did you fact-check?: This is a video purporting to show how the coronavirus is transmitted betwen people
Explanation: The claim is false; the video was produced by a regional hospital trust within the UK’s public healthcare system, the National Health Service (NHS), in May 2010 about how infections spread in hospitals.

What did you fact-check?: This video shows cov patients in China.
Explanation: It's a school intiation in South Africa.

What did you fact-check?: A message shared on WhatsApp and Facebook claims that 15 coronavirus cases were linked to Burnaby’s Metrotown mall, in the western Canadian province of British Columbia.
Explanation: This is false; provincial health officials and the mall administrator told AFP that no cases are connected to the mall to date.

What did you fact-check?: Volcanic ash can kill the coronavirus.
Explanation: WHO says there is no evidence that volcanic ash can destroy Covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: Holding your breath can test for COVID-19.
Explanation: WHO and other health experts said there is no evidence to support this claim.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 means "China Outbreak Virus".
Explanation: It means coronavirus disease.

What did you fact-check?: Cambodian Prime Minister has CoV.
Explanation: 2017 photo of the PM, treated for something else.

What did you fact-check?: In France, a picture showing policemen spraying tear gas on nurses and a text criticizing Macron's treatment towards health employees.
Explanation: The picture is said to have been taken "yesterday", ie during the massive demonstrations in favor of the public health services, that took place in France, from March 2019. The picture was taken in 2010, before Macron was even president.

What did you fact-check?: This video shows a brawl this week which took place in a supermarket in Aubervilliers, in France, because of coronavirus.
Explanation: This scene actually took place in May 2019, according to a police source.

What did you fact-check?: Photos purporting to show the collapse of a temporary hospital in Wuhan.
Explanation: The photos show the collapse of a hotel in Quanzhou, south of Shanghai, where people infected with the novel coronavirus were in quarantine.

What did you fact-check?: Photos of Muslims in Italy allegedly praying outside because of the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The photos have been published long before the covid19 outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: This is a picture of the first Moroccan infected with the virus.
Explanation: The photo comes from an advertisement for an opthamologie clinic in Algeria

What did you fact-check?: This photo shows French nurses holding a sign to denounce police violence.
Explanation: It's a photomontage.

What did you fact-check?: A photo showing two military vehicles transported by a truck on the highway, near Paris, to be used for the French population's confinement.
Explanation: The vehicle transporter and the army told AFP that it was a routine trip, unrelated to the Covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: Video showing racist reactions towards Asian people.
Explanation: Those are actors.

What did you fact-check?: Chloroquine cures CoV.
Explanation: Chloroquine showed signs on CoV according to a Chinese publication but it s not considered as a cure.

What did you fact-check?: 12 pieces of advice for coronavirus, including symptoms, transmission, how to neutralize the virus.
Explanation: The majority of the advice is either false or unfounded.

What did you fact-check?: On March 16th, Macron has already announced quarantine for every cities in France and will announce later during the day the passage to "stage 4" of the epidemic.
Who said/posted it?: Screenshots of an article published by actuainfo.info
Explanation: Stage 4 means back to normal and Emmanuel Macron has not made announces yet about quarantine. The website appears to be a clickbait website.

What did you fact-check?: In France, Mulhouse's rink has been converted into a morgue.
Explanation: Mulhouse city hall and a hockey club, which is used to practising on this rink, had denied the claim.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that Russian supermarkets are imposing pre-filled trolleys with basic food in the midst of the coronavirus crisis.
Explanation: Auchan Russia told AFP photos had been taken during a special event earlier in the week and that there is no pre-filled trolleys for customers because of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A photo showing hundreds of people in the Montparnasse train station in Paris, despite of confinement measures due to the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The photo was taken on May 26, 2019.

What did you fact-check?: A letter from the ministry of Education saying summer holidays will be postponed because of the coronavirus outbreak.
Who said/posted it?: Screenshot of the letter published on Facebook
Explanation: Clues in the letter shows it is a fake (for instance, the signature) and Jean-Michel Blanquer, minister of Education, denied on Twitter having published such a letter. He also denied any change in the holidays' schedule.

What did you fact-check?: A Facebook post saying that people who died after being infected by the novel coronavirus can't receive any mortuary care.
Who said/posted it?: A Facebook user that described herself as an independent journalist. She quoted a "source" in her Facebook post. This quote was misleading.
Explanation: The HCSP (Haut conseil de la santé publique) told AFP not every mortuary care is forbidden for dead people who got infected by the novel coronavirus : embalming is forbidden but mortuary basic care can still be processed (with additionnal precautions).

What did you fact-check?: A legal decree in France, published on March 15th, sets the ground for the use of the army in the fight against the novel coronavirus.
Who said/posted it?: Twitter users (such as lawyers) but also the website Reporterre.net
Explanation: If using the army in the fight against the novel coronavirus is possible, it has nothing to do with the legal decree published on March 15th, according to the Ministry of the Armed Forces. This legal decree only simplifies the management of soldiers deployed to work for other organizations, according to the Ministry.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that 35 people infected by coronavirus being treated in Ivory Coast within a military station, quoting a document from the French investigation website Mediapart.
Explanation: French embassy in Ivory Coast and the Ivory Coast government denied this claim to AFP. Mediapart told AFP it has "no information" about this.

What did you fact-check?: Claims that drinking boiled garlic water cures novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Medical experts told AFP there was no evidence to support the theory about drinking garlic water; international health organisations do not recommend the remedy and have said there is no specific antiviral treatment for the new strain of the novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Keeping you throat moist by drinking water prevents contamination.
Explanation: It's not part of official health recommandations.

What did you fact-check?: Plant-based cure for coronavirus discovered in Iran.
Explanation: The plant-based product has not been either approved or submitted for approval to Iranian authorities, according to the official news agency.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that COVID-19 has been around for a long time, with a photo of an animal vaccine labeled "coronavirus".
Explanation: The coronavirus affecting these animals is different from the virus that appeared a few months ago in China, for which there is no vaccine.

What did you fact-check?: Photo showing the bad accommodations conditions for people recently arrived in the country and quarantined because of the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The photo was first published in February 2017 on TripAdvisor to denounce the bad accommodations of an hostel in South Africa.

What did you fact-check?: This is a new hospital in Wuhan.
Explanation: This is the Tangiers hospital in Algeria.

What did you fact-check?: A photo showing full vegan supermarkets' shelves, next to empty ones, with a caption saying "even at a time of coronavirus, no one wants to eat vegan".
Explanation: The photo had been circulating on the Internet for two years and a half.

What did you fact-check?: Those are corpses on the street in Wuhan.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article.

What did you fact-check?: People who replied to a government text with texts saying they won't respect confinement measures are now facing justice.
Explanation: The Nanterre Court denied having received any instruction to prosecute senders of these messages, and the messages present many inconsistencies.

What did you fact-check?: Cristiano Ronaldo will convert his hotels into coronavirus hospitals.
Explanation: A spokesperson for the hotels said the claim was “inaccurate”; Ronaldo has also not mentioned any such plan on his social media platforms.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that coronavirus stays in the throat 4 days before reaching the lungs and that gargling lukewarm water with vinegar and salt can kill it.
Explanation: Neither water temperature, salt, nor vinegar has any impact on the coronavirus, according to experts interviewed by the AFP and recommendations from WHO and health authorities in several countries.

What did you fact-check?: Senegal doctors have come up with a 'serum' against the coronavirus.
Explanation: the Senegal govt has denied this, at present there is no treatment or vaccine against the novel coronavirus or covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: After the closure of schools in France, president Emmanuel Macron announced classes next summer to catch up.
Who said/posted it?: Fake Twitter account of Emmanuel Macron
Explanation: Emmanuel Macron has not made such announces. It was published from a fake account.

What did you fact-check?: 2 cov cases in Libreville, Gongo.
Explanation: Authorities denied it.

What did you fact-check?: Facebook post claiming that French animal shelters "are overwhelmed by the abandonment of dogs and cats due to the coronavirus".
Explanation: SPA president told AFP the claim was false. However, he fears a saturation of shelters, closed to the public because of containment measures.

What did you fact-check?: Beef meat is the best vaccine against CoV.
Explanation: No study shows this.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that the coronavirus was created and patented in a French institute (Institut Pasteur).
Explanation: The video author refers to a patent filed in 2004 but this patent concerns another type of coronavirus. Moreover, filing a patent for a virus does not mean that it was created.

What did you fact-check?: Statement of Professor Jean-Jacques Muyembe, one of the experts who discovered Ebola, saying black skin is "so efficient that it can not be infected by novel coronavirus".
Explanation: Professor Muyembe denied to AFP having said such a statement.

What did you fact-check?: Disinfectant gel causes cancer.
Explanation: There have been no credible studies to prove this, according to health experts.

What did you fact-check?: The RDC government canceled every future exams for pupils, because of coronavirus.
Explanation: The minister of Education, Willy Bakonga, denied this claim to AFP.

What did you fact-check?: Fennel tean can cure Cov.
Explanation: Doctors are not saying that.

What did you fact-check?: Black people are more resistent to Cov.
Explanation: Dakar's Institut Pasteur denies.

What did you fact-check?: Imported second hand clothes from Europe, Asia or America could spread the novel coronavirus in Africa.
Explanation: Experts told AFP the novel coronavirus does not survive long enough outside the human body, and could not survive so long journeys.

What did you fact-check?: WHO considers canceling Mecca's pilgrimage.
Explanation: WHO did not and could not take such a measure.

What did you fact-check?: Hold your breath ten seconds to check if you are infected with the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Only a test made by labs can detect the novel coronavirus, according to WHO and some experts interviewed by AFP.

What did you fact-check?: Four patients infected with virus hospitalized in Sri Lanka.
Explanation: Only two suspect patients were hospitalized and both later tested negative.

What did you fact-check?: People lying in the street in China because of CoV.
Explanation: It was an artictic performance in 2014 in Germany.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking warm water with lemon protects agains the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Health experts say there is no proof that this is effective in preventing the disease.

What did you fact-check?: "They create diseases to offer vaccines. There is already a patent for an attenuated coronavirus".
Explanation: The Pirbright Institute has a patent for an attenuated form of a different strain of coronavirus, the infectious bronchitis virus (IBV). It only affects poultry.

What did you fact-check?: "Coronavirus in China: more than 30 million quarantined, 2.8 million infected; 112,000 dead! People falling on the streets and trains! Supermarkets without food!"
Explanation: "No official source has confirmed these numbers. There were 81 dead and 2,840 cases confirmed until January 27th. Hal Turner never worked at the FBI. He was only an informer".

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus patient bites a doctor's jugular in the USA.
Who said/posted it?: multiple accounts on Facebook and Twitter
Explanation: The screenshot was doctored. O Globo never published the story, URL directs to a non-related story, URL was shortened with a t.co domain, whereas O Globo uses glo.bo in their tweets.

What did you fact-check?: The Chinese company Ruilan Bao Hu San Biotech Limited is the origin of the novel coronavirus. Its logo resemble the Umbrella Corporation, from the video game Resident Evil.
Explanation: The company is based in Shanghai, 840 km away from Wuhan. Virus origin still unknown.

What did you fact-check?: Video of Wuhan market where the new coronavirus started to spread.
Explanation: Video is from a market in Indonesia.

What did you fact-check?: Photo of several people lying on the ground in the middle of the street, allegedly in China.
Explanation: Photo from Frankfurt, Germany, 2014.

What did you fact-check?: "How to prevent the coronavirus (...) Drink fennel tea twice a day. Fennel tea has the same component as Tamiflu medicine, used to treat H1N1".
Explanation: Fennel tea doesn't has the same component as Tamiflu and Tamiflu is not recommended by WHO to treat the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A case of the novel coronavirus was registered in a hospital in Maranhão.
Explanation: It was a different type of coronavirus, HCoV-OC43, which causes regular colds.

What did you fact-check?: This is a market in China where bats and snakes were served as food.
Explanation: The market was in Indonesia.

What did you fact-check?: Doctors confirm that the novel coronavirus may arrive in Brazil through AliExpress packages.
Explanation: There's no evidence for this claim. All specialists agree that it's very unlikely that a virus would survive more than a few hours outside a host, on a solid surface.

What did you fact-check?: Research shows that parts of the HIV genetic code have been inserted to the new coronavirus.
Explanation: Researchers from India indeed claim to have found HIV genetic sequences on the novel coronavirus, and speculate that it might indicate the new virus was artificially created. Nonetheless, these genetic sequences can be found in many different viruses, including some other strains of coronavirus. The paper, which was not peer reviewed, has been debunked by a wide array of researchers.

What did you fact-check?: Satelite images show increase in SO2 emissions around Wuhan.
Explanation: Images were actually from a weather forecast, based on historical data and meteorological conditions. No use of real-time data.

What did you fact-check?: The Simpsons have predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The frames were taken from different episodes - about the Osaka flu and the housecat flu. One of them was digitally manipulated to include the word "coronavirus".

What did you fact-check?: Vinegar is more effective than alcohol-based hand sanitizers for killing the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Vinegar is not effective as a hand sanitizer. Its effects on breaking up the fat protection around viruses are very limited. Meanwhile, alcohol and soap are very effective on breaking up this protection

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin C and warm water with lemon are effective ways of preventing COVID-19.
Explanation: Vitamin C has no know effect on the novel coronavirus, and neither does warm water with lemon.

What did you fact-check?: Alcohol-based hand sanitizer can influence results in a breathalyzer test.
Explanation: Spreading alcohol-based hand sanitizer does not affect the breathalizer test.

What did you fact-check?: Warm drinks kill the coronavirus, the virus dies when the ambient temperature is higher than 26ºC, gargling warm water helps treating the disease and the virus stays on your hands for 10 minutes.
Explanation: None of this claims have any scientific support.

What did you fact-check?: You can self-diagnose COVID-19 by holding your breath for ten seconds, avoid COVID-19 by drinking water constantly. Also, COVID-19 causes fibrosis in the lungs.
Explanation: None of this is true. Covid-19 does not cause lung fibrosis, which renders the "hold your breath" argument senseless. Also, drinking water constantly does not help you to avoid it.

What did you fact-check?: Cuba developed a coronavirus vaccine.
Who said/posted it?: Olho Aberto PR and other media
Explanation: Cuban medication has been used for treating Covid-19 in China, but it is not a vaccine and the substance has been discovered elsewhere.

What did you fact-check?: Water boiled with garlic cures coronavirus.
Explanation: There's no scientific evidence of that.

What did you fact-check?: Israel has already developed a vaccine against COVID-19
Explanation: Migal Galilee Research Institute, in Israel, is currently one of many labs trying to develop a vaccine agaisnt Covid-19. They claim their vaccine might be ready for tests in 8-10 weeks.

What did you fact-check?: Avoid drinking cold water during the pandemic; be exposed to sunlight.
Explanation: Neither is proven to have any effect on the disease.

What did you fact-check?: Universal Church of the Kingdom of God is selling 500 brazilian reals "blessed" hand-sanitizer bottles.
Explanation: The image was digitally altered to include fake information and the Universal church logo.

What did you fact-check?: Brazilian singer Preta Gil was singing in a carnival "bloco" while infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: She very likely caught the coronavirus seven days after her last public concert, while singing at a wedding that has become a major hub of Covid-19 dissemination. On March 1st, date of her last public concert, there were still only two cases confirmed in the country.

What did you fact-check?: Rodrigo Maia, president of the lower house of the Congress in Brazil, voted a law that forbids the president to close borders.
Explanation: The law doesn't turn difficult to close borders, because it is about migrants rights. And Maia didn't vote "yes" for it.

What did you fact-check?: "coronavirus victims are buried in the morning this Wednesday in Italy. Rest in peace".
Explanation: The image was taken in 2013 by Tullio M. Puglia, for Getty Images. The coffins were used for the bodies of african refugees that died on a shipwreck near Lampedusa, south Italy.

What did you fact-check?: Netflix is offering free access to anyone in Brazil during the coronavirus crisis.
Explanation: Netflix is not offering free services during the pandemic. The URL used is not a Netflix domain.

What did you fact-check?: Petrobras (Brazil's largest oil company) is closing its refineries from March 24th onwards.
Explanation: The alledged press release did not come from Petrobras. Refinaries are not going to be shut down for now.

What did you fact-check?: A man claims his dog was vaccinated for coronavirus, thus the SARS-Cov-2 is not really a new virus.
Explanation: Canine coronavirus (CCov) and the novel coronavirus are not the same virus.

What did you fact-check?: Uber will suspend operations for 10 days in Brazil due to the pandemic.
Explanation: The alledged announcement did not come from Uber, and the company will not stop working during the crisis.

What did you fact-check?: Elderly people who are caught wandering outside in Brazil will have their pensions cancelled by the government.
Explanation: INSS (government body responsible for paying the pensions to retirees) says no such measure has been considered.

What did you fact-check?: Photos show Maju Coutinho (a well known Brazilian journalist) walking around in Leblon beach with her boyfriend, even though she is urging people to stay inside during the pandemic.
Explanation: Pictures are from 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Burglars are disguising as health agents to invade and rob apartment buildings in Belo Horizonte and Goiânia.
Explanation: Police forces from Goiás and Minas Gerais deny these occurrences.

What did you fact-check?: Atacadão (supermarket chain) is distributing goods for free. You might get them if you leave a comment on the post.
Explanation: This is a scam used for acquiring Facebook logins and passwords.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese pet owners are killing their cats and dogs by throwing them out of the window, in fear of their pets spreading the coronavirus. This comes after memos were issued by authorities for pet owners to get rid of their animals.
Explanation: The pet killings happened withtin the context of the Chinese local authorities issuing REAL memos that ordered citizens to get rid of their pets and the dissemination of the misinformation about the transmission of the coronavirus 2019-nCoV, but we cannot affirm that the motivation of the owners of the animals has been related to the disease outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: The Pinol brand of disinfectant is the solution to the coronavirus.
Explanation: Covid-19 was discovered at the end of 2019 and cleaners have not proven its effectiveness against this virus.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking hot water prevents the COVID-19
Explanation: This information is false, health authorities do not recognize hot water as a preventive measure and experts point out that it could be counterproductive.

What did you fact-check?: This video of 'coronavirus patient' persecuted by the press is from Mexico.
Explanation: The video was recorded on February 18 at the Instituto Nacional Cardiopulmonar, Tórax de Honduras.

What did you fact-check?: Mexicans can call the Mexican government to get a COVID-19 test at home.
Explanation: The UIES line was enabled only for suspicious cases and not for the general population.

What did you fact-check?: Holding your breath without coughing will tell you if you have COVID-19
Explanation: False, having difficulty breathing is a feature of any respiratory illness and not a sign of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: In Spain dozens of people faced beatings and shoves with the police because they prevented them from going to a mass to pray against COVID-19.
Explanation: The video has nothing to do with the coronavirus, nor with the state of alert decreed in Spain. In fact, when the video was originally released on October 14 last year, there were still no reports of COVID-19 existing in the world.

What did you fact-check?: European and South American flights cause chaos at Mexico Airport, due to coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was recorded in December and is not related to COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: A mixture of vinegar and fabric softener is a better desinfectant than alcohol.
Explanation: Even when vinegar and quaternary ammonium included in some fabric softeners do have some antibacterial properties, its mixture is not more effective than alcohol in innactivating viruses and killing bacteria. This mixture is not included in the official reccomendations to fight Covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: "Raúl Rodolfo Abhduz Khan, biochemical engineer from Karmalah Laboratories, is the creator of coronavirus.
Explanation: The person in the image is a YouTuber from Spain named Raúl Álvarez, aka AuronPlay. His image is commonly used to create disinformation, i.e. he was blamed for the fire in Notredame and in the Amazonas. The image is manipulated in order to show that is a news from CNN en Español.

What did you fact-check?: A map shows hundreds of thousands of Wuhan residents (or even 5 million of them) traveling out of the city before the lockdown.
Who said/posted it?: Tweet by a research group at University of Southampton. Later many news outlets in UK and Australia
Explanation: The map is merely “an illustrative picture of the global air network” that shows international flight connections.

What did you fact-check?: These charts claim to show the difference among COVID-19, flu, common cold.
Explanation: Charts include inaccurate information about symptoms. They claim people suffering from the novel coronavirus do not develop some symptoms seen in flu or common cold patients, such as a runny or stuffy nose, a sore throat, vomiting, diarrhea and muscle pain, among others -- most of which can actually be seen among COVID-19 patients as well.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows a family killed by the coronavirus amid China’s multi-city lockdown.
Who said/posted it?: Users on Weibo, YouTube, FB, WhatsApp
Explanation: False: The video does not show a family killed by the coronavirus amid China’s multi-city lockdown. The family was reported to have died of carbon monoxide poisoning in Dec 2019.

What did you fact-check?: A video showing an anti-China protest amid the COVID-19 outbreak in Italy.
Explanation: The video show a march in Rome to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the assassination of Valerio Verbano, an Italian left-wing activist murdered in 1980.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a WHO official inappropriately touching a female attendee during a briefing session in China about the novel coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan. Same video was also used with another claim that the man is an Australian politician.
Explanation:
Video was taken out of context. The man in the video is a 2006 Nobel Prize laureate in physics, Professor George Smoot, not someone from WHO or a politician.
The clip shows Smoot attending a business conference in Julu County in Hebei Province in China in June 2018 with his significant other who was having a sore back at the time.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus may have spread due to the consumption of bat soup, according to scientists.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support the claim that the consumption of bat soup is connected to the transmisson of the 2019-nCoV. One recent study indicates that the new virus does share genetic information with other kinds of coroviruses that infect bats, but it is still unclear which animals may have transmitted the virus to humans. Analysing a genetic database, researchers concluded that chinese snakes are the most likely reservoir for the new pathogen, but the hypothesis has yet to be tested experimentally.

What did you fact-check?: WHO advises population to avoid having unprotected sex with animals.
Who said/posted it?: Facebook personal profilles and WhatsApp groups
Explanation: Posts presented an edited version of an image posted by WHO on Twitter in January 27. In the original publication, the organization advised people to avoid contact with wild and farm animals.

What did you fact-check?: Doctors recommend vitamin C and fennel seed tea to help avoid the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence to support the claim that vitamin C or fennel seed tea are effective in the treatment or prevention of the novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin C with Zinc prevent and treat the coronavirus infection.
Explanation: According to WHO, there is still no remedy to treat the 2019-nCoV virus and preventive measures include washing your hands frequently and avoiding contact with infected people, not taking vitamin C with zinc.

What did you fact-check?: The Canadian Department of Health issued an emergency notification reccomending that people keep their throats moist to protect from the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The bulletin is false and there is no scientific evidence that shows that drinking water prevents against coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: 3,500 italians potentially infected with the novel coronavirus arrived in Brazil in a cruiseship
Explanation: The photo that has been shared with the misinformation piece is from the Costa Fascinosa cruise, and the company responsible for the vessel reported that all of its passengers in Brazil are from South America. The ship left Italy on November 17, 2019, has passed through France and Spain and has been on the Brazilian coast since December 2, two months before Italy confirmed its first coronavirus case.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking water and gargling with salt or vinegar eliminate the novel coronavirus
Explanation: According to the brazilian Ministry of Health and experts consulted by Aos Fatos, this information is untrue and may even worsen the patient's condition. Publications circulating on social media with misleading content also omit that there is still no drug or treatment to cure Covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: China benefited financially from new coronavirus
Explanation: Contrary to what the piece of misinformation suggests, the country's stock exchanges have suffered from the pandemic: two of its most important indices - the CSI 300, which brings together the largest companies in the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges, and the compound Shanghai - have fallen 8% and 0.94% since the beginning of the year. In addition, the coronavirus outbreak caused a reduction in economic activity in China, with a sharp drop in industrial production and retail sales and an increase in the unemployment rate in the first two months of 2020.

What did you fact-check?: Israel has found a cure and a vaccine for coronavirus.
Explanation: The video report shared with these posts actually shows the process of developing a vaccine that, according to the scientists in charge, may be available in May. At no time does the video claim that the drug already exists or that a cure for the infection with the new coronavirus has been found.

What did you fact-check?: The Brazilian government released additional money for beneficiaries of Bolsa Família, a national conditional cash transfer programme.
Explanation: The Ministry of Citizenship, responsible for the program, denied on its social networks that there will be such a release and stated that it only announced the inclusion of 1.2 million families in Bolsa Família. In addition, messages circulating on WhatsApp with this misinformation (see here) bring links to fake websites.

What did you fact-check?: Books Predicted The coronavirus Before it happened.
Explanation: One book does have a close enough accurate representation, the second is a work of fiction.

What did you fact-check?: Indian industrialist tweets that a specific mask can kill viruses.
Explanation: The mask is an anti-pollution mask and its effect on COVID-19 is not scientifically explained.

What did you fact-check?: India Announced Holidays for 4 States.
Explanation: No such letter was issued by the government.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese Intelligence Officer Reveals coronavirus is a Bioweapon.
Explanation: The story originated from a reddit thread which discusses horror stories inspired by true events.

What did you fact-check?: Indian Daily Reports That Wife Of A Positive Patient Ran Away, did not comply with the authorities and tested positive.
Explanation: The Indian daily misreported as the woman had not yet tested positive and she did not flee so as to not be tested.

What did you fact-check?: Audio claiming India would be put under a complete lockdown.
Explanation: The government rubbished claims of there being such a lockdown.

What did you fact-check?: Cristiano Ronaldo's hotels to be turned into quarantine centres in Portugal.
Explanation: Footballer's hotel chains denied any such claims.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese Police crackdown on suspected coronavirus patients.
Explanation: Video is originally from the Hong Kong protests.

What did you fact-check?: Staff of two Mumbai hotels have COVID positive cases.
Explanation: Both the hotels denied having any such cases.

What did you fact-check?: Donald Trump announced a vaccine by Roche Diagnostics.
Explanation: Roche Diagnostics received FDA approval for testing kits, not a vaccine.

What did you fact-check?: Narendra Modi is giving free masks in India.
Explanation: A fake phishing website was set up in the name of Narendra Modi.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus patients were being arrested in Punjab, India.
Explanation: The video is of a mock drill which is being passed off as real.

What did you fact-check?: Goats in Ajmer, Rajasthan were found to be COVID-19 positive.
Explanation: The video is old and unrelated to COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Indian cricketer Sachin Tendulkar asked for meat shops to be banned in lieu of COVID-19.
Explanation: Claim was falsely attributed to the cricketer.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 passengers being disembarked at Senegal airport.
Explanation: Video was of a mock drill for dealing with hostage like situations.

What did you fact-check?: Popular Cardiologist Devi Shetty talking about symptoms of COVID-19.
Explanation: The person in question is a different doctor and not the famous cardiologist.

What did you fact-check?: India asked for restriction of movement.
Explanation: The notification is from Malaysia and not India.

What did you fact-check?: India spraying pesticides at night to prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: Officials stated that no pesticides were being sprayed.

What did you fact-check?: Sophie Trudeau is sharing her COVID-19 experience.
Explanation: Video is of a woman from London and not Sophie Trudeau.

What did you fact-check?: A positive COVID-19 patient recently met Narendra Modi.
Explanation: A 2018 picture is being shared with a false narrative.

What did you fact-check?: A line of coffins suggesting they are from Italy currently.
Explanation: Old image of 2013 of migrants dying in a shipwreck shared as recent.

What did you fact-check?: Cow urine is helpful to fight coronavirus.
Explanation: No scientific evidence backs the use of cow urine to tackle viruses.

What did you fact-check?: Government of India recommends homeopathy and other alternate medicines for preventing coronavirus.
Explanation: THe World Health Organization has stated that there are no proved preventions and treatments for this virus. The mechanisms mentioned by the AYUSH ministry are not scientifically proved to help in tackling Coronaviruses.

What did you fact-check?: In surgical masks, the white filter side is supposed to be worn outside and the colored on the inside.
Explanation: Only the coloured side of the surgical mask is to be worn outside and N95 masks are better than these normal surgical masks.

What did you fact-check?: The Chinese Prime minister visited a mosque to gain protection for coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is of the then Malaysian Prime minister in 2015 visiting a mosque in Beijing.

What did you fact-check?: Dettol sanitizer kills coronavirus and the company knew about the existence of the virus before the outbreak of the virus in China.
Explanation: Dettol kills older strains of Coronavirus but has not tested the new strain yet. Coronavirus is a family of strains infecting mammals and humans.

What did you fact-check?: Indian daily falsely links study to coronavirus in digital edition and then changes it.
Explanation: The study was linked to filoviruses and had the minimal role of Wuhan's virology institute.

What did you fact-check?: The Asterix comic books and the Simpsons predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: Coronavirus has been around since the 1960s while the Simpsons picture was edited.

What did you fact-check?: Weed kills coronavirus.
Explanation: The news clip was created through a meme generator while the WHO has stated that there are no proved cures for the virus yet.

What did you fact-check?: People were screaming in Wuhan because they feared the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is actually of Wuhan residents whistling and shouting to commemorate Dr. Li Wenliang, the whistleblower of the virus who died on February 7 after getting infected.

What did you fact-check?: Telangana Ministry in India distributed homeopathic tablets claimed to prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: BOOM could not find any scientific evidence supporting theory that arsenicum album prevents Coronavirus- Follow up to AYUSH story.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus is patented by Pirbright University.
Explanation: Coronaviruses are a group of similar looking viruses. The patent by Pirbright University is for the Avian Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) which is found in fowls, pheasants and turkeys. This patent is not linked to the current 2019-novel Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The Indian health department has issued a notification to drink only 50-80cc of water, avoid spicy food, and not travel in crowded spaces till March 2020.
Explanation: There has been no notification suggesting drinking only a certain amount of water, avoiding spicy food and improving the intake of vitamin C prevent Coronavirus. The children are more vulnerable theory is also not scientifically backed. At the time of the story, there were no confirmed cases in India and the death toll had reached 106 in China.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows larve extractted from person's lip is related to coronavirus.
Explanation: The viral video has no relation to Coronavirus as it is an old video which can be traced back to October 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Avoid ice-creams, cold drinks, and sweets for 90 days to prevent coronavirus.
Explanation: No scientific backing to say that the virus spreads through food items like ice creams and cold drinks. The virus has not even emerged in India.

What did you fact-check?: A Facebook video claiming that a seafood market place is the Wuhan market in China.
Explanation: This video is of the Langowan market in Indonesia and not of the Wuhan seafood market.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a girl dying of coronavirus in a shopping mall.
Explanation: The video is from Malaysia where the girl died due to a heart failure and not Coronvirus. BOOM corroborated the theory with a family member of the deceased

What did you fact-check?: Corpses are strewn in China due to coronavirus.
Explanation: The image is from Frankfurt, Germany from 2014 where people lay down in a pedestrian zone as part of an art project in remembrance of the 528 victims of the "Katzback" Nazi concentration camp.

What did you fact-check?: Garlic water prevents the novel coronavirus as proved by an old Chinese doctor.
Explanation: The WHO has not prescribed any methods, there is no link with the recent Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Hubei district is filled with bats on their roofs which are the main source of coronavirus thus the virus spread there.
