Explanation: The video is an 8 year old video from Miami Florida and is not linked to the Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Broiler chickens were found to have coronavirus in Mumbai.
Explanation: Chickens have not been identified as the source for the Coronavirus so far and the attached pictures are not linked to Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Pigs mulled in China blamed for coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is from the African swine flu outbreak in China in 2018-19.

What did you fact-check?: Xi Jinping visits mosque for coronavirus.
Explanation: BOOM found that the video is from July 2016.

What did you fact-check?: China asks for permission to kill 20000 infected cases.
Explanation: The website is renowned to share misinformation. There is no evidence for China asking for the same.

What did you fact-check?: Videos stating that 25,000 Chinese are being killed.
Explanation: Three different videos - 2 unrelated to the Coronavirus and one with overlaid music wre clubbed together with false claims.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking alcohol kills the coronavirus.
Explanation: Drinking alcohol does not cure Coronavirus, alcohol in sanitizers does have an effect.

What did you fact-check?: A Chinese SWAT Team takes down a coronavirus suspect
Explanation: A mock drill video was shared as China committing atrocites on its patients.

What did you fact-check?: Indian Government and World Health Organization advised people to not purchase colours from China for Holi.
Explanation: No such advisory was shared by the government or the Ministry.

What did you fact-check?: A Shaheen Bagh protestor in India was claimed to have coronavirus.
Explanation: BOOM contacted hospitals in Delhi and confirmed that no Shaheen Bagh protestor had tested positive for COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Muslims to understand why Muslims are not contracting COVID-19.
Explanation: BOOM found that the viral video is a combination of three clips of Xi Jinping visiting the northwest region of China in 2016.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows reciting Namaaz and Quran can only be the treatment of pandemic COVID-19.
Explanation: BOOM looked at the video and found several indications about it being a 'Viral Test', Aaj Tak's show where it debunks false claims.

What did you fact-check?: UNICEF advises a certain set of steps to follow for coronavirus.
Explanation: UNICEF has not released this advisory and most of the claims are not scientificlly backed.

What did you fact-check?: News channels suggests drinking tulsi and noni juice will help prevent the Novel coronavirus.
Explanation: A morphed screenshot of the news channel was used.

What did you fact-check?: Israel and USA have come up with a vaccine.
Explanation: Israel has found a vaccine with properties similar to COVID-19, San Diego had developed an algorithm.

What did you fact-check?: 4600 Chinese people arrived to Hakata Port in Japan.
Explanation: According to Hakata-city, this information is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: "Tokyo Olympic Games 2020 will be canceled because of coronavirus."
Explanation: According to The Tokyo Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games, this information is false.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese people rush to Japan to abuse Japanese health insurance system.
Explanation: According to Ministy of Health, this information is mostly false.

What did you fact-check?: A Chinese person, who was conveyed from Kansai airport (in Osaka) to a hospital, has run away before they could be tested.
Explanation: According to the Kansai Airport Quarantine Station, this information is absolutely false.

What did you fact-check?: New coronavirus information "15% fatality rate, 83% infection rate" and "the worst in human history".
Explanation: According to Ministry of Health, this information is absolutely false.

What did you fact-check?: A tweet entitled "Risk of novel coronavirus and countermeasures" saying "The virus stays alive for 48 hours." "The clothes need to be disinfected with alcohol and goggles to prevent corneal infection." "Die without fever."
Explanation: Acording to the Virology Expert; Inactivation will not take 48 hours. No cases have been reported of death without fever. It is difficult to completely disinfect outerwear with alcohol. Goggles are not generally needed. Not an artificial virus.

What did you fact-check?: In Japan, "It’s the Democratic party's fault that health insurance system is abused by foreigners"
Explanation: Accoring to Japan Tourism Agency, this information is false.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus is a "virus weapon", as lethal as Ebola. Everyone who is infected dies.
Explanation: The Washington Times article does not provide any evidence. According to the CDC, the source of the new coronavirus is currently likely to be wildlife. The mortality rate is currently 2-3%. Most of the dead are elderly people or those with underlying illnesses such as diabetes.

What did you fact-check?: The Taiwanese flag is printed on masks to prevent Chinese from buying up.
Explanation: Production of the mask with the national flag started at the latest in 2019. There is no relationship with this coronavirus. Posts posted as "jokes" on Taiwanese Internet bulletin boards have spread.

What did you fact-check?: "Scientists found similar sequences in the coronavirus and in the HIV"
Explanation: There is some similarity between the new coronavirus and the proteins of HIV, this is only accidental, saying that "similar sequences can be found in many organisms."

What did you fact-check?: "Kochi Prefectural Assembly, who returned from Wuhan, refused the test, while it was infected with coronavirus"
Explanation: No coronavirus infection has been confirmed in Kochi Prefecture, and no tests have been carried out.

What did you fact-check?: China officially said that the new coronavirus had "confirmed aerosol infection" and that "in short, airborne infections" was spread.
Explanation: Aerosol infections are rare and different from airborne infections.

What did you fact-check?: In Japan, Okinawa Prefecture Governor Tamaki Denny was seen Kachashi dancing with the mayor of Nanjo City. It was reported that "the governor and the mayor danced while the people were terrified about the new coronavirus infection."
Explanation: It is true that Governor Tamaki danced Kachashi with Mayor Zukeran in January 25. But this is before a cruise ship anchored in Naha.

What did you fact-check?: This is map “based on traces of Wuhan citizens”,during the period between the outbreak of the new coronavirus and the blockade of Wuhan.
Explanation: This map is an image showing the routes of passenger aircraft around the world, and it is incorrect to use "maps based on traces of movement"

What did you fact-check?: A large amount of sulfur dioxide was observed in Wuhan because up to 14000 bodies were incinerated.
Explanation: The source of the information is "Windy.com", but even if the body was burned, "Windy.com" does not show real-time sulfur dioxide.

What did you fact-check?: In Japan, if the new coronavirus test is negative, the cost is 80,000 yen. If positive, the state will bear the cost.
Explanation: No voluntary testing of the new coronavirus has been performed. The test is "when it is determined that the prefecture is necessary based on travel history and contact history with patients", but in this case, the test cost is public expense regardless of negative or positive, and it is "free".

What did you fact-check?: Image claims to show dozens of coffins containing Italians who have died from COVID-19.
Explanation: The photo actually shows the caskets of African migrants who died in a 2013 shipwreck off the coast of Italy.

What did you fact-check?: US military brought the virus to Wuhan on October 2019.
Who said/posted it?: Spokesperson of the Chinese Foreign Affairs ministry
Explanation: The US CDC director says that the flue has started in October in the US, and that some apparently flue-related deaths were in fact due to the Covid-19. He does not say that the Covid-19 has sarted in october in the US.

What did you fact-check?: "The chloroquine stock in Paris hospitals was robbed".
Who said/posted it?: Dr Perronne speech have been used by a well-known far-right Twitter account
Explanation: The chloroquine stocks had lowered drastically, but there have been no robbery.

What did you fact-check?: Hundreds of Italian families are running away from the virus to Africa.
Explanation: We have no proof of this assertion.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking hot tea can prevent from catching COVID-19.
Explanation: Drinking hot tea has no effect on Covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: A video supposedly shows Italians or French people singing Madonna, Katy Perry, Britney Spears or Aya Nakamura on their balcony because of the lockdown measure in France and Italy.
Who said/posted it?: Madonna official Twitter account, Katy Perry official Twitter account etc.
Explanation: The video was shot in Torino (Italy) and people are singing and dancing La Macarana.

What did you fact-check?: Tencent revealed the real numbers of dead people.
Explanation: We have no proof the screenshot is true. However, it seems really unlikely.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows pigs buried alive.
Explanation: This video if from January 2019.

What did you fact-check?: This video shows corpses on the streets of Wuhan.
Explanation: It is in Shenzhen and shows people coming from Hubei sleeping in the streets because no one wants to rent them a rool.

What did you fact-check?: The COVID-19 has been invented by a big French public medical institute (Institut Pasteur).
Who said/posted it?: Viral video of an unknown man
Explanation: Big confusion between the 2003 coronavirus and the Covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: The military is coming to Paris because of the virus.
Explanation: Normal military movements ; nothing to do with the covid.

What did you fact-check?: Another rumor claims the military is coming to Paris because of the virus.
Explanation: Normal military movements ; nothing to do with the covid.

What did you fact-check?: The ice skating rink in Mulhouse has been requisitioned for to be used as a morgue.
Explanation: The rink is not used to stock dead bodies.

What did you fact-check?: An official decree taken by the government says the military will have to help in the hospitals.
Who said/posted it?: French community on Twitter and Facebook
Explanation: The text is just a transposition of an old law into a decree - and has nothing to do with the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Argentinian Health Minister said that there was no possibility that the coronavirus exists in Argentina.
Explanation: In January, González García suggested that at that time "there is no possibility that there is Coronavirus in Argentina", and that, if there was a case in the country, it would be imported, which actually happened.

What did you fact-check?: This graph compares coronavirus deaths with other diseases.
Explanation: Specialists emphasize that the comparison is misleading because it is a new virus that is still spreading and has not reached its "maximum circulation" like the other diseases mentioned.

What did you fact-check?: Argentine President Alberto Fernández said that coronavirus dies at 26 degrees celsius.
Who said/posted it?: Alberto Fernández (Argentine President) on Radio Mitre
Explanation:
The WHO maintains that the virus can be transmitted in all climatic areas and that "the virus is too new for us to know how a warmer climate could affect transmissibility".
According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), it is not yet known whether climate and temperature affect the spread of COVID-19. There is still no scientific consensus on the impact of room temperature on this particular virus.

What did you fact-check?: Ibuprofen enhances the coronavirus.
Explanation:
The World Health Organization assured that there is no proven evidence that the use of ibuprofen can aggravate the health of patients with this virus.
Initially, he recommended the use of acetaminophen (paracetamol) to treat symptoms, but later clarified that he was "not aware of reports of any negative effects" of ibuprofen.

What did you fact-check?: This video of a person infected with coronavirus being detained by the police is not real, it´s a drill.
Explanation: This video of a person infected with Coronavirus being detained by the police is not real, it´s a drill. It was shot last February 21 at Henan Tongbai by the police and the emergency response team.

What did you fact-check?: A case of coronavirus in the Argentine province of Santiago del Estero was confirmed
Explanation: There are no confirmed cases of coronavirus in Argentina at this date.

What did you fact-check?: A case of coronavirus in the Argentine province of Chaco was confirmed
Explanation: There are no confirmed cases of coronavirus in Argentina at this date.

What did you fact-check?: Argentinian doctor discovered a vaccine against coronavirus in Spain
Explanation: Is false that an argentinian doctor discovered a vaccine against Coronavirus in Spain. The men shown in a photo attached with the message is an actor. The World Health Organization informed that "there is no vaccine and no specific antiviral medicine to prevent or treat".

What did you fact-check?: Argentine President Alberto Fernández said that "the WHO recomended to drink hot drinks because heat kills the virus" (about coronavirus)
Who said/posted it?: Alberto Fernández (Argentine President) on Radio Mitre
Explanation:
The organization did not issue any recommendation on the consumption of beverages for the prevention of Coronavirus.
Experts deny this advice and even say that it could be harmful. This version circulates on social media and WhatsApp in Argentina and in other countries.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 was created in 2014 by an English institute.
Explanation:
A viral video denounces that the Pirbright Institute, of the United Kingdom, created that year the virus that causes COVID-19.
The institute denied the rumors, noting that the virus strain they work with to make a vaccine is different from the new Coronavirus: it does not affect humans.

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin C and lemon water prevent coronavirus.
Explanation:
There is no recommendation from the World Health Organization or scientific evidence to support this.
There is also no vaccine or medicine to prevent the disease yet.

What did you fact-check?: Two local celebrities in Argentine are infected with coronavirus
Explanation: Fake twitter accounts claimed they had contracted the virus. The celebrities denied the disinformation.

What did you fact-check?: Nostradamus predicted the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation:
In the book Prophecies of Nostradamus it doen´t say any of the words that are now being spread.
The prophecies that record the words "plague" and "dust" are different from the one that circulates in the image that went viral.

What did you fact-check?: This viral image of people lying on the street is related to coronavirus.
Explanation: The image was taken in Germany during an event commemorating the victims of the Nazi concentration camp in Katzbach.

What did you fact-check?: Helicopters of the Argentine Air Force will spray disinfectant against the coronavirus.
Explanation:
The alleged measure was denied by the Argentine Ministry of Defense.
The same message circulates, and was denied, in different countries.

What did you fact-check?: Christine Lagarde said: "The elderly live too long and that is a risk to the global economy".
Explanation:
There are no written or audiovisual records of the former IMF director saying the statements attributed to her.
In addition, the European Central Bank -inquired by Maldita- assured that Lagarde had not said that phrase.
Part of the phrase attributed to the president of the European Central Bank (ECB) comes from a 2012 report by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in whose presentation Lagarde was not present.

What did you fact-check?: In this video Putin said: "Powerful of the world, I am aware of his diabolical plans to reduce the population".
Explanation:
The captions were changed to make people believe that the Russian president said things he did not say at the time.
The video was recorded at an event commemorating World War II.

What did you fact-check?: Spaniards are violating quarantine rules.
Explanation: The video was recorded in October 2019 days before the exhumation of the remains of the dictator Francisco Franco.

What did you fact-check?: Gargling with warm water and salt removes the coronavirus.
Explanation: The World Health Organization says there is no evidence that rinsing your mouth with saline "provides protection against this disease."

What did you fact-check?: Cuba discovered a serum that cures COVID-19.
Explanation: This supposed discovery was denied by an Egyptian official, whose last name is the same as that attributed to the Cuban Minister of Health in the disinformation, who is actually called Portal Miranda.

What did you fact-check?: The recommendations against coronavirus in the viral WhatsApp audio were made by the owner of Swiss Medical (private health insurence company).
Explanation:
A report by the Conicet Sensory Research Laboratory indicates that, although it is limited, there is evidence that the audio does not belong to the businessman.
The company denied that the audio was recorded by the president of the company.

What did you fact-check?: Recommendations of Dr. "González Ayala" circulating on WhatsApp.
Explanation:
Dr. Silvia González Ayala denied that she was the author of the recommendations and said that she will file a criminal complaint.
Furthermore, the text has several false claims.

What did you fact-check?: The Colombian government has just made it official that all citizens will receive 350,000 pesos a week for staying home to prevent the proliferation" of the new coronavirus COVID-19.
Explanation: It is false that the Columbian government is giving 350,000 pesos to stay at home.

What did you fact-check?: The Colombian government is closing the border with Venezuela, even though they said they're not going to do it
Explanation: At the time of the fact-check the government had not closed the border. But it did so a few days later.

What did you fact-check?: There is a study that establishes the relationship between ibuprofen and the severity of the virus infection. . . apparently what Ibuprofen does is facilitate the reproduction of the virus.
Explanation: There is no solid scientific evidence to indicate that Ibuprofen worsens the Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A 1981 book predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: There are coincidences, but it's not a prediction.

What did you fact-check?: A salesman in Medellín's El Hueco market was sent to a hospital with coronavirus symptoms.
Explanation: Colombia's Ministry of Health reports no confirmed cases of Coronavirus infections in Colombia. Medellín's Secretary of Health also reports no cases in their city.

What did you fact-check?: 10,000 people have died because of coronavirus in Wuhan.
Explanation: WHO data listed only 170 deaths in China at the time of publishing

What did you fact-check?: Market video where ‘the coronavirus began’, was not recorded in Wuhan but in Indonesia.
Explanation: Video taken in Langowan, Indonesia.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus "arrived" to Cúcuta in Colombia.
Who said/posted it?: Luis Guillermo Vélez in his column for La República
Explanation: A column meant to be satirical did not explain this aim and many readers believed that there were confirmed cases of coronavirus in Cúcuta, Colombia's largest city in the border with Venezuela.

What did you fact-check?: Photo of people lying on the ground is caused by coronavirus.
Explanation: Video is from a performance in Frankfurt in 2014

What did you fact-check?: This is Leslie Chow, a doctor who died in China fighting coronavirus.
Explanation: It's actor Ken Jeong, Leslie Chow is one of his characters.

What did you fact-check?: A Postobon tank in Colombia was infected with coronavirus and all sodas were contaminated.
Explanation: The alleged infection of a Postobón tank is false. Both the company and the Ministry of Health denied it.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus has already existed, even in domestic animals, and we have the vaccine to act against this virus.
Explanation: Wuhan coronavirus is not related to canine coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Raúl Rodolfo Abhuz Khan, a biochemical engineer from Karmalah laboratories creator of the coronavirus.
Explanation: The Auronplay YouTube image was used in a screenshot that is being used in misinformations to "denounce" the "multi-million dollar pharmaceutical business" behind the coronavirus. First, CNN did not publish this news at any time and the man in the photo is also Raúl Álvarez (Auronplay), a famous Spanish youtuber.

What did you fact-check?: In a voice note, a pilot greets from the airport of San José del Guaviare and says that he is in quarantine along with other people, between 18 and 22, who arrived in that city by plane and there they were diagnosed that they were infected by coronavirus.
Explanation: WhatsApp circulates an audio of an alleged pilot infected with the new coronavirus, but what he says is a lie. So far, there is no confirmed case in Colombia.

What did you fact-check?: There is a crowd waiting to greet the Colombians living in Wuhan who are being flown to Bogotá.
Explanation: The images are from 2018, when crowds gathered to meet the Colombian National Football Team after the World Cup in Russia.

What did you fact-check?: In two videos of a YouTube channel it is said that in Ibagué there are cases of COVID-19 and that the Colombian government is covering it up.
Explanation: In two videos of a YouTube channel it is said that in Ibagué there are cases of coronavirus and that the Colombian government is covering it up. However, this information is false.

What did you fact-check?: There is a confirmed case of coronavirus in a Bogotá hospital.
Explanation: The case was never treated under the suspicion it was coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A case of coronavirus was confirmed in Cali in Colombia, and a video shows doctors treating patients in a bus station.
Explanation: Video shows a drill organized by Cali's transportation authority, to prepare in case coronavirus arrives in the city.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese government is killing people who refuse to be evacuated.
Explanation: Video is an edit from four videos taken out of context.

What did you fact-check?: A case of coronavirus was confirmed in Sincelejo in Colombia.
Explanation: There is a possible case in Sincelejo which hasn't been confirmed.

What did you fact-check?: A person fainted in Cali's bus terminal because of COVID-19.
Explanation: It's a photoshopped image.

What did you fact-check?: An audio is circulating on social media claiming it's coming from the Colombian scientist Rodolfo Llinás offering some recommendations to know "if we have the infection" of the COVID-19 coronavirus.
Explanation: Audio by Rodolfo Llinás with recommendations on the Covid-19 is false.

What did you fact-check?: The mayor of Buga, Valle del Cauca, said: "I invite the people of Buga to keep calm and to live each day as if it was the last"
Explanation: He never said this.

What did you fact-check?: In Colombia, "First Child registered as Yair coronavirus Mosquera".
Explanation: "First Child registered as Yair coronavirus Mosquera". The screenshot of the alleged note from Caracol has been broadcast on social networks.

What did you fact-check?: Hot lemon juice prevents coronavirus.
Explanation: It is false that hot lemon juice prevents coronavirus. The publication allegedly written by "Laila Ahmadi of China, Faculty of Medical Sciences, Zanjan University" is false and that university is not located in China.

What did you fact-check?: Cristiano Ronaldo transformed his hotels into hospitals for COVID-19 patients.
Explanation: Cristiano Ronaldo did not say this and is not planning to do this.

What did you fact-check?: A ship from China is anchored in Santa Marta, in Colombia.
Explanation: The Yuan Shun Hai ship is not anchored in Santa Marta is anchored and does not come from China.

What did you fact-check?: "17 at 6:00 am, the state of emergency begins throughout the national territory" in accordance with "article 116 of the Constitution", in Colombia.
Explanation: WhatsApp chain that alerts state of emergency by Covid-19 is from Spain.

What did you fact-check?: Holding your breath for 10 seconds will tell you if you have COVID-19.
Explanation: This is not an approved method for testing.

What did you fact-check?: There are 30 cases of COVID-19 in Barranquilla, but the government is hiding them.
Explanation: At the time of publishing there were no confirmed cases.

What did you fact-check?: Nostradamus predicted the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The text used as proof is not found on Nostradamus' writings.

What did you fact-check?: State of emergency begins on Tuesday, the 17th, according to article 116 of the Constitution
Explanation: The text is from Spain.

What did you fact-check?: Gargles with hot water and salt can prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no scientific basis for this claim.

What did you fact-check?: China has successfully developes a vaccine ready to combat coronavirus.
Explanation: China announed the vaccine began clinical trial, not that it was developed successfully.

What did you fact-check?: Cali in Colombia is going to be quarantined, that is to say that for 14 days all commerce, supermarkets, shopping malls will be closed, no one can enter or leave by land or by plane.
Explanation: At the time of this publication, there had been no quarantine or trade closure in the Valle del Cauca capital, as a viral audio claimed.

What did you fact-check?: The WHO recommended that all countries go into quarantine to combat COVID-19.
Explanation: In networks and the media, it has been stated that the World Health Organization, WHO, "recommended that all countries declare themselves in quarantine to combat Covid-19". However, the WHO itself denied it.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows the Russian leader Vladimir Putin, giving a speech with captions that make him believe he is rebuking world leaders.
Explanation: A video is being moved on Facebook and Twitter in which Vladimir Putin, the President of Russia, is seen giving a speech in front of a crowd. The video is accompanied by Spanish subtitles that make it appear that you are criticizing the leaders of other countries for their recent actions. Some social network users even shared the video as if this were Putin's response to the handling that other countries have given to the coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus was created in a biological laboratory in Wuhan.
Explanation: There is no evidence that 'the coronavirus comes from a biological laboratory in Wuhan,' as claimed by Mexican youtuber Alexander Backman.

What did you fact-check?: Germany gave medical protection equipment like masks to China, now it's missing in Germany.
Explanation: Germany sent protection equipment to China twice in February.

What did you fact-check?: The first dog was infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: A dog in Hong Kong was tested weakly positive for Coronavirus but didn't show any symptoms so far.

What did you fact-check?: New strain of Virus already patented / Bill Gates funds institute which hold patent and Bill Gates predicted outbreak and 65 Million Deaths.
Explanation: There are many patents for corona viruses, but those are for different strains, not the one that recently broke out in China. Bill Gates has not predicted the outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: 37.000 US soldiers are entering the EU while everybody is busy with the coronavirus, the soldiers are immune.
Explanation: The Nato exercise Defender Europe 20 is no secret exercise, there are only 29.000 US soldiers and media reported about it for months. Further, it was stopped because of the Coronavirus outbreak - soldiers are not immune.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows coffins of people who died because of coronavirus in Italy - it shows that the virus is dangerous and you should stay inside.
Explanation: The photo is old and shows coffins of migrants who drowned at a boat accident at Lampedusa in 2013. But the appeal to stay inside to avoid infection with coronavirus is correct.

What did you fact-check?: Jobcenters (for unemployed people) close from today on in Germany.
Explanation: The jobcenters are not completely closed, they offer personal contact in emergency cases.

What did you fact-check?: Everything is much worse than reported; the current virus is worse than SARS; it causes red rashes on the skin, media is not reporting enough; people are falling over from the virus in the streets.
Explanation: The video is spreading unproven, misleading and partly false claims about the outbreak of the new Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: China orders citizens to abandon/kill their pets as they can transmit coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no proof that chinese authorities have ordererd the killing of pets; however, there is proof that some chinese authorities have apporved killings of stray dogs and cats in order to stop the spreading of the virus. The WHO says that right now there is no evidence that the virus can be transmitted through pets.

What did you fact-check?: The German government made a "secret plan" about coronavirus in 2012 that foretold the pandemic.
Explanation: There is no secret plan but a public risk assessment of the German government on 2012 that contained a hypothetical epidemic of a fictional coronavirus named Modi-SARS.

What did you fact-check?: Although Germany closes its borders refugees and migrants may still come in and they will not be medically checked for coronavirus.
Explanation: Asylum seekers may under certain circumstances still come to Germany, but they are not the only persons allowed to cross the border. And there will be medical checks if they are infected.

What did you fact-check?: The WHO says the coronavirus might be spread via food.
Explanation: The WHO has no hints so far that infections with Coronavirus via food are possible.

What did you fact-check?: The Seafood Marked is the source of the novel coronavirus, strange animals and foods were sold there, such as batsoup and snakes.
Explanation: It is possible that animals transmitted the virus to people. Many of the first patiens had visited the market. However, a direct link has not yet been proven.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus is more dangerous for animals than for humans.
Explanation: There is no proof that animals can get or spread the new Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The University hospital in Vienna found out that Ibuprofen speeds up the spreading of the coronavirus.
Explanation: The voice message tells an untrue story and it is not clear whether Ibuprofen can have a negative effect. There is no proof so far that if affects Covid-19 patients

What did you fact-check?: What if it's not a virus but 5G that is causing disease and deaths?
Explanation: The deaths from COVID-19 had nothing to do with 5G.

What did you fact-check?: Taking chlorine dioxide helps against coronavirus.
Explanation: Taking chlorine dioxide does not help against the coronavirus or against other diseases. It is harmful.

What did you fact-check?: A Video shows people storming a Aldi supermarket to buy groceries because of Coronvirus fear.
Explanation: The video was made in 2011 and shows people who wanted to buy laptops at an Aldi store in Kiel.

What did you fact-check?: This virus must be old because a bottle of desinfectant from 2015 shows „coronavirus“.
Explanation: The coronavirus family is known since decades, that's why the name shows on older desinfectants.

What did you fact-check?: Tips against coronavirus like holding your breath and drinking water.
Explanation: These tips don't prevent infection with coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows an Italian doctor who says that nobody died only from coronavirus in Italy, that it's not more dangerous than a flu.
Explanation: The video is from February when there were only 11 deaths by Coronavirus in Italy. It is not possible to say whether people with prior diseases die only because of the virus. But studies show that also healthy people died so far.

What did you fact-check?: QQ accidentally showed that the real death toll is 25,000 people.
Explanation: Epidemiologists say that such a high death rate is impossible at this time. Also, with the inspection tool availabl on most browsers, we were able to create an exact copy of the screenshot.

What did you fact-check?: The virus was created by humans and patented.
Explanation: The patents exist but are not for the current coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese scientists expelled from a Canadian microbiology lab took the coronavirus with them to China.
Explanation: The two scientists at the National Microbiology Lab (Winnipeg, Canada) are suspected to have sent live Ebola and Henipah viruses to Beijing in March 2019, but it has nothing to do with the coronavirus. They were expelled from the lab, but are not considered spies.

What did you fact-check?: The common flu kills 60 times more people annually than the coronavirus.
Explanation: It is not right to compare common flu to Corona virus because influenza is seasonal virus, we have vaccines for it and the virus is predictable whereas while this new corona virus exists only for few months and nobody could say exactly what is mortality rate from this virus. Even compared to current information about Coronavirus fatality rate, it comes much higher (around 2-3 percent) than common flu (0.01 percent).

What did you fact-check?: One of Polish telecomunications company used quarantine as a cover up to put 100 5G antennas in Gdynia.
Explanation: They were installed long before coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: "coronavirus epidemy in Poland"
Explanation: Article has clearly misleading, false headline that is an obvious clickbait: "Prime minister has no doubts: Coronavirus epidemy in Poland". In the article itself there is no claim or statement said by any of Polish officials that could justify such alarming headline.

What did you fact-check?: Romania has changed the law so that those who break the quarantine will face 15 years in prison.
Who said/posted it?: Various Fb posts, article on a website
Explanation: 15 years is maximum potential punishment (from 7 up to 15 years of imprisonment) but not for those who break the quarantine but for those infected who willingly spread contagious disease and it will be proven to result in death of other people.

What did you fact-check?: 156 thousand people died in China due to the coronavirus, 90 thousand in Wuhan itself.
Explanation: Article was based on Russian YouTube video, which was based on another article written by infamous conspiracy fake-news website. Figures had no reliable source of information.

What did you fact-check?: Gates Foundation funded development of coronavirus.
Explanation: Article was based on manipulative connection of facts concerning the Gates Foundation and Pirbright Institute which resulted in misleading context and ultimately, disinformative article.

What did you fact-check?: Satellite images showing high levels of sulphur dioxide above China are possible evidence of mass cremations of people who have died from coronavirus.
Explanation: This is a forecast based on historical data. Full Fact analysis was mentioned in our article.

What did you fact-check?: In Poland, people who are not insured have to pay for medical test for coronavirus, so if they can't afford it, they will spread it.
Explanation: He included a document from hospital which named the price for voluntary coronavirus test, for those who are not suspected of having coronavirus (they haven't been to affected areas nor they have medical signs of disease). Anyone who IS suspected of having coronavirus, will have medical examination free of charge, no matter if he's insured or not.

What did you fact-check?: World labs confirm: coronavirus was bioengineered.
Explanation: There is no evidence of this.

What did you fact-check?: Fake coronavirus pandemic is a cover-up for the "5G disease".
Explanation: There is no link whatsoever between 5G technology and spread of the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Iranians have published report saying that coronavirus is a biological warfare.
Explanation: There was no such report and claims about coronavirus being biological warfare have been already debunked.

What did you fact-check?: Cristiano Ronaldo will turn his hotels into hospitals.
Explanation: Information was published without verification and was denied afterwards.

What did you fact-check?: Medical University in Vienna has published a study regarding ibuprofen and coronavirus.
Explanation: There was no such study, Medical University of Vienna denied it and rated is as fake news. Relation between ibuprofen treatment and worsening conditions of patients with COVID-19 is still researched but unproven at the moment.

What did you fact-check?: An image shows "Spanish biologist" who claimed that footballers which earn millions of euros should research the cure for coronavirus.
Explanation: This is not the Spanish Biologist. Her name is Isabel García Tejerina and she is former Spanish Minister of Agriculture.

What did you fact-check?: Stopping breathing for 10 seconds will help you detect the coronavirus.
Explanation: It won't help you in detecting coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Polish charity organisation WOSP has withdrawn and donation to coronavirus fight in Poland.
Explanation: There was no decision of backing down whatsoever. WOSP couldn't possibly donate the money it collected during public gathering as there was clearly stated goal for that gathering that can't be changed afterwards. WOSP is involved in many activities supporting coronavirus fight.

What did you fact-check?: A CBC news report would have said that Chinese scientists from a Canadian lab sent the coronavirus to Wuhan.
Explanation: Nothing in the CBC report (and 2 subsequent reports) said anything about "spies", or even coronavirus, and no link is done between the expulsion of these two scientists in July 2019 and the virus.

What did you fact-check?: 3 preliminary studies who became viral on social networks for wrong reasons.
Explanation: Those are 3 authentic publications, but they were either too preliminary to conclude what they were concluding, or social networks overstated their conclusions.

What did you fact-check?: A CBC news report would have said that Chinese scientists from a Canadian lab sent the coronavirus to Wuhan.
Explanation: Nothing in the CBC report (and 2 subsequent reports) said anything about "spies", or even coronavirus, and no link is done between the expulsion of these two scientists in July 2019 and the virus.

What did you fact-check?: A health expert surmised that the SARS-Cov2 virus might not spread in Nigeria due to hot temperature.
Explanation: Warmer air holds more moisture; thus preventing airborne viruses from travelling as far as they would in dry air. Still, the jury’s out on whether or not SARS-Cov2 will be resistant or vulnerable to hot temperature.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus has not "hit" Ghana.
Explanation: While there are reports of two suspects exhibiting symptoms of the said virus, both men tested negative. This is according to Dr Asare, the Chief Executive Officer of Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital.

What did you fact-check?: Viral video suggests the two cases of coronavirus in Ghana tested negative.
Explanation: The video is not new. It was part of a news item published by Citi TV on February 6, 2020, when two suspected cases tested negative.

What did you fact-check?: Viral post suggests Dettol sanitizer can kill coronavirus.
Explanation: Dettol has been tested on, and found to kill coronaviruses such as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS). However, the manufacturer of Dettol, Reckitt Benckiser Group plc(RB), says it has not yet tested its products on the novel coronavirus and could not confirm whether Dettol is effective against the new coronavirus strain.

What did you fact-check?: Facebook user alleged coronavirus is unknown and kills in seconds.
Explanation: The coronavirus is not unknown nor does it kill ‘under a few seconds.’ The WHO says the virus is part of a family of viruses that includes Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS-CoV) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS-CoV). Also, fatality and severity of the disease may be determined by age and other pre-existing health conditions.

What did you fact-check?: Twitter users said Adutwumwaa Bitters cures coronavirus.
Explanation: Adumtwumwaa Bitters does not cure coronavirus. Producers of the medicine, Adumtwumwaa Herbal Industries Limited, have emphatically stated that their product cannot and does not cure the deadly virus. The World Health Organization (WHO) says there’s no cure, vaccine or specific antiviral medicine to prevent or treat coronavirus at the moment.

What did you fact-check?: Facebook page suggests a bowl of garlic cures "Wuhan's" coronavirus.
Explanation: Health authorities have not recommended any particular drug for coronavirus. So, suggesting an alternative medical practice(s) such as eating a bowl of boiled garlic water is questionable.

What did you fact-check?: Twitter user posts viral image suggesting that cocaine kills coronavirus.
Explanation: The World Health Authority has said there is no that there is currently no specific medicine to prevent or treat the new coronavirus. Moreso, relevant authorities stance is in contradiction to the viral headline.

What did you fact-check?: China seeks approval from the court to kill over 20 000 coronavirus patients.
Explanation: There are a few inadequacies detected on the source’s website. Also, zero credible news platforms have published this claim. All these make the claim unsubstantial.

What did you fact-check?: Article suggests African skin and blood is resistant to coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no evidence to suggest “black people’s” immunity to the virus, or conversely “white people’s” vulnerability to it. The World Health Organisation (WHO) already stated that anyone in proximity to an infected person is at risk of contracting it (COVID-19).

What did you fact-check?: In Nigerian, Ibrahim Magu, Acting EFCC Chairman attributed corruption as the reason for coronavirus.
Explanation: Coronavirus recently named Covid-19 by the World Health Organisation is a disease. Further, health authorities surmise it emanated from the wet markets in China; being a zoonotic disease. And while the jury’s out on the full clinical picture for Covid-19’s, no evidence suggests it to be a function of moral misconduct or the activities of corrupt individuals.

What did you fact-check?: Social media posts claim Chloroquine, an antimalarial drug can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: No health authorities have certified chloroquine as a cure for coronavirus. WHO, the foremost authority on the subject, according to the Director-General of the body, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, says while the organisation is currently conducting a number of drug trials, it does not expect a result before three weeks. More so, the “malarial chloroquine used in China was not one of the drugs.”

What did you fact-check?: A Twitter page claimed shaving of facial hair ensures safety from COVID-19, further attributing the message to the CDC.
Explanation: Results from our research show that the message from Today.ng's article is a misappropriation of a 2017 NOISH publication; a notification directed at workers using respirators in carrying out their tasks. It has nothing to do with preventing the spread of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Constant sex kills coronavirus.
Explanation: Sex cannot kill or cure coronavirus, the science does not add up. Rather such close contact with an infected person will expose the partner to the disease.

What did you fact-check?: Viral picture message in Nigeria suggests former president Obasanjo said that there is no coronavirus in Nigeria and that the minister of health lied.
Explanation: President Obasanjo's spokesperson, Kehinde Akinyemi refuted allegations attributed to Baba; a moniker often used to describe the former head of state. Additionally, Dubawa initiated a google reverse image search, which revealed that the "Fox News writer" (the source) used the image out of context.

What did you fact-check?: A Facebook post suggests that drinking lots of water and gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar eliminates the coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim has not been corroborated by any health institution. The WHO says there is currently no specific treatment, drug or vaccine for the Covid-19, although some home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus spreads in Ecuadorian cities (Quito - Guayaquil).
Explanation: The Ministry of Public Health analyzes a suspicious case. There is no confirmation about the presence of the virus in Ecuador.

What did you fact-check?: The Health Authority confirmed 3 cases of coronavirus in the country.
Explanation: There were no confirmed cases at that time.

What did you fact-check?: The first patient diagnosed with COVID-19 was dead.
Explanation: The patient was still alive.

Who said/posted it?: ZeroHegde, Urn Review, HispanTV, RT, Whatsapp users
Explanation: Nature Medicine magazine published on 17th March that scientists have found Sars-CoV-2 is very different from other coronaviruses and hasn´t evidence of being manipulated or created in lab but it is product of "natural selection". A the the other hands, sources are all-Moscow related and alt-right, conspiracy theories and antisemitism approaches

What did you fact-check?: A dry throat make you more vulnerable to be infected by coronavirus.
Explanation: Already factchecked by Maldita.es, but they found it said Spain instead of Canada.

What did you fact-check?: Lombardia, Italy, ask to Cuba, China and Venezuela to send doctors.
Who said/posted it?: Said by Giulio Gallera, posted by many media and Twitter users, specially related to Maduro
Explanation: Gallera really said that but the next day he explained venezuelan doctors weren´t related to Maduro but to Piccola Venezia, a local italian-venezuela NGO. China send doctors with no relations with him and was Cuba, and not him, which offers to help a week before his speech.

Explanation: Other coronaviruses has started to die over 56°C but there are no studies about Covid-2019.

Who said/posted it?: Americo De Grazia, AlbertoNews (TW) + WhatsApp chain

Explanation: Despite the article cited by the presidente and the Cuban embassy in China claiming that this medicine is being used by Health Secretary in China, there are no proof about it and Interferón 2B has another uses.

What did you fact-check?: A suspicious case of coronavirus in Militay Hospital in Maracay from a army member who claimed have visited China in December.
Explanation: The journalist was misinformed and rushed to publish the information. Every source consulted explained the patient was never suspect or examinated for coronavirus becaue he came from Chine one month and a half ago.

Explanation: WHO confirms bleach and other desinfects might work to kill the virus.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking warm water or tea could prevent contagions.

What did you fact-check?: A herbal tea can cure symptoms of coronavirus, even if it is a bioterrorism weapon.
Explanation: A so-called "doctor" in nanotechnology and antivaccine Venezuelan activist said coronavirus can be cured by electromagnetism and/or this herbal tea. He also claimed he cured presidente Chávez from cancer but then died because he didn´t follow his treatment. This is false.

What did you fact-check?: Ibuprofen worsen coronavirus infection.
Explanation: Ibuprofen could worsen some conditions but there are not proof it could include covid-19. Spanish health authorities has communicated that ibuprofen is not contraindicated to treat first or mild cases.

What did you fact-check?: Helicopters are going to spread chemicals against the coronavirus.
Explanation: False information circulating in many Spanish-speaking countries, from Spain to Honduras.

What did you fact-check?: People with A-blood type are more prone to get coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Egyptian doctor has invented a fluid to treat coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus patients develop lung fibrosis but you can diagnose holding your breath.

What did you fact-check?: Maracaibo in Venezuela is the safest city to avoid coronavirus because it´s too hot, said Unicef.
Explanation: Unicef communicates it hasn´t publish that kind of information.

What did you fact-check?: Availability of a kit for coronavirus self-diagnosis in Italy.
Explanation: On March 9th there was no legal kit for doing Coronavirus self-diagnosis. Only governament authorities are authorized to do it.

What did you fact-check?: Availability of a kit for coronavirus self-diagnosis.
Explanation: A Facebook advertisement selling surgical masks links to a webpage where they sell also a kit for Coronavirus self-diagnosis. On March 9th there was no legal kit for doing Coronavirus self-diagnosis. Only governament authorities are authorized to do it.

What did you fact-check?: A new case of coronavirus 2019-nCoV was registered in Saudi Arabia. A nurse from India was diagnosed with the sepcific strain of the virus.
Who said/posted it?: Original post was from the "Athens News Agency-Macedonian Press Agency"
Explanation: "Acording to Dr. Tarik Al Azraqi, head of the commitee for infectious diseases in Saudi Arabia, the nurse was diagnosed and received treatment for MERS not 2019-nCoV."

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus 2019-nCoV was patented in the past and is human-made, a project in which the Bill and Melinda Gates foundation is involved.
Explanation: "The patent mentioned in the articles in question is about the development of a vaccine for the IBV virus which belongs in a sub-family of the wider category of viruses termed coronaviruses. In short the patent was not for the coronavirus 2019-nCoV."

What did you fact-check?: The bottle of Dettol mentioned the coronavirus since October of 2019 and so the company knew that there was about to be an outbreak of the virus.
Who said/posted it?: Posted on various social media pages and individual accounts
Explanation: "The term coronavirus is an umbrella term for viruses that have specific characteristics. In the Dettol bottle we encounter the term human coronavirus in the list of microbes that this product can deal with. Human coronaviruses are 7 including the newly added 2019-nCoV, so the product did not mention the new type of human coronavirus 2019-nCoV but other members of that specific group."

What did you fact-check?: According to a news reporting, a doctor in the Wuhan hospital was seen collapsing and later lossing his life as a result of being infected from the coronavirus 2019-nCoV in front of patients and hospital staff.
Who said/posted it?: Posts found on social media and news websites
Explanation: "The incident which was captured in the video in question was a violent attack in the public hospital at the city of Quzhou, at the Hejing county in China. The doctor and two of his collegues were injured by the relative of a patient who lost his life after an acute myocardial infarction."

What did you fact-check?: The Canadian Ministry of Health issued a press release which states that they are taking security measures to combat the coronavirus 2019-nCoV.
Who said/posted it?: Posts on various social media pages and accounts
Explanation: "The Canadian Health Ministry didn't issues such a statement and the security measures mentioned are incorrect."

What did you fact-check?: The first building of the Huoshenshan hospital in Wuhan city was build in 5 days.
Explanation: "The building in the pictures that were circulated in social media is the medical center Dabie Mountain which was restructured in order to respond to the coronavirus patients in a short period of time. It is located in the town Huanggang, 75 kilometers away from Wuham."

What did you fact-check?: In a video that went viral on social media we see a street market in the city of Wuhan in China from where the new coronavirus 2019-nCoV began to spread.
Who said/posted it?: Posted on various social media pages and individual accounts as well as prominent news sites
Explanation: "The market seen at the video in question is located in Indonesia, not in China."

Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Doctors reccomend vitamin C and fennel seed tea to help avoid the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: 80 clients of a brothel were put on quarentine due to coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus test costs US$ 3,000 in US.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: The article includes a compilation of different false claims and manipulative photos: 1) false claim saying that there was identified infected person in Georgia, 2) false claim about banana being a source of spread of coronavirus, 3) false claim saying that chinese passengers getting fever medication, 4) false claim about Georgian doctors refusing to screen passengers on the coronavirus in the airport
Who said/posted it?: Facebook page "daily developments", online news website "alia.ge", clickbait site "ambavi.cc", news-front - Russian funded news agency,
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: First infected in Almaty (Kazakhstan).
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: China earned 20 billion dollars on coronavirus.
Explanation: Zombie-fake. For the first time, such a text with a sum of 20 billion and a link (inactive) to the website Faktxeber appeared in 2014 after the annexation of the Crimea, and it featured not China and the leader of the Chinese Communist party, but Russia and Vladimir Putin. As for the Chinese stock markets, they are generally closed until February 3 and transactions are not conducted there.

What did you fact-check?: The Chinese foreign Ministry officially demanded an explanation from the United States due to the fact that containers with biohazard markings were found buried in the evacuated Consulate General in the city of Wuhan.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus may have originated in lab linked to China's biowarfare program.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: China builds a hospital in 48 hours for Coronavius patients.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Kazakhstanis burned and smashed Chinese restaurants and homes because of the spread of coronavirus in the country.
Explanation: The video is real, but the text was misleading. There is no connections between pogroms and coronavirus. It was an ethnic conflict between Kazakhs and Dungans that arose on domestic grounds

What did you fact-check?: "The new fad disease called the “coronavirus” is sweeping headlines. Funny enough, there was a patent for the coronavirus was filed in 2015 and granted in 2018."
Explanation: All of the posts link to patents that are related to two different viruses in the coronavirus family. There is no patent related to the new virus

What did you fact-check?: "So let me get this straight about this virus. It’s “new” yet it was lab created and patented in 2015 (in development since 03’).
Explanation: All of the posts link to patents that are related to two different viruses in the coronavirus family. There is no patent related to the new virus

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin C can “stop” the new coronavirus.
Explanation: While it’s true that vitamin C can have a marginal effect on warding off a cold, there’s no evidence that it can stop or treat the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: We did a Q&A on the facts about the coronavirus.
Explanation: Q&A on the facts about the coronavirus

What did you fact-check?: Donald Trump said about coronavirus, “People are dying who have never died before.”
Explanation: Ernest Hemingway said it.

What did you fact-check?: Social media posts that implied arrested Harvard professor Charles Lieber had a connection to the new coronavirus.
Explanation: Lieber, a nanoscientist, was charged for lying about his participation in a Chinese recruitment program and his affiliation with a Chinese university. He is not accused of being a spy and has no connection to the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Authorities have identified that the international chemical-warfare terrorist ‘Samuel Whitcomb Hyde’ is behind the deadly China ‘coronavirus.'”
Explanation: It's a long-running internet hoax. Sam Hyde is a comedian who is the frequent target of such hoaxes

What did you fact-check?: “CORONAVIRUS: Reports of 10,000 DEAD in Wuhan, China."
Explanation: As of early Jan. 27, the estimated death toll is 81 — all of them in China.

What did you fact-check?: A “Chinese spy team” working in a Canadian government lab sent “pathogens to the Wuhan facility” prior to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: Eric Morrissette, a spokesman for the Public Health Agency of Canada, told us by email, “this is misinformation and there is no factual basis for claims being made on social media.”

What did you fact-check?: “BILL AND MELINDA GATES FOUNDATION & OTHERS PREDICTED UP TO 65 MILLION DEATHS VIA CORONAVIRUS — IN SIMULATION RAN 3 MONTHS AGO!”
Explanation: InfoWars distorted the facts about an emergency preparedness exercise for a fictional pandemic exercise.

What did you fact-check?: Chlorine dioxide kits sold online under various names — Miracle Mineral Solution, Miracle Mineral Supplement, Master Mineral Solution — will cure coronavirus.
Explanation: MMS does not "cure" coronavirus and can be dangerous to your health.

What did you fact-check?: The new coronavirus contains HIV “insertions” and shows signs of being created in a lab.
Explanation: This stems from a poorly done study that was retracted. There is no evidence that the new virus was bioengineered, and every indication it came from an animal.

What did you fact-check?: The new coronavirus can be cured by drinking one bowl of freshly boiled garlic water.
Explanation: There is no known cure for the virus.There are no antiviral treatments that are recommended to prevent or treat the new coronavirus, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

What did you fact-check?: A bovine coronavirus vaccine, for cattle, is proof that the novel coronavirus isn't "new" and is evidence of "how much the media controls people."
Explanation: The cattle vaccine has nothing to do with the COVID-19 virus.

What did you fact-check?: An image of a tweet that purportedly shows Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer criticized President Trump's restrictions on foreign nationals traveling to the US from China.
Explanation: It was a fake tweet.

What did you fact-check?: The government — or specific states such as Michigan or Florida — has mandated that employers and schools close for two weeks.
Explanation: No such announcement has been made. It was apparently a prank.

What did you fact-check?: Pope Francis and his 2 aides have infected with COVID-19.
Explanation: Pope tested negative.

What did you fact-check?: Hand sanitizer will “do nothing for the coronavirus.”
Explanation: CDC says hand sanitizers with 60% alcohol can be used to help prevent contracting and spreading the virus.

What did you fact-check?: A misleading chart being spread on Facebook, erroneously dubbing the new coronavirus the “least deadly virus."
Explanation: The chart cites old data about coronavirus cases and deaths, and it contains an error that makes COVID-19 look less fatal than the 2009 H1N1 “swine flu” outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: President Donald Trump in the next 48 to 72 hours will impose a nationwide “mandatory quarantine.”
Explanation: The White House’s National Security Council addressed the claim in a statement on Twitter, saying: “Text message rumors of a national #quarantine are FAKE. There is no national lockdown.”

What did you fact-check?: Gargling water with salt or vinegar “eliminates” the coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no known treatment for the new coronavirus,according to WHO.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 is no worse than other outbreaks that have occurred in “every election year,” suggesting that the new coronavirus is being “hyped” to hurt President Donald Trump.
Explanation: Most of the dates cited to defend those conclusions about previous outbreaks are misleading or incorrect.

What did you fact-check?: Indian Nurse in Jeddah Detected with Novel coronavirus(2019-nCOV).
Explanation: Official Goverment handles have clarified that The Indian Nurse is not suffering from the deadly 2019-Ncov.

What did you fact-check?: 7 children die of coronavirus with 1 week in Karimganj (Assam, India).
Explanation: Public Health Officials have denied any coronavirus death, these clildren died in a span of 2 months due to fever and other illness.

What did you fact-check?: Video Of An Indonesian Traditional Market Trending Viral As Wuhan, China.
Explanation: an old video from Indonesia shot in July 2019 is being falsely shared as a Market in Wuhan, China which was the origin of the Coronavirus. This video has nothing to do with the Coronavirus or its place of origin.

What did you fact-check?: Image Show Dead People On The Streets Of China.
Explanation: The picture was taken in 2014 in Frankfurt, Germany as a tribute to the victims who lost their lives in a Nazi concentration camp. This image has nothing to do with Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A Sri Lankan Girl Finding A Cure For coronavirus.
Explanation: From our investigation it is evident that any definitive cure or antibiotic for 2019-nCoV has not been discovered as yet. Therefore, the claims of the discovery of a drug that can cure Wuhan Virus are totally baseless.

What did you fact-check?: Prime Minister of China visited a mosque and realised that the only way to protect oneself from coronavirus is to bow before Allah.
Explanation: This Video is from an AP archive repository that was uploaded in 2015 showing ex-Malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi visiting a mosque in China which is falsely being shared as Prime Minister of China visiting a mosque during Coronavirus outbreak in the country. Also as per the AP repository this event took place in the year 2004.

What did you fact-check?: New Confirmed Case Of coronavirus In The Macarthur Region of Australia!
Explanation: This story has not been reported by 7NEWS Sydney news, nor any other news outlets,(7News Sydney confirmed with us).

What did you fact-check?: Fake News Of coronavirus Infecting Boiler Chicken.
Explanation: We found the above circulated post to be False. There is no such confirmation that broiler chicken has been infected by Coronavirus, the source of the disease is yet to found. The images in circulated are old and unrelated.

What did you fact-check?: Manir Hossain, a 23-year-old man from India’s Tripura, had died in a hospital in Malaysia due to coronavirus.
Explanation: Upon our investigation, we found the above news reports to be False. An Indian citizen from Tripura did not die due to Coronavirus in Malaysia. The reason for his death is Status Epilepticus Secondary Meningoencephalitis.

What did you fact-check?: Police Publicly Kill A coronavirus-Infected Woman In China.
Explanation: Video on social media is not related to Coronavirus. The woman in the viral video was taken into custody for violating traffic restrictions in China’s Heilongjiang province.

What did you fact-check?: People in Wuhan locked inside their houses trying to escape building fire.
Explanation: The fire was caused due to electrical wiring failure. This video is not related to COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: WHO declared COVID-19 to be the abbreviation for China Outbreak Virus In December 19.
Explanation: WHO declared the official name of Coronavirus as COVID-19, which stands for Corona Virus Disease. It has been falsely claimed to be an abbreviation for China Outbreak Virus In December 19.

What did you fact-check?: New confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Kolkatta reported by Press trust of India.
Explanation: A clear case of misreporting done by PTI. There are no confirmed Coronavirus patients in Kolkata/Confirmed both by the airport authority of Kolkatta and the Traveller

What did you fact-check?: Bus driver in China vomits blood after becoming unconscious behind the wheel.
Explanation: This video dates back to 2015 when a driver in Xiamen, China was suffering from gastrointestinal bleeding.

What did you fact-check?: Video showing Massive Explosion in Wuhan, China to control the spread of coronavirus.
Explanation: Viral video on social media dates back to 2015 when there were giant explosions at the Chinese port of Tianjin. This video is old and has no relation with Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese converting to Islam after realizing that no Muslim was affected by COVD19 in the country.
Explanation: Viral video is available on the internet since June 2019 and has no relation with the current outbreak of Coronavirus in China.

What did you fact-check?: China needs coronavirus SWAT (special weapons and tactics) police team to arrest this drop dead virus victim.
Explanation: Video shows a mock drill by Tongbai police practicing to take down Coronavirus infected patients in case they are uncooperative.

What did you fact-check?: Cocaine Cures COVID-19.
Explanation: There is still no vaccine or medical treatment available or discovered for COVID-19. Cocaine certainly is not a cure for Coronavirus as it is a stimulant and addictive drug.

What did you fact-check?: Japanese doctors claim Drinking Water Every 15 Minute Prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no Japanese advisory issued regarding frequent consumption of water. World Health Organization has clarified , that drinking water will not prevent a Coronavirus infection.

What did you fact-check?: Muslim People in China seeking refuge in Islam by reading Quran to save themselves from COVID-19.
Explanation: Fact Crescendo found the above post to be False. The video was in existence since the year 2013 which is way before the outbreak of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Consuming onion and salt followed by a glass of water can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence to prove that onion, salt and water can be used to cure COVID-19. Also at present there is no cure for Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Anti-Malaria Drug Chloroquine Is A Cure For coronavirus.
Explanation: Anti- Malaria drug Chloroquine is not an authorized medicine to cure Coronavirus. There is no scientific evidence to prove that Chloroquine can be used to cure COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Indian Ministry of Health and Family Welfare as issued an office memorandum declaring compulsory holiday in four Indian states.
Explanation: Ministry of Health India has denied any such notification.

What did you fact-check?: WHO approves anti-Malarial drug Chloroquine for COVID-19.
Explanation: Fact Crescendo found the details mentioned in the news published by Economic Times to be False. WHO has not declared, approved or recommended anti-malarial drug Chloroquine as a treatment medicine for COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Australian researchers have found that bananas can help prevent infection of COVID-19.
Explanation: We found the post to be False. There is no proof that banana can boost one’s immune system and prevent the disease caused by coronavirus. At present there are no medicines to cure COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Hot air application through a hairdryer on the face to heat up nostrils and the sinus kills the Novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Fact Crescendo found the above-mentioned post to be False. Hot air application through a hairdryer on the face to heat up nostrils will not kill the Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Recording of a conversation where one claims to be a friend of WHO’s India Director’s brother- Saurabh, who gave him information that India will go into a complete lockdown mode from 15th April to 15th June 2020.
Explanation: WHO’s official in SEARO confirmed to us that the viral audio on social media is “Fake”.

What did you fact-check?: Banglore Municipal body (BBMP) will be spraying medicine in the air to kill coronavirus.
Explanation: The BBMP Commissioner, the Mayor and PIB Fact Check India have clarified that the viral message is just a rumor and the BBMP has no such plans to spray any medicine for COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: A video of Pigs being buried in China with is related to the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video showing the mass burial of pigs in China is unrelated with the recent Wuhan virus outbreak. The video is a year old and shows the mass burial of pigs after the outbreak of the African swine fever virus.

What did you fact-check?: A video of bat infested roof claimed to be from Hubei-china claiming it to be the source of coronavirus.
Explanation: This video dates back to 2011, which is almost 9 years ago. This video is from Miami, Florida, USA and has nothing to do with Novel Coronavirus and China.

What did you fact-check?: Sick COVID-19 patients at the airport runway in Senegal.
Explanation: Video is old and not from Italy. It actually shows mock drill carried out on 28 November 2019 at Blaise Diagne Airport in Dakar, the capital of Senegal. It has nothing to do with coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Consuming salt and onion can cure the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: No research available on the topic also Sri Lankan health department officials have officialy dismissed the claim.

What did you fact-check?: Kitchen foods plus morning sunshine can prevent and cure coronavirus.
Explanation: At present there is no evidence to prove that eating kitchen foods like onion, garlic and lemondoes prevent or cure Covid-19 and the same is not recommended by WHO.

What did you fact-check?: Thailand CDC announces green chiretta can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: No such evidence for curing Covid-19 with green chiretta is recommended by WHO or Thailand CDC.

What did you fact-check?: Viral Post claiming that covid-19 infected patient was found in Hsipaw township hospital in Mynamar.
Explanation: Both ministry of health and sports and Sipaw township medical superintendent have issued patient had not contracted the COVID19.

What did you fact-check?: IDH Hospital, main center in Sri Lanka for treating COVID-19 patients, is in shortage of number of assentials.
Explanation: We contacted both doctors and health officials and confirmed that there is no shortage of goods at the hospital as of yet and the messages were fabricated.

What did you fact-check?: Image claims that death bodies from Italy kept in a room.
Explanation: The image is from a Cairo Mosque which was turned into a makeshift morgue in 2013.

What did you fact-check?: Russian president using lions to ensure people stayed indoors in Russia.
Explanation: Lion roaming in Johannesburg street as part of a film production in 2016.

What did you fact-check?: China builds a hospital in 48 hours for coronavius patients.
Explanation: Our fact check reveals that the newly opened hospital is an extended wing of Huanggang Central Hospital, scheduled to open in May 2020. A dedicated work force made the empty building into a fully operational hospital within two days, which was mistaken as the Huoshenshan Hospital proposed to be constructed in 6 days. Huoshenshan hospital is still under construction and is expected to open to the patients on 3rd day of February.

What did you fact-check?: “The person in this Image came with the Chinese lady who was tested positive for coronavirus, fled away avoiding medical tests and is reportedly hidden in Delgoda (In Sri Lanka) area”
Explanation: The allegations are totally baseless and the photo had been taken from a profile of a person named Tharin Gunawardhana, an undergraduate student from the University of Moratuwa and a Srilankan national

What did you fact-check?: Special prayer is organized by the Muslim community in China to save people from coronavirus.
Explanation: Viral video has got nothing to do with the recent Corona virus outbreak

What did you fact-check?: Consuming alcoholic beverages may help reduce the risk of infection by the novel coronavirus; COVID-19.
Explanation: Drinking alcohol does not protect you from coronavirus infection, according to WHO.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus pneumonia is similar to a dry cough & Hot Weather, Garlic And Hot Water Are Remedies for COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no scientific proof that hot and humid weather conditions or drinking warm water and consumption of garlic, onions and other spices can prevent the spread of novel Coronavirus infection.

What did you fact-check?: Channel4's Jon Snow is infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: Jon Snow was on a self-isolation after an Iran assignment in late February and has reported to work after 14day period, and continues to be part of the Channel4 News and to-date has not contracted COVID-19, verified from his Twitter account and verified News sourced.

What did you fact-check?: Traditional Cures And Self-Checks For coronavirus.
Explanation: Our fact check reveals that there is no scientific evidence to prove that drinking water washes down COVID-19 and gargling with warm water & salt or vinegar eliminates the Coronavirus. Similarly the self-check breath test for Coronavirus is absolutely baseless.

What did you fact-check?: Claims Of Cures For COVID-19 From Multiple Countries.
Explanation: While some drugs have provided symptomatic improvement, there is no confirmation that any of the medication currently being tested across different parts of the world is a definitive cure for COVID-19. WHO officially confirms there has not been any definitive vaccine or antiviral drug developed to prevent or treat COVID-19 to date, hence all above claims are misleading.

What did you fact-check?: Viral claims propogating UNICEF Message About coronavirus.
Explanation: Mr. Jeremy Sprigge, Communication Specialist of UNICEF Sri Lanka confirmed that “these messages are NOT UNICEF statements and henceforth FALSE” and that an official communication regarding the same would be published via UNICEF’s social media channels.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus infected girl was admitted to Badulla Hospital in Sri Lanka.
Explanation: “The girl was tested negative for Coronavirus, and she was administered medicines for her ailment and then discharged”.

What did you fact-check?: Mélange Of Unrelated Videos From China Shared Misleadingly In Context To Recent Corona Virus Outbreak.
Explanation: A mix of different unrelated videos from China have been merged to create this misleading video shared in context to Corona Virus. People infected by Corona Virus 2019-nCoV, do not exhibit the symptoms such as howling like dogs and biting as shown in the video.

What did you fact-check?: "Gale of the wind" and "Neem Tree" leaves are good medicine to protect from the coronavirus.
Who said/posted it?: Crime news Srilanka and number of Tamil FB Users
Explanation: As stated by WHO still there is no official remedy or cure for COVID-19, while some of the traditional methods have symptomatic improvements.

What did you fact-check?: Man contracts COVID-19 by eating mutton.
Explanation: It's a fake news card and the news channel has denied publishing any such news.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus will be cured after a 14 hours curfew.
Explanation: Novel Coronavirus have differnt life spans on differnt objects however it can live upto 2 to 3 days.

What did you fact-check?: Pope Francis ran away at a public meeting due to coronavirus fear.
Explanation: This video dates back to 2019 and is not related to COVID19.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows Chinese police crackdown on suspected COVID-19 patients.
Explanation: We found the video to be False because this is an old video A from Hong Kong showing riot police storm a metro station to crack down on political protesters in the city.

What did you fact-check?: Bitter gourd juice can cure coronavirus in just two hours.
Explanation: PIB India clarified that this viral message is Fake. According to WHO there is no cure medicine discovered or recommended to cure Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: After COVID-19 outbreak in europe Muslims and non-Muslims have come out in the streets shouting praises for Allah and reading Kalma.
Explanation: Fact Crescendo found the viral video to be unrelated. The video dates back before the outbreak of COVID-19 in Europe. This is a demonstration march by the citizens in Hamburg, Germany in solidarity with Uyghur Muslims.

What did you fact-check?: People In Wuhan Locked inside their houses by the Chinese goverment.
Explanation: The video is of people in wuhan offering their respects to the whistleblower, doctor Li Wenliang.

What did you fact-check?: Saddam Hussein predicted coronavirus outbreak 40 years ago.
Explanation: The video is edited and was shot before the Iraq war. In the video Saddam Hussein can be seen discussing prospects of war with his military advisors and son Qusay. There's no mention of CoronaVirus in the actual video.

What did you fact-check?: "Only India can resist CoronaVirus."- Saudi Crown Prince Mohammad Bin Salman.
Explanation: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammad Bin Salman has not made any such statement.

What did you fact-check?: Image of coffins from Italy showing carnage due to recent COVID-19 outbreak.
Explanation: The image is 7 years old and is of the dead bodies of African immigrants who died while entering Italy.

What did you fact-check?: Dettol sanitizer can kill coronavirus. The company knew about the coronavirus back in 2019.
Explanation: The ‘Coronavirus’ mentioned on Dettol bottle is the previous strains of Coronavirus, not the 2019 novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV). Also, Dettol manufacturer (‘RB’) has clarified that they do not yet have more details of the new virus and are not yet in a position to confirm levels of effectiveness against the new strain.

What did you fact-check?: No more deaths from COVID-19 as Israel scientists have discovered a vaccine for COVID-19.
Explanation: Various vaccines proposed by Israel scientists and other researchers across the world are under development and are yet to be cleared for production and distribution. Israel’s MIGAL Research Institute is also in the process of producing a vaccine for COVID-19. According to WHO, as on 11 March 2020, there is no vaccine for COVID-19.
