What did you fact-check?: Effects of Coronovirus on an affected persons lip.
Explanation: The video shared a effectof Coronovirus on a patient lip is found to be on the internet at least since November-2019 i.e. before the recent epidemic broke out. So, it is not related to the recent Coronavirus epidemic.

What did you fact-check?: 4 people died in Hyderabad (India) due to coronavirus.
Explanation: No cases of Coronavirus have been reported in India at this time.

What did you fact-check?: Ministry of health’s emergency notification to the public about coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The advisory message has not been issued by the Health Ministry. Also, in the precautions released by the Ministry, there is nothing related to keeping the throat moist.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a girl dying of coronavirus.
Explanation: The girl in the video has not died due to Coronavirus. The family of the girl and the Malaysian Health Ministry have confirmed that the rumours about the girl’s death are FALSE.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a market in Wuhan (China), the suspected origin of the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The video was taken at an animal market in Langowan (Indonesia). It is not related to Wuhan (China).

What did you fact-check?: Two ways of wearing a surgical mask: Colored side out if you are sick and white side out if you do not want to become sick.
Explanation: There is only one way of wearing a three-layered surgical mask. The colored side of the surgical mask should face outwards.

What did you fact-check?: Video of the new hospital set up by China for coronavirus patients.
Explanation: The video is found to exist on the internet at least since 2018. So, the claim that it shows the new hospital set up by China for Coronavirus patients is FALSE.

What did you fact-check?: Xi Jinping has said that Chinese scientists found cure for coronavirus in cow urine.
Explanation: Xi Jinping did not make the statements regarding gaumutra (Cow urine) mentioned in the post.

What did you fact-check?: Image of coronavirus victims in China.
Explanation: The image is from Germany and it shows people lying down in a pedestrian zone, as part of an art project in Frankfurt, in remembrance of victims of the Katzbach Nazi concentration camp.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a family died due to novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was found on the internet at least since the last week of December 2019. But the first death from the novel Coronavirus was reported only in the second week of January 2020.

What did you fact-check?: Video of Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang visiting a Mosque and offering prayers seeking protection to the country from coronavirus.
Explanation: The man in the video is not Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang, he is former Malaysian PM Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. The video was taken in 2015 and it shows Badawi visiting ‘Nan Xia Po’ Mosque in Beijing to offer his Friday prayers.

What did you fact-check?: 2019 novel coronavirus can be cured by one bowl of freshly boiled garlic.
Explanation: World Health Organization (WHO) has issued a clarification that garlic may have some antimicrobial properties but there is no evidence that it can protect people from the 2019 novel Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Videos of Pigs being buried in China due to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The videos posted are old. They are in no way related to the recent Coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: President Xi Jinping visits Masjid to pray for the coronavirus vicitims.
Explanation: 2016 video of Xi Jjinping visiting a mosque is being shared in the context of the recent Coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Peope behaving abnormally in China due to coronavirus.
Explanation: Old video clips are shared in the context of the recent Coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus found in Broiler Chicken.
Explanation: No evidence to prove that Coronovirus found in the broiler chickens. WHO has clarified that meat cooked properly can be consumed.

What did you fact-check?: Video of bats found under the tiles of many roofs in Hubei, China. They were the source of coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was not taken in China. It’s an old video uploaded on 05 July 2011 by a Miami based roofing company called ‘Istueta Roofing’. The bats in the video were found under the tiles during the process of replacing a roof for a customer in Miami (US).

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus patients in China are being caught by officials on a highway.
Explanation: The video in the post is the video of a ‘Mock drill’. The China SWAT team in the video is ‘practising’ to deal with Coronavirus patients.

What did you fact-check?: Video of police killing COVID-19 affected people in China.
Explanation: The posted video was edited with three unrelated clips to falsely claim that Police with arms are killing people. The Yiwu Police have clarified that the armed Police in the video were on their duty to kill a rabid dog. And, the last clip is related to an accident.

What did you fact-check?: Runny nose and coughing sputum suggest that one does not have COVID-19. They are not symptoms of COVID-19.
Explanation: In the advisories issued by WHO, it can be seen that ‘runny nose’ and ‘sputum production’ are also symptoms of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Precautionary measures suggested by the UNICEF.
Explanation: The viral message was not issued by the UNICEF. Some of the measures suggested in the message contradict the WHO’S view on COVID-19. Also, some have no scientific evidence.

What did you fact-check?: Aaj Tak channel telecasted a program that said drinking alcohol or smoking weed can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: Aaj Tak channel did not telecast any program that said drinking alcohol or weed can cure COVID-19. The posted photos are taken from their fact-check episode. In the episode, they debunk the claim and conclude that neither a peg of alcohol nor weed can cure COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Aaj Tak telecasted a news in which the Chinese PM said, ‘Reading Quran and offering namaz is the only cure for COVID-19’.
Explanation: It is a clipped video of Aaj Tak’s fact-check. In the full version, it can be seen that Aaj Tak has debunked the claim and concluded that no such statement was made by the Chinese PM.

What did you fact-check?: AIIMS (Indian medical institute) team has said that Toddy has medicinal properties to cure coronavirus.
Explanation: AIIMS team has never said that Toddy has medicinal properties to cure Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Most affected countries by COVID-19 are along the same 40-degree North latitude.
Explanation: 40-degree North latitude passes through some of the countries most affected by COVID-19 but does not pass through half of the locations given in the post. Also, it does not touch Wuhan (Hubei Province – where around 60% of all the positive cases are reported), which is at around 30-degree North latitude.

What did you fact-check?: Photo of Meat (mutton) affected by coronavirus.
Explanation: It is a photoshopped image. No proof so far that Coronavirus is present in mutton.

What did you fact-check?: Video of Police in China taking into control suspected COVID-19 patients in the country.
Explanation: The video shows Police in Hong Kong taking into control demonstrators who were protesting against the introduction of a controversial bill that would have allowed extraditions to mainland China.

What did you fact-check?: After husband tested positive for coronavirus, wife fled from Bangalore to Agra in India.
Explanation: The woman went to her parents place in Agra on 9 March, while her husband was confirmed positive for coronavirus on 12 March. Also, she didn’t enter Bangalore city. Karnataka government has also clarified that the woman didn’t flee to her parents’ place.

What did you fact-check?: Indian President Ramnath Kovind pouring gaumutra (cow urine) on globe to prevent coronavirus.
Explanation: 2017 image falsely shared as President Ramnath Kovind pouring gaumutra on a globe to prevent Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A worker of Prince hotel in Mehdipatnam (Hyderbad, India) has tested positive for coronavirus.
Explanation: The message is fake. In Telangana state, till date, only one confirmed case of Coronavirus is reported and the person who tested positive for the virus is a software engineer.

What did you fact-check?: Office Memorandum of the Indian Ministry of Health & Family Welfare declaring holidays to the states of Maharashtra, Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh and Sikkim in the wake of COVID-19.
Explanation: No, the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare hasn’t declared holidays to the states of Maharashtra, Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh and Sikkim. The Office Memorandum with such information is ‘fake’.

What did you fact-check?: 5000 million Rupees fund allocated by Telangana CM KCR for coronavirus prevention is entirely funded by Central Government.
Explanation: No, the entire fund is not given by the Central Government.

What did you fact-check?: Video of American President Donald Trump announcing that Roche Medical Company will launch the vaccine for COVID-19 next Sunday.
Explanation: In the video, American President Donald Trump hasn’t said that Roche Medical Company will launch the vaccine for COVID-19. He announced FDA’s approval of a Coronavirus ‘test’ developed by a company ‘Roche’ to increase and accelerate the country’s capacity to test for the virus.

What did you fact-check?: 2000 people died of COVID-19 in one day (on March 15) in France.
Explanation: As per WHO, 36 people died of COVID-19 in France on March 15, not 2000 people.

What did you fact-check?: Oman is releasing pesticides in the air through helicopters to eliminate coronavirus.
Explanation: Oman's Health Minsitry has clarified that they are not conducting any such operation with helicopters.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking water every 15 mins will protect people from coronavirus.
Explanation: WHO has clarified that drinking water is important for overall health but it does not prevent coronavirus infection.

What did you fact-check?: Gargling with lukewarm water mixed with salt/vinegar will remove coronavirus.
Explanation: Press Information Bureau (India) has clarified that Coronavirus cannot be treated by gargling with warm water mixed with salt and vinegar.

What did you fact-check?: Facts about coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: An FAQ on the recent Coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Iran’s deputy Health Minister: This year we have had 13,200 flu cases which caused the death of 108 people. Our population is a fourth of the US’s. Last year they had 28 million flu cases which resulted in 16k deaths. Yet nobody is restricting travel.
Explanation: Flu’s death rate in the US is less than 0.1% and moreover deputy minister’s comparison of flu and covid19 is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: Children under 8 are immune to the novel coronavirus.
Who said/posted it?: Socila Media and some News Agencies
Explanation: Official WHO reports indicate that among infected there have been children as young as 2. Malaysian press have reported that 3 coronavirus cases in Malaysia include a 2-year-old boy. Also Australia's ABC reports: Queensland confirms third coronavirus case as eight-year-old child from Wuhan, China.

What did you fact-check?: Health Canada has advised that by keeping the throat moist (by drinking water) can help preventing infection.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence to support this. Health Canada has never suggested this method.

What did you fact-check?: The claim that the book The Eyes of Darkness predict the spread of coronavirus in 1981.
Explanation: The book is a work of fiction that mentions a biological weapon called Wuhan-400 (Originally Gorki-400) that has no similarities to the Covid19. The other page, is from a totally different book “End of Days” by American psychic Sylvia Browne.

What did you fact-check?: The name coronavirus on disinfecting spray can reaffirms that the virus was known before the outbreak and might be planned.
Explanation: Coronaviruses have been known for decades. SARS and MERS were caused by coronaviruses. The companies (Lysol, Clorox,etc) have stated that their products have demonstrated effectiveness against viruses “similar” to COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: The cover of a Tintin book titled "Tintin in Wuhan" that shows the character standing in an old Chinese market wearing special suits, while people are wearing masks.
Explanation: This is a doctored image that is made of frames from two different Tintin books.

What did you fact-check?: The Simpsons have predicted the coronavirus pandemic years ago, along with many other predictions.
Explanation: Other than the "Osaka Flu" infecting many residents of Springfield, the events of the episode Marge in Chains (1993) have no similarities with the Covid19 pandemic and what is currently happening around the world.

What did you fact-check?: Exposing Parviz Nouri Sayha, who claims he has made the medicine for coronavirus.
Explanation: Our investigations show that almost everything this person, who calls himself “professor” claims is fake and unfounded. Even his resume and bibliography is filled with fabricated items

What did you fact-check?: Iran's head of judiciary: the first centers that volunteered to suspend activities in response to the coronavirus outbreak were religious Institutions and those connected to the clergy.
Who said/posted it?: Iran's head of judiciary, Ebrahim Raiesi
Explanation: This is an outrageous claim and couldn't be farther from the truth. Weeks after the outbreak, holy shrines and mosques refused to close down.

What did you fact-check?: Iran's former president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad: It is clear to the world that the mutated coronavirus was produced in lab, manufactured by the warfare stock houses of biological war belonging to world powers.
Explanation: This is absolutely baseless.

What did you fact-check?: The claim that a scientific paper published in Nature in 2015, shows that the new virus was developed in labs.
Explanation: On the contrary, the authors state that viruses similar to SARS have been detected in populations of bats.

What did you fact-check?: Quotes by Finnish national health authorities between 20th of January and 3rd of March taken out of context.
Explanation: Currently, an image with the title "THL and coronavirus in the news" is being circulated in social media, gathering comments from the National Institute for Health and Welfare on coronavirus from January to March. The statements quoted by THL experts are quoted but appear to be largely inaccurate when removed from context. The list as a whole is deliberately misleading. Its purpose is to undermine the credibility of the responsible authority, THL, without providing it with verified information.

What did you fact-check?: BIll Gates contributed to the spread of coronavirus.
Explanation: The work that Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation does on healthcare has in no way contributed to the spread of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is enabled by 5G technology.
Explanation: There is no scientific proof that coronavirus is in any way linked to 5G.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is caused by bat soup.
Explanation: There is no evidence that eating bat-soup is the cause of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus was created in laboratory in Wuhan.
Explanation: There is no evidence that coronavirus was created in a laboratory in Wuhan.

What did you fact-check?: Medical book states that coronavirus is just a common cold.
Explanation: COVID-19 is more dangerous than the common cold.

What did you fact-check?: Holding your breath for 10 seconds can determine if you have COVID-19, drink water every 15 minutes.
Explanation: The article lists myths that go against WHO recommendations.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking water in which garlic was boiled will cure you from COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support this claim.

What did you fact-check?: image showing italian doctors exhausted and sleeping.
Explanation: Images that were used belong to a campaign in Mexico for healtworkers rights.

What did you fact-check?: Propolis cures COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support this claim.

What did you fact-check?: A secret invasion of 40 thousand american troops immune to COVID-19 is ongoing in Europe.
Explanation: A secret invasion of 40 thousand American troops on Europe is not happening.

What did you fact-check?: Corporations invented the coronavirus.
Explanation: there is no evidence to support this claim.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 arrived in the US by train.
Explanation: The photo has been manipulated.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 is a human made, and an American biological weapon
Explanation: Scientific reseach shows that the virus is not human made.

What did you fact-check?: Croatian president tells people to buy in bulk for at least 2 weeks.
Explanation: The president did not say you should buy food to sustain you for two weeks.

What did you fact-check?: The link between COVID-19 and 5G is being hidden.
Explanation: The link is not being hidden because it doesn't exist.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is actually chemtrail lungs.
Explanation: Chemtrail lungs do not exist as a condition.

What did you fact-check?: Wash your throat with salted water and apple vineger to cure COVID-19.
Explanation: WHO and other medical institutions say this is not a cure.

What did you fact-check?: Spanish scientist says go to Ronaldo or Messi for the cure, as they are better paid.
Explanation: The former Spanish minister for agriculture never said this.

What did you fact-check?: You should leave your shoes outside, as they carry the virus.
Explanation: Official sources say this is not true.

What did you fact-check?: These images show coffins of COVID-19 victims in Italy.
Explanation: Images in question were actually taken in 2013.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese claim that the virus was created in 2015 in US.
Explanation: There's no evidence that supports this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Cristiano Ronaldo turned his hotels into hospitals.
Explanation: The claim is false.

What did you fact-check?: 35 Italians tourists don't want to leave Ethiopia and go back in Italy because of the coronavirus.
Explanation: Testimonies seems to be invented and the characters quoted does not exist. The website is well known for clickbait content and false stories.

What did you fact-check?: Another video showing a woman eating a bat soup in Wuhan.
Who said/posted it?: Twitter, Facebook, YouTube, TikTok, Instagram users, anonymous
Explanation: We tracked the girl's social media accounts, confirmed they were authentic. She claims the video was taken over the summer but wouldn't tell were. The set up and meal look like Palau traditionnal bat soup but we couldn't confirm.

What did you fact-check?: Close-up of a bat soup bowl that is eaten in Wuhan, or elsewhre in China.
Who said/posted it?: Twitter, Facebook, YouTube, TikTok, Instagram users, anonymous
Explanation: A local source in Palau said he recognized a specific local restaurant. Table, room setting and plates' decorations match with other pictures found online showing tourist dining in unspecified restaurant in Palau. Not enough elements for us to call it false but pretty close.

What did you fact-check?: This video shows a woman eating a bat soup in Wuhan.
Explanation: Video shot in Palau in 2016.

What did you fact-check?: This video shows a man eating a bat soup in a restaurant in China.
Explanation: With identified many elements in the video that matched pictures published by Chinese bloggers who visited Palau and documented their trip.

What did you fact-check?: Filipinos are eating a bat soup in Wuhan.
Explanation: YouTubers made the video last July in Palau.

What did you fact-check?: Bat market and bat meat being sold in Wuhan.
Explanation: Video taken in Indonesia (Manado)

What did you fact-check?: Video of Wuhan market with dogs, snakes, rats and bats...
Explanation: Video taken in Indonesia (Langowan)

What did you fact-check?: Caption on YouTube: "doctor affected by the virus hospital wuhan china".
Explanation: Prior instances of the video had captions, confirmed by media reports, said the video showed a doctor collapsing in Yunnan province because of overwork and hypoglycemia.

What did you fact-check?: People panicking about a COVID-19 case at the Dakar Airport.
Explanation: this footage has nothing to do with the coronavirus pandemic and was taken out of context from a Senegalese TV footage showing an exercise.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese police use a fishing net to arrest a man with a high fever.
Explanation: The video shows a police training exercise.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese police kill a woman escaping a COVID-19 quarantine in China.
Explanation: The scene actually shows a motorbike accident.

What did you fact-check?: People lying on the ground in China because they got coronavirus.
Explanation: Video comes from South Africa during a initiation rite in a private school.

What did you fact-check?: Chinse people fleeing China to Vietnam because of coronavirus.
Explanation: People are actually going from Vietnam to China for work.

What did you fact-check?: First patient healed in Algeria.
Explanation: The man is from Morocco and appears in a TV add for an hospital in Morocco.

What did you fact-check?: Senegalese president and government appears with masks during a press conference.
Explanation: The picture is digitally edited to add the masks.

What did you fact-check?: Panic scene in Germany with people rushing into a supermarket.
Explanation: The video is taken during the sales.

What did you fact-check?: Demonstrations against Chinese people in Italy.
Explanation: Anti-fascist demonstration on February 22 in Roma.

What did you fact-check?: Racist scene against Chinese people in the metro in Belgium.
Explanation: Vidéo is an excerpt of the Youtube channel "Would you react" with actors.

What did you fact-check?: OMS staff member is spreading coronavirus on purpose.
Explanation: The man is an astrophysician, and he is touching this lady because she is his girlfriend, and she is sick.

What did you fact-check?: Picture showing the Mecca totally empty.
Explanation: The picture is from a miniature designed by an artist.

What did you fact-check?: Saddam Hussein explaining what is coronavirus about.
Explanation: Sound has been edited. It's a video from 2003 where Saddam Hussein is talking about the USA/Irak war.

What did you fact-check?: A train carrying vaccines with the inscription COVID-19.
Explanation: Content seems to be digitally edited, and there is no inscription on that location on such trains.

What did you fact-check?: franceinfo hosted a chat with a scientist in order to answer questions about the coronavirus, including fake news
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: A Chinese woman from Wuhan arrived in France with suspected symptoms of coronavirus.
Explanation: The Chinese embassy in France confirmed the presence of this Chinese woman in France and said that she gave reassuring news. According to French authorities, investigations are underway, but this suspicious case has never been officially reported.

What did you fact-check?: Statistics are predicting millions of dead people and billions of infected people in a few days.
Explanation: There is no modelization of the virus yet. So it's impossible to predict anything about the epidemic.

What did you fact-check?: Why it's dangerous to make your own hand sanitizer at home.
Explanation: It's dangerous to create your own hand sanitizer at home but DIY videos dont' tell you that.

What did you fact-check?: Do Americans have to pay 3000 or 4000 $ for a day of containment?
Explanation: Some Americans had to pay 3000 or 4000 $ after being contained in hospital.

What did you fact-check?: Did the French Health minister underestimate the risk of contamination in France?
Explanation: The French Health minister really said that the risk of seeing the virus spreading in France was almost equal to zero, but it was at the very beginning of the outbreak in China and her statement was consistent with the datas she had.

What did you fact-check?: Is it true that people can't use the right of withdrawal at work because of the outbreak?
Explanation: French labor law experts think that the risk of being infected with the virus at work can be a reason to refuse going back to work in some cases, but not all.

What did you fact-check?: Did the coronavirus mutated and became more agressive?
Explanation: Chinese scientists discovered that this coronavirus has taken two different types. They suggest that the second type could be more aggressive. But this is only a theory, never tested in lab and French scientists consider that there no really important mutation of the virus yet.

What did you fact-check?: Does France underestimate the outbreak?
Explanation: On social networks, many users claim that the number of coronavirus cases in France is underestimated, because there are fewer tests in France than elsewhere. But this international comparison is not really relevant.

What did you fact-check?: Will the coronavirus epidemic disappear in April thanks to the heat, as Donald Trump said?
Explanation: It's impossible to predict the evolution of this epidemi, because this coronavirus is a new virus. Weather probably plays a role, but it remains to be determined among other factors.

What did you fact-check?: Can pets contaminate humans?
Explanation: According to the WHO, there is no evidence that dogs or cats can be infected with the new coronavirus. French medical experts confirm that a virus crossing the species barrier is rare.

What did you fact-check?: A package from AliExpress sent from China can spread the new coronavirus.
Who said/posted it?: Multiple Twitter accounts + Messages on franceinfo.fr news feed
Explanation: The coronavirus need a living host to grow. This kind of virus lives only a few days in a liquid and only a few hours on an object. The virus would die during the long transport from China to France, for example. The scientist never observed this king of contamination before with any kind of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus was created and patented by an American lab two years before this epidemy.
Explanation: These pre-existing patents are referring to other viruses and coronaviruses.

What did you fact-check?: Scientists and experts answer questions and rumors about the coronavirus (bat soup, Wuhan P4 Laboratory, patented virus, people collapsing, etc).
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Cats and dogs can be infected and can contaminate humans with COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence that pets such as dogs or cats can be infected with the new coronavirus, say WHO and French medical experts.

What did you fact-check?: A confidential governmental document proves that the government has decided to postpone local elections in France because of the outbreak.
Explanation: This document is a fake. The government didn't take this decision.

What did you fact-check?: French far right leader Marine Le Pen says that the EU didn't do anything against the outbreak
Explanation: The EU has activated the civil protection mechanism, launched aid program, mobilizes funds for research and called for more international cooperation and coordination.

What did you fact-check?: Is it useful to close borders to stop the outbreak?
Explanation: French medical experts say closing borders in order to prevent infected people from entering in France is ineffective. Likewise, health tests before entering the country have little effect.

What did you fact-check?: Does a sulfur dioxide pollution in Wuhan reveal that China is burning bodies of victims?
Explanation: The map behind the rumor is not a real-time air quality report, but a forecast based on past datas, which therefore cannot take account of alleged recent events.

What did you fact-check?: Satellite images showing high levels of sulphur dioxide above China are possible evidence of mass cremations of people who have died from coronavirus.
Explanation: False. The maps are not satellite images, and do not show actual levels of sulphur dioxide. They are simply forecasts based on historical data and weather patterns.

What did you fact-check?: 8 coronavirus patients in Ghana have recovered.
Explanation: Please read the full article

What did you fact-check?: DailyMail reported that a virus leaked from the Wuhan National Biosafety Laboratory was responsible for the pandemic.
Explanation: The DailyMail article didn’t report that. Rutgers University microbiologist Dr Richard Ebright told DailyMail that "at this point there’s no reason to harbour suspicions" that the facility had anything to do with the outbreak, besides being responsible for the crucial genome sequencing that lets doctors diagnose it.

What did you fact-check?: "Japan has sent many masks to Wuhan, China. But China hasn’t supported Japan ever before."
Explanation: China sent their rescue team and many goods at Great East Japan earthquake (2011), donated a lot of money to Japan at the 2016 Kumamoto Earthquake, and the Heavy Rain of July, 2018.

What did you fact-check?: A team from @WorldPopProject has heat mapped the highest risk counties for the #Wuhancoronavirus. "Japan has the second highest country because the Abe administration doesn’t emforce immigration restrictions."
Explanation: The ranking is based on Lunar New Year travel prior to the holiday in 2018. This report does not refer to any countries immigration restrictions in this year. Japan has the second highest risk country but it's not related to the immigration policy.

What did you fact-check?: "Some Japanese people infected with the novel coronavirus were refused from a charter flight from Wuhan to Tokyo (on Jan.30) without any Japanese legal basis."
Explanation: It is true that two Japanese people who may have been infected could not take a charter flight. They were not permitted to go through the Chinese immigration office because they were stuck at the quarantine station by Chinese medical staff. Japan didn't refuse them.

What did you fact-check?: The Korean Government pay travellers' medical expense for coronavirus without basis law.
Explanation: According to IHR 2005, government is responsible for paying medical treatment expense to travellers. Accordingly, related Act also defines it.

What did you fact-check?: All the soldiers in South Korea cannot go on leave because of the novel coronavirus(2019-nCoV) outbreak.
Explanation: South Korea's ministry of national defense said, "The restrictions on all soldiers are not true at all. However, we only partially limited the area where there were confirmed cases."

What did you fact-check?: According to a certain document, there are infected cases in some areas of South Korea, but the Korean government is hiding the cases.
Explanation: The documents are confirmed as crafted documents. These case are under investigation by Korean police.

What did you fact-check?: The Korean Government took every facial mask from factorys to send masks to China.
Explanation: Some sellers claimed this to consumers. However, it turns out to be false.

What did you fact-check?: The Chinese government announced on official document "Garlic is a preventive food for Novel coronavirus."
Explanation: The official document is not from China's central government. It's from Shanghai city government. On this original document, there is no mention about garlic or preventive food.

What did you fact-check?: Novel coronavirus is commuicated by package or imported goods shipping from China to Korea.
Explanation: Currently there is no evidence to support transmission of novel coronavirus by imported goods. Also there have not been such cases in Korea.

What did you fact-check?: New coronavirus arrives in Colombia.
Explanation: The piece says the Wuhan coronavirus was afound in a patient in the town of Ibagué, Colombia, and shows a written diagnosis to show it. However, the image shows it to be a different sort of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A case of new coronavirus was confirmed in the city of Ibagué, in Colombia.
Explanation: Health authorities had not confirmed the case and they were the only ones to be able to do so beacuse they are the ones who can test.

What did you fact-check?: Jair Bolsonaro has the new coronavirus.
Explanation: Health authorities had not confirmed the case and they were the only ones to be able to do so beacuse they are the ones who can test. It was a clickbait.

What did you fact-check?: Garlic heals the new coronovirus.
Explanation: WHO said that there is no evidence that proves that garlic heals coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Healthy ministry sent an email about the new coronavirus.
Explanation: Colombian Ministry of Health explained that the email was false.

What did you fact-check?: 30 cases of new coranvirus in the city of Barranquilla, in Colombia.
Explanation: At the time of this publicaction, the Health ministry hadn´t confirmed any cases of coronavirus in Barranquilla.

What did you fact-check?: Saline water kills the new coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no solid scientific evidence to indicate that mouthwash and saline water kills coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Tips for the new coronavirus: holding breath and drinking water.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence to indicate that holding breath and drinking water every 15 minutes kills coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: China finds a vaccine for the new coronavirus.
Explanation: Chine didn't find a vaccine for coronavirus..

What did you fact-check?: Ibuprofen aggravates patients with the new coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence that conclusively proves ibuprofen aggravates coronavirus patients.

What did you fact-check?: A photo of coffins of dead people as a result of the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The images were taken in October 2013.

What did you fact-check?: People with type A blood are more prone to get the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The study is preliminary and there is no scientific evidence that supports the relation between type blood and Covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: A huge container of soda drinks was infected wirh coronavirus.
Explanation: There was no contamination. There is no evidence of coronavirus in the country or of its ability to contaminate soda drinks.

What did you fact-check?: There's a definitive proof that chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine, are effective against COVID-19.
Explanation: Studies have shown some early promise, but it's not entirely solid to say the treatments work against coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Initial Lack Of Evidence For Human-To-Human COVID-19 Transmission Unusual.
Explanation: We lined up the tweets from WHO and showed there was a progression from not know to the transmission being human-to-human

What did you fact-check?: 5G technology caused the coronavirus.
Explanation: Historical events were conflated, and did not back up claims with real evidence.

What did you fact-check?: WHO director overstated COVID-19 fatality rate as more than flu.
Explanation: CDC data and doctors said that coronavirus has much higher mortality rate than flu.

What did you fact-check?: Walmart closing hundreds of its stores.
Explanation: This story is several years old, and there has been no recent announcement.

What did you fact-check?: Cristiano Ronaldo bought private island to escape coronavirus.
Explanation: Ronaldo's management company confirmed it was false.

What did you fact-check?: Trump said "people are dying who have never died before".
Explanation: Searches in databases of the phrase never show up. Other fact checks confirm fabrication.

What did you fact-check?: Obama family flown to private island to escape coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: Website has visible disclaimers saying it is purely satire.

What did you fact-check?: Link takes viewers to application for FEMA assistance in the US.
Explanation: Link just takes you to a meme picture.

What did you fact-check?: Fox News won Pulitzer for coronavirus coverage.
Explanation: Claim made on website that is clearly labeled as satire.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates and Vatican have a plan to depopulate world with coronavirus vaccine.
Explanation: Video clip taken out of context from 2010 Gates TedTalk.

What did you fact-check?: Homeland Security mobilizing national guard to combat coronavirus.
Explanation: National Guard refuted claims.

What did you fact-check?: Joe Biden tested positive for coronavirus.
Explanation: Another news publication refuted the false claim.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus cases linked to 5G rollout.
Explanation: Overlaps in the map between 5G and cases can be explained by population density.

What did you fact-check?: Photo shows coffins from coronavirus outbreak in Italy.
Explanation: Old photo from African migrants who died from shipwreck in 2013.

What did you fact-check?: Tom Hanks died, confessed admiration for Trump.
Explanation: Story published by clear death-hoax website.

What did you fact-check?: Helicopters Are Spraying Disinfectants To Try To Eradicate coronavirus.
Explanation: False information being spread on Facebook. Completely made up, but post is spreading across countries.

What did you fact-check?: That a 2015 research article about a lab-made coronavirus referred to the current outbreak.
Explanation: It was an opinion piece, and while facts used in the article appear accurate, it did not refer to the current coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is in Des Moines.
Explanation: The story came from a prank website where it got over 9000 Facebook engagements

What did you fact-check?: Scripps urgent care in San Diego is on lockdown, two people with coronavirus isolated.
Explanation: Scripps denied it was true through their Twitter account, there was one person with the flu but no coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Lysol Products Can Kill Novel coronavirus.
Explanation: While Lysol products are advertised to kill 99.9% of bacteria and viruses, including coronavirus, the company is referring to previous strains of the virus. There is no known cure for the novel (or new) coronavirus strain.

What did you fact-check?: Common Cold Is The Only Type Of coronavirus.
Explanation: Coronaviruses can cause different illnesses in animals and humans, including the common cold. However, they can also lead to severe diseases such as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).

What did you fact-check?: States Are Imposing Mandatory Leave And Statewide School Closures Due To coronavirus.
Explanation: Though schools have closed since this announcement, at the time of its original posting, it was not true.

What did you fact-check?: All baby formula providers are shipping formula for free during coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: Enfamil and Gerber issued statements clarifying this is a hoax.

What did you fact-check?: Evidence Shows The WHO Director-General Overstated COVID-19 Fatality Rate
Explanation: All evidence says the WHO director-general was on point. This is a ultra-conservative false spin on what the director-general said, getting many facts and medical numbers wrong.

What did you fact-check?: A meme posted offers mixed advice -- some true, some false -- about coronavirus protection.
Explanation: The claims in this meme are muddled.

What did you fact-check?: "Patent on this "new" coronavirus expired on the 22nd, today".
Explanation: As noted above, the patent for the vaccine for this new Wuhan strain did not expire on January 22, 2020. That patent is related to the SARS epidemic, which killed more than 800 people after it broke out in China in 2002.

What did you fact-check?: "There's magically already a vaccine available."
Explanation: Anthony S. Fauci, a top official at the National Institutes of Health (NIH), told Bloomberg Law that a potential vaccine "could move into early-stage human testing in the next three months."

What did you fact-check?: That the China-centered coronvirus had infected 2.8 million people and killed 112,000.
Explanation: This was a wild exaggeration of the facts. It supposedly relied on reporting from "covert intelligence sources." At the time of the story, some 900 people had been infected and 26 had died.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus Outbreak Prompted Gun And Ammunition Policy Changes At Walmart.
Explanation: Walmart had already changed its ammo sales policy on September 3, 2019, a month after a gunman killed 22 people at one of its stores in El Paso, Texas.

What did you fact-check?: Hair Weaves And Lace Front Wigs Made In China Likely To Contain coronavirus.
Explanation: There is very little chance of coronavirus spreading this way, and there have not been any reported cases of this happening.

What did you fact-check?: That a spray could protect against the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The product being hawked by the Genesis Church 2 is essentially bleach.

What did you fact-check?: That a tabletop exercise using a model of the current outbreak "predicted" 65 million people could die from the coronavirus.
Explanation: There was no prediction made at the tabletop exercise. It was held in October of 2019 and used a different model of the coronavirus, and no predicted death toll was estimated by the groups.

What did you fact-check?: That explosion occured in Wuhan, China, tied to the coronavirus outbreak.
Who said/posted it?: Ricky DJ Moore II on YouTube
Explanation: It was a video supposedly of an explosion in Wuhan, China. A search showed it was actually footage of the first of several explosions in Tianjin, China, from 2015.

What did you fact-check?: KNUST students discover vaccine for coronavirus and cure patient in Cote d'Ivoire.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Romania developed a coronavirus vaccine able to cure white people only.
Explanation: There is no known cure for the coronavirus. This is a hoax.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus was called a "plague" by the WHO, and that 2.9 million were infected while 950,680 people had died
Explanation: A global emergency was declared by WHO. To date, 213 people had died as a result of the coronavirus and another 9,800 cases had been confirmed in mainland China, according to reports, while cases had been discovered in more than a dozen countries worldwide.

What did you fact-check?: Scientists claim Wuhan coronavirus is HIV-1 engineered "super weapon".
Explanation: The scientific research cited was not peer-reviewed, and the paper was withdrawn by the researchers to revise their results.There was also a note saying it was only a preliminary study.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates helped fund patent for coronavirus.
Explanation: The Pirbright Institute addressed the conspiracy theories and said the patents involve infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) only, and the Gates Foundation did not fund that work.

What did you fact-check?: Scientists from Australia create the first vaccine for novel coronavirus
Explanation: This website was a scam. There is no known, widely available or public vaccine for the coronavirus. The website that was taking orders was shut down.

What did you fact-check?: Video from China show people fleeing from coronavirus quarantine
Explanation: The video footage is originally from an anti-government protest that was posted in December 2019, well before the coronavirus quarantine began.

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin C stops or slows novel coronavirus.
Who said/posted it?: Health Impact News, Orthomolecular Medicine News Service
Explanation: There is, to date, no known cure for coronavirus. Medical professionals and researchers also said there was no conclusive evidence to suggest Vitamin C can treat or prevent coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: China seeks court approval to kill over 20,000 coronavirus patients to stop the spread of the outbreak.
Explanation: This unsubstantiated claim came from a website that published frequently false claims. There is no evidence that China went to courts looking for such approval. Claim was also debunked by several other outlets.

What did you fact-check?: Autopsy reveal Wuhan doctor was murdered in his sickbed.
Explanation: The story fabricates a quote and did not offer on-the-record source for its claim. It also came from a website that frequently publishes false information. Other news outlets confirmed Li Wenliang died from the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus cases reported in Rome, Georgia
Explanation: The medical facility issued a statement saying there was not a confirmed case.

What did you fact-check?: Residential building was set on fire in Wuhan to control spread of coronavirus.
Explanation: A fire broke out in a different city in China, but officials said the fire had no connection to the coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: High-rise buildings have become human incinerators to combat spread of coronavirus
Explanation: There was no concrete evidence to prove that buildings were being burned to stop coronavirus. The Twitter authority cited in the story was not credible.

What did you fact-check?: Latest research by Chinese scientists said coronavirus will render most male patients infertile.
Explanation: The study has not been peer-reviewed. But the study also does not go as far as to say coronavirus will definitely cause infertility in men.

What did you fact-check?: Data shows massive release of sulfur dioxide gas near Wuhan.
Explanation: The images in the Twitter posts are not satellite measurements, and a member of NASA said the images did not show significantly increased SO2 measurements. Some other websites cited the images as evidence -- though false -- of bodies being burned due to coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Popping bubble wrap does not exposes people to coronavirus.
Explanation: Bubble wrap is not produced by people blowing air into the plastic. Claim originated from a satirical Facebook page that was shut down.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is a biological warfare weapon.
Explanation: Dr. Francis Boyle did say that coronvirus is a biological warfare weapon, but the story lacks context. There is no supporting evidence to back up that suggestion. It was debunked as a rumor and untrue that coronavirus was made in a lab.

What did you fact-check?: 20 million Chinese convert to Islam, and coronavirus does not affect Muslims.
Explanation: The video doesn't feature Chinese people, but rather Filipino men. Video footage predates major coronavirus reports.

What did you fact-check?: Six coronavirus cases confirmed in Wichita, Kansas.
Explanation: No cases were confirmed there, and claim came from non-credible websites.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is bioweapon leaked from Wuhan lab.
Explanation: Already disproved similar claims. Scientists in Wuhan insisted no link between virus and labs.

What did you fact-check?: Cocaine kills coronavirus.
Explanation: Fake story was generated by a website that allows people to create their own news stories. Previously busted claim.

What did you fact-check?: Florida Man Arrested For Robbery Using Cough As A Weapon.
Explanation: Image was created using prank generator site.

What did you fact-check?: CDC Recommends Men Shave Their Beards To Protect Against coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is based on a Centers for Disease Control chart created in 2017 to advise medical workers on the best practices for wearing "filtering facepiece respirators" during contact with viral patients. It was not intended for the general public - nor specifically for preventing the spread of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Doctors Recommend Carbon Filter Face Masks To Prevent coronavirus Spread.
Explanation: Videos falsely claims that doctors are recommending carbon filter masks as a way to protect families, although the FDA and CDC both concluded that they are not effective for children and are not recommended for home use. The videos are used to sell the masks to people concerned about the coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Pope Francis And Two Aides Tested Positive for coronavirus.
Explanation: No official Vatican communication confirms this.

What did you fact-check?: Journalist Claims A coronavirus Patient Was Murdered.
Explanation: The tweet did go out from a TV reporter, but it was doctored to claim that a murder investigation was underway at the nursing home.

What did you fact-check?: A Bovine Vaccine Can Be Used To Inoculate People Against coronavirus.
Explanation: There is still currently no approved and public vaccine.

What did you fact-check?: Patents Mean Deadly Diseases And Viruses Were Created Or Invented In A Lab.
Explanation: Instead, the patents are for possible treatments or vaccines, some of which were tested but did not work.

What did you fact-check?: Officials Say coronavirus Killed 200 In Iran.
Explanation: The number of deaths in official reports on March 3, 2020, were much lower than stated in this article.

What did you fact-check?: Donating Plasma Or Blood Is Free Testing For The coronavirus.
Explanation: Currently the test for coronavirus is free.

What did you fact-check?: Novel coronavirus has 99.7 survival rate.
Explanation: The CDC did not confirm this, and the user did not offer any citations for clarification of this fact.

What did you fact-check?: VP Pence Urged People With coronavirus To Go To The Police.
Explanation: This is a fake Tweet by Pence. He never said this.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus Test Does Costs $3,200.
Explanation: Patients will not incur costs when tested by the CDC.

What did you fact-check?: Mayor Of Buffalo Told People To Evacuate Due To coronavirus Outbreak
Explanation: The mayor denied this claim when he responded to a Facebook post spreading the misinformation.

What did you fact-check?: CDC Published Sponsored Facebook Post Asking For Help With "Escaped" coronavirus Patient
Explanation: The post was created by a fake CDC account.

What did you fact-check?: As Of March 7, 2020, Tanzania And Zambia Had Confirmed First Cases Of coronavirus.
Explanation: At the time, the MP said there were no reported cases in Tanzania. WHO also didn't confirm cases at the time in either country.

What did you fact-check?: Freshly Boiled Garlic Water Is A Cure For coronavirus.
Explanation: There is still no cure.

What did you fact-check?: Department Of Homeland Security Officials Says Illegal Border Crossings May Spread coronavirus.
Explanation: No officials were quoted to confirm this. Headline is mainly the false part.

What did you fact-check?: A NYC Man With Suspected coronavirus Drops Dead In The Middle Of The Street.
Explanation: Of the cases in NY at the time, there were no confirmed deaths.

What did you fact-check?: Every U.S. election year has disease outbreak with it.
Explanation: WHO data doesn't match the dates in the post, and many diseases originate outside the U.S.

What did you fact-check?: 10,000 Deaths In Virus Outbreak in Michigan, Washington, Idaho, North Dakota, Missouri, Mississippi.
Explanation: The CDC counted 25 deaths and 647 confirmed coronavirus cases in the United States as of March 10, 2020.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus found in toilet paper.
Explanation: This was created by a prank generator, and the CDC did not include this as a way in which coronavirus spreads.

What did you fact-check?: Gargling salt water and vinegar will kill the virus.
Explanation: Pulmonologist debunked the memes, and CDC offers real advice about how to say safe.

What did you fact-check?: U.S. presidential election canceled due to coronavirus.
Explanation: The federal government has made no such announcement about canceling the U.S. presidential election.

What did you fact-check?: Australian Hospital Staff Rolled In A Wilson Volleyball To Keep Tom Hanks Company In Quarantine.
Explanation: This came from a satire website, and the photo in the story is old and unrelated to Tom Hank's illness.

What did you fact-check?: A former and controversial CIA officer said coronavirus was made in a lab.
Explanation: The quote was pulled out of context and was mere speculation, not fact.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus scare began after impeachment.
Explanation: the outbreak began in China in late 2019, and it led to the World Health Organization to declare a global health emergency on January 30, 2020, before the final impeachment vote.

What did you fact-check?: Supermarkets are recalling coronavirus-infected toilet paper.
Explanation: The CDC said that coronavirus is spread through respiratory droplets. No reports yet of toilet paper recalls.

What did you fact-check?: Man did pass along coronavirus infection at a WalMart in Louisiana.
Explanation: The man in the photo who posted it admitted it was a joke.

What did you fact-check?: NYC did implement citywide quarantine.
Explanation: NY Mayor Bill de Blasio tweeted it was a false alarm.

What did you fact-check?: Curfew Issued For Bossier City Due To coronavirus.
Explanation: The article itself says it's a joke and a prank.

What did you fact-check?: CEO Resignations Are Linked To Global Conspiracy.
Explanation: Some CEOs have stepped down since coronavirus outbreak, but there's not evidence to suggest it's all linked to a global power issue.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus found in crab legs.
Explanation: Image did not actually come out of real broadcast with typos, and came from an app that let people make their own stories.

What did you fact-check?: Military on streets of Philadelphia preparing to invoke martial law and bring citizens to FEMA camps.
Explanation: Lt. Col. Keith Hickox, the state public affairs officer said the information was false.

What did you fact-check?: Article overstates threat of coronavirus.
Explanation: The claims in the article are backed by science.

What did you fact-check?: Dallas student celebrating spring break collapses from coronavirus.
Explanation: Came from fake news generator website.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is the least deadly virus.
Explanation: The chart, published by Business Insider, issued a correction on the chart exaggerating its figures. But the false info still spreads.

What did you fact-check?: Cristiano Ronaldo turning his hotels into hospitals to fight coronovirus.
Explanation: Ronaldo's management company denied the claim.

What did you fact-check?: WalMart reducing hours of operation.
Explanation: WalMart website confirms

What did you fact-check?: Tanker train marked with 'COVID-9' on its side.
Explanation: Photo was digitally manipulated

What did you fact-check?: CDC warning people that morel mushroom increases coronavirus risk by 200%.
Explanation: User who published made clear this was a hoax.

What did you fact-check?: A dog vaccine can be used against coronavirus in people.
Explanation: There is still no approved vaccine for coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: 15 minutes in a sauna will kill the coronavirus.
Explanation: Infectious disease epidemiologist debunked this

What did you fact-check?: Eating bananas prevents coronavirus.
Explanation: The video splices together clips to make incorrect and misleading information.

What did you fact-check?: Italy has mandated no treatment of all elderly patients for coronavirus.
Explanation: The guidelines to ration care to those with higher survivability are only suggestions at this point.

What did you fact-check?: All U.S. Citizens Are Entitled To $700 Per Week To Stay At Home To Avoid Spread Of coronavirus
Explanation: U.S. citizens may get some economic relief from Congress at some point, but that could still be a few weeks away.

What did you fact-check?: List comparing diseases with coronavirus.
Explanation: The comparison of the outbreaks is extremely misleading as it doesn't take into account the rate of infections, timeframes of the outbreaks and the rapid rise in the number of COVID-19 cases.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 is A Scripted Narrative To Justify Closed Borders Or Force Residents To Remain Home
Explanation: Debunked as a conspiracy theory.

What did you fact-check?: Trump Is Promising To Send Americans Checks - Only After Checking People's Social Media History.
Explanation: This is a false tweet, though there have been real suggestions to have a stimulus package.

What did you fact-check?: Tom Hanks was arrested, with others, for pedophilia.
Explanation: Claim was called out by several outlets as a conspiracy theory, though Hanks and his wife did test positive for coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: 5G Technology Believed To Have Caused coronavirus
Explanation: The claim is false, not backed by scientific research, and many dates given to back up the theory are wrong or misleading.

What did you fact-check?: A tent will be set up next to the Viamed de Calahorra hospital (La Rioja) to carry out rapid tests for coronavirus.
Explanation: No, a tent will not be enabled next to the Calahorra hospital for rapid coronavirus tests.

What did you fact-check?: The government of Spain is going to declare a state of emergency.
Explanation: There is no proof that Spain would enter a state of emergency starting March 23, when the viral audio was spread.

What did you fact-check?: False offer of free Internet during 60 days due to the quarantine.
Explanation: Please read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Gang in Madrid pretending to be doctors to steal in people's houses.
Explanation: Neither the National Police nor the local police have any complaint about this issue in Madrid.

What did you fact-check?: Thieves in Palma (Spain) pretending to be doctors to steal in people's houses.
Explanation: National and Local Police explained that there is no complaint that describes a similar case.

What did you fact-check?: Gang in Vitoria pretending to be doctors to steal in people's houses.
Explanation: Local and regional Police said they have no complaints about assaults like that.

What did you fact-check?: Viral audio from WhatsApp in which a doctor from hospital Fundación Jiménez Díaz in Madrid claims that there are two young patinents in very bad condition because of coronavirus and there are no more respirators in intensive care units.
Explanation: In an internal cocument, the head of intensive care unit explains that the young patients have not patologies related to coronavirus. He also says that there are respiratories for all patients.

What did you fact-check?: The head of Coordinated Emergences, Fernando Simon, has said that is better to get coronavirus now, because later it will be no space in hospitals.
Explanation: Simon didn't said that, it's is a satirical content shared as real.

What did you fact-check?: A case of novel coronavirus in Huelva (Spain).
Explanation: It hasn't been any case of novel coronavirus in Huelva (Spain) at 3rd of February.

What did you fact-check?: Farts recorded by infrared temperature sensors recently installed in airports and train stations to monitor temperatures of passengers amid coronavirus outbreak can screen them all.
Explanation: The farts were added digitally.

What did you fact-check?: China orders citizens to abandon/kill their pets as they can transmit coronavirus.
Explanation: Several state outlets have asked citizens not to abandon their pets. We also didn't find any local authorities ordering the killing of pets.

What did you fact-check?: Bats that hide under Wuhan rooftops caused the COVID-19 outbreak.
Explanation: The video was filmed in Miami in 2011.

What did you fact-check?: Letters and packages sent from China can be a way of infection.
Explanation: Viruses can live for some time in objects like door knobs. WHO has declares COVID19 can't live very long in envelopes and boxes.

What did you fact-check?: Summer temperatures will make coronavirus disappear.
Explanation: We don't know enough yet about the coronavirus to know if this will happen.

What did you fact-check?: Malaga closes nurseries due to coronavirus.
Explanation: It's a manipulated screenshot of a 'El Mundo' article.

What did you fact-check?: A case of coronavirus in Andorra.
Explanation: There is no case of coronavirus in Andorras (as of 10 of February).

What did you fact-check?: Face masks are a good protection system against coronavirus.
Explanation: Masks are not a good way of protection unless your are a health professional or your are in contact with somebody infected.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a woman eating bat soup and its relation with the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: There is yet no confirmation regarding the exact cause of the outbreak. Also, the video was filmed in Palau in 2016, so there is no relation with the current Coronavirus in China.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a plate of bat soup that allegedly started the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: There is yet no confirmation regarding the exact cause of the outbreak, although some scientists agree that bats can be (and have been in other ocasions) carriers of Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Video in which a doctor faints whilst operating after being infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Video of a road traffic control in China to detect people infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was filmed in China, but it's a simulation, not a real incident.

What did you fact-check?: WhatsApp chain sent by a doctor at Vall d'Hebron Hospital (Barcelona) about coronavirus
Explanation: That doctor didn't write chain. The chain also makes some inaccurate claims.

What did you fact-check?: Elderly COVID-19 patients won't have access to respirators
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: A 1981 book predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The book does talk about a virus called Wuhan-400, but it's not the same as Covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: Chain message that says that Bill Gates patented the coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: This video is taken in Wuhan (China) in the place of the outbreak of the coronavirus.
Explanation: This is not a video from Wuhan (China), is a video from Indonesia recorded in July 2019.

What did you fact-check?: The WHO has recomended to avoid unprotected sex with live wil or farm animals
Explanation: It is a manipulated image of a real advice image from the WHO.

What did you fact-check?: Emergency nofication issued by Health Ministry about coronavirus and recommendations
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: "Five foods that help you not to get the coronavirus"
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus has killed over 10.000 people
Explanation: The latest report from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control says there are currently 170 people who died.

What did you fact-check?: The biological research laboratory Ruilan Bao Hu San Biotech Limited in Shanghai, the city where #coronarvirus originated, has a logo like that of the Umbrella Corporation of RESIDENT EVIL and corona is an anagram for Racoon. WTF
Explanation: There are no proves of the relation between the Chinesse company RLSW and coronavirus, neigther that Shanghai is the place where it all started. Moreover the anagram of the word "corona" is not the same as Raccoon, the name of the city where takes place the videogame Resident Evil.

What did you fact-check?: The Lysol and coronavirus conspiracy: "2019-nCoV is old and there is already a cure to it"
Explanation: Although human Coronavirus was first discoverd in the 60s, the current 2019-nCoV outbreak was first identified recently.

What did you fact-check?: Over 1.500 people have died because of coronavirus
Explanation: As of January 31, the Coronavirus death toll is 213.

What did you fact-check?: A neighbour of Noia (region of Galicia, Spain) has been infected with coronavirus
Explanation: The picture has been doctored. La Voz de Galicia hasn't published that article and ther has been no new case of Coronavirus in Spain.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is not new as there is a vaccine for dogs that prevents it
Explanation: Coronavirus is not new, but the current outbreak was caused by a type that was recently discovered.

What did you fact-check?: Rinsing your mouth with salted water will prevent coronavirus infection.
Explanation: The doctor's team has debunked the chain.

What did you fact-check?: First case of coronavirus in San Vicente del Raspeig (Alicante, Spain).
Explanation: The article was not published by El País and there has been no case detected in Alicante.

What did you fact-check?: Spain's Health Secretary recommends not selling products from China.
Explanation: The Health Secretary has denied making such recommendations.

What did you fact-check?: The Simpsons predicted the coronavirus.
Explanation: The episode of The Simpsons talked about a flu from Japan, no China. Moreover, one of the photos shared was manipulated.

What did you fact-check?: A child from China has coronavirus in Galicia (Spain)
Explanation: There are no children infected with coronavirus in Spain at this date.

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin C and Omega prevents coronavirus.
Explanation: There isn't any food that can prevent coronavirus infection.

What did you fact-check?: The Chinese news website Tencent filters that there are more than 24,000 deaths from coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: This photo is a "chinese tapa"¨from a bat.
Explanation: False: The picture is not of a Chinese dish, but of a soup from Guam island (United States)

What did you fact-check?: Consuming magnesium chloride, sodium bicarbonate, ginger and lemon juice prevents coronavirus infection.
Explanation: No health organization has recommended eating any of these products to prevent Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Pigs are burried alive due to coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is not recent and has nothing to do with Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A monkey is been infected with coronavirus in this photo.
Explanation: The photo is a capture of a video taken at least two months before the first symtoms of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: The new coronavirus was registered in 2004.
Explanation: It was another type of Coronavirus that was registered in 2004, not the one that caused the current outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Lectures have been suspended at the University of Sevilla due to coronavirus.
Explanation: The University has made a statement saying that the document that has been shared is false.

What did you fact-check?: A new case of coronavirus in Sacedón (Guadalajara, Mexico).
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: An article of El Pais says there is a possible case of coronavirus at the hospital Gregorio Marañón, in Spain.
Explanation: El País hasn't published that article and the typography doesnt't match.

What did you fact-check?: An aritcle of El Pais says ther is a case of coronavirus at the School of Architects of Madrid.
Explanation: El País hasn't published that article.

What did you fact-check?: First case of coronavirus in Alcalá de Henares (Madrid).
Explanation: One screenshot shows a false article done with an app that lets you create these fake contents and the other one shows an article that HAS NOT been published by El Mundo newspaper.

What did you fact-check?: A brothel with 86 customers put in quarantine after a prostitute tested positive in coronavirus.
Explanation: It was a "satirical" content.

What did you fact-check?: "Spanish newspaper ABC reports that there are two possible COVID-19 cases in Gines and Benecazón (Seville, Spain).
Explanation: ABC has not published that article

What did you fact-check?: A man with a gas mask at a supermarket in Lugo (Galicia, Spain).
Explanation: The picture was taken in Austria, not Spain.

What did you fact-check?: School has been suspended in Catalonia until March 2.
Explanation: It's not a real statement by the Catalonian education department.

What did you fact-check?: The wife of a Chinese shop owner of Totana (Murcia, Spain) has coronavirus.
Explanation: It was not the case.

What did you fact-check?: Autorities should implement temperature tests to travelers from China.
Explanation: There is no evidence those tests are precise enough to detect inffectes peoble that have no fever

What did you fact-check?: Garlic water can treat coronavirus.
Explanation: WHO says there is no evidence.

What did you fact-check?: Pangolin is the original cause of the COVID-19.
Explanation: The scientists that first pointed to pangolin as the original cause of the infection have since then rectified.

What did you fact-check?: An alkaline diet can prevent getting infected.
Explanation: No food or diet, neither alkaline or otherwise, can prevent the infection

What did you fact-check?: Ministry of Health (Spain) sends WhatsApp chain with advices against coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: It's not a real alert by the Ministery of Health.

What did you fact-check?: 3.000 people from Elche (Spain) infected by coronavirus after coming back from Milan's international footwear industry fair.
Explanation: There currently aren't any Coronavirus cases in Elche and the Ministery of Health has not released any statement claiming so.

What did you fact-check?: You can't get infected by kissing the hands of a virgin or saint statue.
Explanation: Kissing the hands of a virgin or saint statue is a tradition of the Holy Week in some parts of Spain, but it is not free for viruses and therefor can be a way of inffection.

What did you fact-check?: New coronavirus was registered in 2018.
Explanation: It was another type of Coronavirus that doesn't affect to humans. This one was registered in 2018.

What did you fact-check?: Claims of cannibalism in China. People are cutting a baby in order to eat it.
Explanation: This actually shows an autopsy on a baby.

What did you fact-check?: A patent that is being shared to claim COVID-19 is old.
Explanation: The patent is related to SARS, not COVID-19

What did you fact-check?: No work in several regions of Spain due to coronavirus.
Explanation: It's a joke. When you click on the link it takes you to a picture of a monkey.

What did you fact-check?: A WhatsApp message suggests holding the breath during 10 seconds and drink water every 15 minutes are effective methods fighting coronavirus.
Explanation: There are no medical and scientifical evidences of this.

What did you fact-check?: Medical Center in El Cachorro (Sevilla) closed due to possible coronavirus infected person.
Explanation: Medical center in El Cachorro (Sevilla) wasn't closed due to possible coronavirus infected person. Emergencies official channel of Sevilla denies it.

What did you fact-check?: Medical report of Hospital General Universitario Santa Lucía de Cartagena (Murcia) ifrom a person with possible coronavirus.
Explanation: The medical report is not actual, ist from the past, and another kind of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: It is a designed virus ordered to laboratories by Christine Lagarde when she was in the IMF, and she said that "Old people live too long and this is a risk for the global economy. We must do something, urgently".
Explanation: There is no proof that the quote atrtibutted to Lagarde was said by her. It probably comes from a part of an IMF inform.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus was caused by a mysterious vaccine activation distributed in China by chemtrails and activated by 5G.
Explanation: It is a combination of old conspiracy theories very popular on the internet.

What did you fact-check?: Madrid's government has announced students will have to make-up classes during summer.
Explanation: Madrid's government hasn't announced the students will have to make-up classes during summer: the shared photo is fake.

What did you fact-check?: EvAU's exam is going to be postponed to June 18th in Madrid.
Explanation: Madrid's government hasn't announced Evau's exams are going to be postpone: the viral imaged is a set up.

What did you fact-check?: Spanish actress Cristina Pedroche has promised to show a boob if the number of coronavirus infections gets to 1 thousand in Spain.
Explanation: It is false, the quote comes from a satirical website.

What did you fact-check?: Public broadcast RTVE published a map of coronavirus cases in Spain that in fact was a map of penis' average size in different regions.
Explanation: There is no evidence that RTVE published a map of coronavirus cases in Spain that in fact was a map of penis' average measure in different regions. The map was a map from El País about unemployment rate.

What did you fact-check?: Classes were cancelled in all Basque Country because of coronavirus.
Explanation: Classes were not cancelled in all Basque Country (at 10/03/20), just in to places: Vitoria and Labastida. It is a manipulated image using a media name.

What did you fact-check?: Regional government of Castilla-La Mancha announced in Twitter the closing of schools until April 1.
Explanation: Regional government didn't announced that, it was a manipulated image.

What did you fact-check?: Spanish Education minister, Isabel Celaá, wore purple latex gloves on Women's Day demonstration because she was afraid of coronavirus.
Explanation: It is something that other women an politicians did years before, when there was no coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Madrid ex-mayor Manuel Carmena has coronavirus.
Explanation: Reported by a fake Twitter account pretending to be spanish newspaper El País.

What did you fact-check?: Neuroscientist Rodolfo Llinás says that if you can last 10 seconds without coughing and without discomfort it means that there is no fibrosis in the lungs and therefore no coronavirus infection.
Explanation: Rodolfo Llinás claims that he has not said that and there is no evidence that these recommendations are effective.

What did you fact-check?: Audio from WhatsApp in which the head of Cardiology at the Gregorio Marañón Hospital states that we are in a moment of uncontrolled coronavirus infection.
Explanation: The public health authorities of the Community of Madrid have classified the audio that supposedly belongs to the head of Cardiology at the Gregorio Marañón Hospital as false.

What did you fact-check?: Zamora has cancelled Holy week due to coronavirus.
Explanation: It's a false article created on 12minutos, a site that lets you create "satirical" articles.

What did you fact-check?: Spanish Ministry of Interior is closing-off Madrid.
Explanation: The ministry of Interior has denied releasing that statement.

What did you fact-check?: Catalonia, Valencia and Aragon cancel classes in schools, colleges and universities because of coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The article was not published by El País.

What did you fact-check?: Tuit reports that Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro has tested positive for the coronavirus.
Explanation: Fake Twitter account pretending to be Folha de Sao Paolo.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking hot beverages prevents coronavirus infection.
Explanation: Fluid intake has nothing to do with the infection process.

What did you fact-check?: Spain ex-King Juan Carlos I has the coronavirus.
Explanation: It was tweeted from a fake account pretending to be spanish newspaper El País.

What did you fact-check?: China has announced the sucess of Egyptian serum form Dr. Hala, Ealth Minister of Egypt, against coronavirus.
Explanation: Egyptian Health Ministry denied it.

What did you fact-check?: Audio from WhatsApp that says there are a doctor and two nurses hospitalized on the ICU in Terrassa (Barcelona)
Explanation: The hospitals in Terrassa deny this situation.

What did you fact-check?: Film 'coronavirus' predicted the current pandemic
Explanation: That's not the cover of the movie. The original name of the film in Korean is "Gamgi" (Cold), "Flu" in English, and it is translated into Spanish as "Virus".

What did you fact-check?: Video recorded by a Muslim resident in Spain who accumulates supplies for chronavirus
Explanation: The product brands shown in the video are Dutch.

What did you fact-check?: El País' publishes that Renfe is proposing an ERTE for its employees due to the measures taken by the coronavirus
Explanation: El Pais' has not published the article and Renfe denies that they are considering apply an ERTE.

What did you fact-check?: These remarks were made by Spanish Health official Fernando Simón 9 days ago
Explanation: These remarks were made on January 31, not 9 days ago.

What did you fact-check?: MIlitary planes are going to fumigate the region of Comunidad Valenciana to disinfect from coronavirus
Explanation: Minsitry of Defense said there is not going to be such action.

What did you fact-check?: Speech from spanish King Felipe VI about coronavirus was a plagiarism from book "Palmeras en la nieve" or "Las Palmeras"
Explanation: It is not king's speech about coronavirus, but from years ago about Catalonien. This speech was afterwards included in the book "Las Palmeras". Ther is no plagiarism.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus was spread via bananas
Who said/posted it?: facebookpage “Georgia first of all” & Russian aggregator website Pikabu.ru
Explanation: Coronavirus has transmitted from living organisms - animals - and any evidence, as if bananas or other food products transmit it, has not yet been revealed. Moreover, bananas have been a source of various conspiracies for years, and was considered to be a source of spreading the Ebola, then AIDS and swine flu groundlessly and without any scientific justification. 'Myth Detector's developed banana 'timeline' reflecting the conspiracies that were inspired by a banana and banana-caused viruses at different times.

What did you fact-check?: Spreading coronavirus is the interest of the USA, because American laboratories are operating not only around Russia but in the surroundings of Asian countries and in Georgia (Lugar lab)
Who said/posted it?: Russian TV Channel Ren TV, Igor Nikulin, military expert and former Georgian Minister of Security Igor Giorgadze (comment made in 2018)
Explanation: There are several conspiracy narratives developed in the report, including on US Labs artificially linked to the Coronavirus. In the context of conspiracy narrative, the story author names Tbilisi-based Lugar Laboratory of biological research, making an unreasonable parallel between virus found in China and Tbilisi Laboratory. Moreover, the story features the archive material from 2018, in which former Georgian Minister of Security Igor Giorgadze talks about the threats coming from the Lugar Lab. Lugar Laboratory is a part of the National Center for Disease Control and Public Health of Ministry of Health of Georgia. For years, Lugar Lab has been a target of Kremlin, Russia affiliated media, Russian politicians and high officials.
