Except for US-financed C Hepatitis Treatment program, there are other conspiracies linked to the lab.

What did you fact-check?: A WhatsApp forward has gone viral which claimed that a vaccine for coronavirus has been discovered. The viral forward also claims that the treatment for coronavirus is mentioned in an Intermediate Zoology book.
Explanation: The viral forward reads, “It is not a new disease as it is already mentioned in the Intermediate zoology book along with its treatment. It happens sometimes that many great scientists and doctors do not focus on lesser-known books as they are mostly busy with famous books. Book name: Zoology, Writer: Dr. Ramesh Gupta, Page No. 1072.) Friends, this is not fake news so I request you to kindly share it maximum so all coronavirus patients are treated in time.”The treatments mentioned in the viral page of the book are first of all not a treatment for coronavirus but a treatment for common cold caused by a coronavirus which is negated partially by various research reports so the viral claim that there is pre-existing medication for coronavirus, is ‘Misleading’.

What did you fact-check?: Riots in London due to the unavailability of food items. The United Kingdom will be locked down by tonight. Army soldiers take to the UK streets.
Explanation: This video is of riots that happened in Peckham, London. With the help of Google search, we found several global media reports on the London riots. It was clear from these reports that the video viral on social media is the London riots that happened in 2011.

What did you fact-check?: Russia has unleashed over 500 lions to ensure that people stay inside their homes amid the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The image of a bulletin viral on social media has nothing to do with Russia or Russian President. The image is from South Africa’s Johannesburg, and the lion seen in the viral image was brought for film shooting by a production crew.

What did you fact-check?: People's Daily's official twitter handle shared an old image as newly built hospital building in Wuhan
Explanation: The viral image was taken from an online listing and is actually a modular apartment building.

What did you fact-check?: Confirmed case of coronavirus found in Shaheen Bagh, Delhi.
Explanation: There have been three official cases of coronavirus in India so far. The Twitter handle's claim about the Coronavirus case in Shaheen Bagh is fake and misleading.

What did you fact-check?: Can cow urine cure coronavirus?
Explanation: In our verification, we found several media reports, research reports, and advisories that talk about prevention and cure of the disease but there was no mention of cow urine and dung in these reports hence the claim made by the Hindu Mahasabha president Swami Chakrapani is ‘Misleading’.

What did you fact-check?: Can cannabis cure coronavirus?
Explanation: The image has been created with the help of a website called dopl3r. No government mandate or science research or WHO have commented on cannabis and if it can cure coronavirus or not.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus patients are being caught on highways in China.
Explanation: The video is not about the corona virus patients being caught, but of the training and mock drill given to the Swat team in China.

What did you fact-check?: People of the Muslim community have prohibited visiting Mecca Medina to avoid the outbreak of coronavirus, but people of Sanatan religion are playing Holi at the crematorium of Kashi Vishwanath as a pyre.
Explanation: Mecca Medina of Saudi Arabia was neither closed due to fear of virus. To take some precautions, there was a ban on the arrival of travelers from few countries. On 5 March people were prevented from going inside because of sanitization.

What did you fact-check?: A viral message listing false and unrelated statements about coronavirus has falsely been attributed to the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund (UNICEF).
Explanation: No such advisory has been released by UNICEF. Nor much is known about novel coronavirus as it is a newly found coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking lots of water and gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar eliminates the novel coronavirus. Spread the information as you can save someone with this information.
Explanation: According to GMA news report, saline gargles or gargling with water and salt will provide no protection against or cure for the 2019 novel coronavirus acute respiratory disease (2019-nCoV ARD). The report also carried a statement by the Dr. Eric Domingo “I think this is a home remedy that has been followed for many, many generations and I don’t think there’s going to be any harm in doing it. Saline gargle has always been advocated to improve mostly symptoms of sore throat...I don’t think there is any evidence that it will kill a virus,” Domingo said.

What did you fact-check?: "Ministry of Health ITALY released a small video, HOW the virus spreads!!!... BEST VIDEO. Please see ..how innocently it spread. SOAP is the remedy CLEAN/ WASH ur Hands always"
Explanation: The viral video is not released by the health ministry of Italy in the wake of coronavirus but it is long-existing on YouTube, we reached the conclusion that the viral claim is ‘Misleading’.

What did you fact-check?: The viral video claims to show the visuals of china police personnel trying to control the patients allegedly suffering from the pandemic.
Explanation: The viral video has nothing to do with the coronavirus outbreak and is related to police storming the metro in the wake of Hong Kong protests.

What did you fact-check?: A WhatsApp forward is doing the rounds which claims that Prime Minister Narendra Modi called for a 14-hour long ‘Janta Curfew’ on 22 March from 7 am to 9 pm because the lifespan of the coronavirus at one place is only 12 hours and if we all follow the Janta Curfew religiously then the chain will be broken
Explanation: There is no clear information on the lifespan of the novel coronavirus. However, various study reports have suggested a similar lifespan as that of other coronaviruses. PM Modi’s motive behind calling for a ‘Janta Curfew’ was just to curb the spreading of novel coronavirus and the Government has not claimed that the Janta Curfew is called to kill the virus hence the claim turned out to ‘Misleading’ in our fact-check.

What did you fact-check?: A Parasite Removal Video Shared In Relation With coronavirus
Explanation: The video was uploaded on YouTube on October 24, 2019 with the title “Amazing Botfly Removal on Lips”.

What did you fact-check?: Russia announces the closure of airspace and suspension of all its incoming and outgoing flights to China.
Explanation: Russian government had imposed some temporary and partial ban on the movement of Chinese nationals. All Russian airlines, with the exception of national airline Aeroflot (AFLT.MM), stopped flying to China from Jan. 31. Small airline Ikar will also continue flights between Moscow and China. All planes arriving from China will be sent to a separate terminal in the Moscow Sheremetyevo airport. Aeroflot reduced the frequency of flights to Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou until Feb. 29.

What did you fact-check?: Pigs burried in china, is it because of coronavirus?
Explanation: The claimed video is one year old when pigs were burried in large numbers after the outbreak of african swine flu.

What did you fact-check?: Can garlic soup cure coronavirus?
Explanation: The claim is false as according to the WHO no treatment has yet been found for coronavirus. The search is still on.

What did you fact-check?:
More than 35 million people in China are now on a travel lockdown. More than 2700 have been sickened, and 81 have died.
Nothing happens without Allah's permission and He is aware of all things.
Explanation: The shared image is not from China. This image was taken on 14 March 2014 in Frankfurt, Germany, where people lay down in a pedestrian zone as part of an art project in remembrance of the 528 victims of the Katzbach Nazi concentration camp.

What did you fact-check?: Can dettol kill coronavirus?
Explanation: The company said that coronavirus cannot be eliminated by using its liquid soap. Also, the company said that we do not know about this virus and no testing has been done at the moment.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus found in Broiler Chicken
Explanation: The pictures are outdated and have nothing to do with the coronavirus. Pictures that went viral on social media are about sick chickens.

What did you fact-check?:
1. Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang visited a mosque and seek protection to the country from coronavirus. 
2. Chinese president Xi Jinping visited a mosque in China after realizing the fact that only Allah can save China from this epidemic.
Explanation: The first video is of former malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi who visited a mosque in China during his visit in 2015. The second video is aslo an old one, President Xi Jinping paid a visit to the Xincheng Mosque in Yinchuan city, capital of NW China's Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region on Tuesday, July 19, 2016.

What did you fact-check?: "THE CHINESE HAVE BEGUN TO USE THEIR HUMAN CORPES TO PROCESS INTO PRODUCTS SUCH AS CORNED BEEF TO SHIP TO AFRICA. Please share with your contacts..Very important"
Explanation: The video might be of Tibet or China’s Sichuan as residents of both these territories perform such rituals. However, we haven’t found the origin of this claim hence we can not emphasize whether or not visuals in this video belong to Sky Burial. But from our findings it is evident that the video is in no way related to the coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: China is seeking court’s approval to kill 20000 people positive with coronavirus
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: "Arsenic album-30 homeopathic medicine can prevent coronavirus. Information given by Ministry of AYUSH."
Explanation: According to WHO, there is no evidence that any medicine can stop or cure the virus. The World Health Organization does not recommend any medication, including antibiotics, as a prevention or treatment of COVID-19. Meanwhile, the AYUSH Minister AYUSH Minister Mr. Padnaik also said that they never claimed that arsenic album 30 can cure corona virus.

What did you fact-check?: Israel has manufactured the coronavirus (COVID-19) vaccine
Explanation: According to Isreal, work at The Biological Institute is going on and it may take time. 50 of the most senior researchers and scientists are working hard to prepare a vaccine. The Image which is being circulated along with the claim is a reference image, available on shutterstock.

What did you fact-check?: Eating salt on the onion will eliminate the coronavirus.
Explanation: According to the World Health Organization , eating onions increases the immune system . But it has nothing to do with the treatment of coronovirus. In the investigation we found that no cure for this virus has yet been discovered.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus can be cured by sniffing clove and camphor and by drinking water, the virus will go to the stomach and the acid in the stomach will kill the virus.
Explanation: Dr. Mohammad Imran, an Ayurveda doctor, said, “It is merely a rumor which has gone viral on social media .There is no scientific evidence which backs the claim that sniffing clove and camphor can cure coronavirus. However, natural camphor and clove does have certain health benefits as it can cure fungus and bacteria”.

What did you fact-check?: As coronavirus outbreak surges, PM Narendra Modi has decided to facilitate fellow countrymen with free masks under the ‘Swacch Bharat’ scheme.
Explanation: The government has not announced any such scheme under which it is aimed to provide free masks. The viral webpage may be a part of the decade-old phishing technique or it may be an attempt to collect the data. However, the intent behind creating this webpage is not yet clear but it is crystal clear that the webpage doesn’t belong to Indian govt and might be a venture of some fraudulent organization.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese intelligence officer terms the Novel coronavirus as a biological weapon invented by China.
Explanation: The viral post also claims that the damage caused by the pandemic is being normalized by the Chinese officials. The website which has published the alleged testimony of the said Chinese intelligence officer has published the report with the headline, “CORONA UNMASKED: Chinese Intelligence Officer Reveals True Magnitude of China’s Fake “Coronavirus” Crisis – 包含中文字符版本”. The story published by the Reddit community No Sleep is just a horror story and does not have anything to do with reality. the community itself terms it as a storytelling platform and not a true story publisher.

What did you fact-check?: Football player Cristiano Ronaldo turned all his hotels into hospitals to help coronavirus patients and is paying doctors and the staff.
Explanation: A spokesperson for the hotel denied the claim stating "We are a hotel. We are not going to be a hospital. It is a day like everyone else, we are and will remain a hotel." The news was also denied by HRT, Gol, Haber, Pogled, Flash and Hayat, while the Sport and Magazine plus portals deleted their articles.

What did you fact-check?: Andhra Pradesh Chief Minister YS Jagan Reddy has claimed that ‘Paracetamol’ is the only medication for coronavirus.
Explanation: It is evident from our findings and Dr. Pandey’s testimony that Paracetamol can help with the coronavirus symptoms but it cannot entirely cure coronavirus. We also found that Paracetamol is not the only medication that can help with coronavirus symptoms as there are many medications.

What did you fact-check?: The United States of America threatened Iraq with coronavirus in 1990.
Explanation: According to the AP Archive description, Saddam Hussein said, “If God wills it and we have to run after the enemy, then we will do it.” Also, in AP’s description, we found that Saddam Hussein did not refer to the word ‘Coronavirus’ in the original video.

What did you fact-check?: Seeing the rise of novel coronavirus in India, the World Health Organization (WHO) has recommended the government of India to lockdown the country from April 15 to June 15.
Explanation: We reached out to one of the representatives in India, who rubbished the claim and clarified that WHO has not made any such recommendation.

What did you fact-check?: A video is doing the rounds in already flooded WhatsApp groups. It is being claimed that the lady shown in the video is the wife of Canada’s PM Justin Trudeau. In the viral video, a lady can be seen describing her improved condition because of medication and also warns to not take chances.
Explanation: The lady in the viral video is not Canadian PM Justin Trudeau’s wife Sophie Grégoire Trudeau but a British national namely Tara Jane Langston.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese converting to Islam after realising that no muslim was affected by #coronavirus #COVD19 in the country.
Explanation: The viral video is old and not related to coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A video has gone viral on social media which claims to feature one of the victims of the deadly virus.
Explanation: The same video was posted YouTube on October 24th, 2019, which was before the first case of Coronavirus got reported in China in December 2019.

What did you fact-check?: A video of a girl is being shared on social media where she collapsed in a store and claims are being made that she was affected by coronavirus.
Explanation: Incident is from Malaysia and the girl has been identified as Nur Izzah Izzati. Malaysia’s Health Ministry also confirmed that the claim attached with the video is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a market in the Chinese city of Wuhan, where the deadly coronavirus strain emerged.
Explanation: The video actually shows a market in Indonesia’s Sulawesi island.

What did you fact-check?: Picture of people lying on the street is being shared online with a caption that implies that the picture is related to the recent outbreak of coronavirus in China.
Explanation: The picture was taken in Frankfurt when people participated in an art protest to pay tribute to the lives lost in the Nazi concentration camps in 2014.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows bat infestation under a tiled roof claims to be the source of coronavirus in China's Hubei.
Explanation: The viral video is eight-year-old and it is not from China.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese PM visited mosque following coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The man in the viral video is former Malaysian Prime Minister, Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. The video was shot during his visit to China when he visited Beijing’s Nan Xia Po Mosque in July 2015.

What did you fact-check?: China is seeking court’s approval to kill all who were tested positive with coronavirus.
Explanation: The official website of the National Health Commission of the People’s Republic of China uploaded the daily brief on coronavirus and there was no mention of any such case there

What did you fact-check?: A picture of a Dettol disinfectant spray is being shared online in which the label on the back of a bottle shows the product claiming to have been proven to ‘kill coronavirus’ and that they knew about the new strain since 2019.
Explanation: The recent outbreak of coronavirus in China is a strain named 2019-nCoV. For this particular strain, the source of infection, animal host and reservoir are currently unknown.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese President Xi Jinping visited mosque amid coronavirus outbreak and requested the people of the Muslim community to pray ‘in present crisis
Explanation: Chinese President Xi Jinping’s visit to the mosque is not related to Coronavirus as the viral video is almost-four-year-old.

What did you fact-check?: Left-wing Spanish politicians Irene Montero and Pablo Iglesias have private sanitarian services waiting in front of their homes.
Explanation: Madrid's Health Department, the emergency medical service and PODEMOS say it is false.

What did you fact-check?: Police has not issued any "domiciliation order" in Madrid to stay at home under a fine of 1000€.
Explanation: The National Police has denied on its Twitter account this document that forces the citizens of Madrid to remain at home from 9 p.m. to 9 a.m

What did you fact-check?: EFE news agency published that a tweet announcing that the Government will impose fines of 300,000 euros on people who travel to other regions.
Explanation: EFE news agency denies it published that tuit. Also, Newtral could not find any proof that the agency published the tweet.

What did you fact-check?: "A looting" in a supermarket due to the coronavirus.
Explanation: The images were recorded three years ago in an establishment of the supermarket chain HiperDino.

What did you fact-check?: Irene Montero is caughing on someone during the 8M women protest.
Explanation: The subtitles are manipulated. irene Montero and the concerned person deny the false claim.

What did you fact-check?: Egypt Health Minister has given to China the vaccine against coronavirus.
Explanation: World Health Organization (WHO) states that to date, there is no vaccine or drug to prevent or treat Covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: Insurance companies in Spain cease to cover traffic accidents due to coronavirus.
Explanation: The Insurance Business Association UNESPA, which includes 200 companies in the sector, has debunked the hoax.

What did you fact-check?: Madrid has enabled the phone number 915038030 to request prescriptions.
Explanation: The region of Madrid says it is a hoax.

What did you fact-check?: Niño Jesús hospital is now "clean" of coronavirus to take care of children and young people in Madrid.
Explanation: The Hospital and the health ministry explain it is false.

What did you fact-check?: Here are the measures that Mercadona will implement due to the coronavirus crisis.
Explanation: Mercadona's Communication department explains that nearly all the points of the message are false.

What did you fact-check?: Police has "free entry in houses and buildings" in Malaga to identify possible coronavirus infections.
Explanation: Malaga and Police authorities debunk the hoax on their official twitter accounts.

What did you fact-check?: Javier Orthega Smith, from VOX, said that he prefers to have coronavirus than have "homosexualism".
Explanation: The claim is from a satire website.

What did you fact-check?: France will pay rent, light and gas during quarantine for its citizens.
Explanation: France is only paying for small company's that are not earning enough.

What did you fact-check?: Helicopters and military aircraft spraying and disinfecting the streets at 11 p.m.
Explanation: Air Force and Ministry of Defense sources deny it.

What did you fact-check?: France has suspended payment of rent and taxes for citizens due to coronavirus crisis.
Explanation: The measures announced by President Emmanuel Macron are for SMEs in difficulty and include both payment deferrals and cancellations.

What did you fact-check?: Some of Madrid hospitals close because they are "too full" because of the coronavirus.
Explanation: Madrid's health ministry says it is not true. Hospitals still working and accepting people.

What did you fact-check?: The exams to access university in Valencia region will be delayed to August 10, 11 and 12.
Explanation: The Valencian Government debunks the hoax on its official social medio accounts.

What did you fact-check?: The Army is requisitioning coronavirus protection material in Catalonia.
Who said/posted it?: The president of the chamber of commerce of Catalunia presidente de la Cámara de Comercio de Barcelona, Joan Canadell
Explanation: The Defense ministry denies the claim.

What did you fact-check?: Cuba has the vaccine against the coronavirus called Interferón.
Explanation: The interferon is a drug used in certain countries to mitigate the spread of COVID-19, but it is not a vaccine.

What did you fact-check?: Cuba's health ministry, Dr. Hala, has given the vaccine to China.
Explanation: For the moment, there is no vaccine against covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: The parks of Adra, in Spain, are being fumigated with poison.
Explanation: Local and national police explain to Newtral.es that it is not true.

What did you fact-check?: Education Ministry will aprove the exams of every student in Spain.
Explanation: The ministry of educations debunks this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Vladimir Putin accused the "rest of the leaders" to have a plan to "reduce the world population".
Explanation: The subtitles are manipulated.

What did you fact-check?: People committing suicide due to quarantine in Spain.
Explanation: National Police of Valencia confirms that the images that are shared these days are from last year.

What did you fact-check?: The King of Spain has plagiarized his COVID-19 speech from a book.
Explanation: A picture shows a fragment of the King's speech and the image of a book as if the king had plagiarized his words from a writer.

What did you fact-check?: The schools in Bizkaia in Spain do not close until September.
Explanation: The Education ministry of The Basque Country denies it to Newtral.es.

What did you fact-check?: Aspirating boiling water vapor for five minutes desactivates the coronavirus.
Explanation: Doctors say it does not desactivate the virus. The WHO also says there is no vaccine yet.

What did you fact-check?: Lemon and bicarbonate kill the virus.
Explanation: Official sanitary authorities debunk that claim

What did you fact-check?: We made a Q&A of what we know about the videos of people fainting in the middle of the street.
Facemasks prevent from getting infected.
Explanation: Health authorities does not recommend using facemask unless direct contact with a positive.

What did you fact-check?: Increasing border controls will stop coronavirus from spreading.
Explanation: Neither WHO or CDC estimate that closing frontieres will stop the coronavirus

What did you fact-check?: Chinese elderly couple infected with coronavirus say goodbye while they are in a hospital.
Explanation: The elderly couple hospitalized for other conditions such as lung cancer and respiratory failure.

What did you fact-check?: The bill for a coronavirus test in the US is 3.000$.
Explanation: CDC is not making people pay the test by now.

What did you fact-check?: Viral image with differences between a cold, the flu and COVID-19.
Explanation: The symptoms are not accurate.

What did you fact-check?: They are not looking for volunteers to be infected with SARS-CoV-2 in British laboratories for 4,000 euros.
Explanation: Headlines shared on networks do not specify that they will inject other coronavirus strains, 0C43 and 229E.

What did you fact-check?: This video showing a market of animals claims to be filmed in Wuhan.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus killed 10.000 people in Wuhan.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article.

What did you fact-check?: Chain message with a notification from the Spaniard department of Health.
Explanation: The Spanish heatlh department did not issue that notification.

What did you fact-check?: Canadian Department of Health issues emergency notification that asks people to drink warm water.
Explanation: The notification was not issued by the Department of Health of Canada.

What did you fact-check?: China builds a hospital in 48 hours for coronavirus patients.
Explanation: The building has been in construction since 2018. What China has done is accomodate the building with 1.000 beds for coronavirus patients

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates funds institute hold patent and also predicted outbreak and 65 Million Deaths.
Who said/posted it?: Multple websites and social media users
Explanation: The work that Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation does on healthcare has in no way contributed to the spread of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a doctor that faints while operating coronavirus because he got infected.
Explanation: Symptoms do not show inmediatly and accoding to chinese media he fainted because he spent 17 hours operating.

What did you fact-check?: There is a person with coronavirus in Galicia (February 4th).
Explanation: According to the Spanish Health Ministry, there is just one case of coronavirus in Spain until now. The image has been manipulated and La Voz de Galicia hasn´t published that article.

What did you fact-check?: There is a person with coronavirus in Huelva (February 4th)
Explanation: According to the Spanish Health Ministry, there is just one case of coronavirus in Spain until now. The image has been manipulated and RTVE hasn´t published that information.

What did you fact-check?: Is it safe to receive a letter or a package from China?
Explanation: According to the WHO and other experts, people receiving packages from China are not at risk of contracting.

What did you fact-check?: A picture show people in China fainted on the Street after they got infected of the coronavirus
Explanation: The pictures was actually taken in 2014 in Germany during a concentration to remember holocaust victims.

What did you fact-check?: A person with coronavirus in Andorra (February 10th).
Explanation: As of February 10, there is no confirmed case of coronavirus in Andorra.

What did you fact-check?: Germans quarantined in La Gomera by the coronavirus leave home isolation without permission.
Explanation: The Ministry of Health of the Canary Islands denies they have returned to Germany.

What did you fact-check?: A person with coronavirus in Calella, Barcelona (February 13th).
Explanation: This is denied by the health authorities.

What did you fact-check?: Bats that hide under Wuhan rooftops caused the COVID-19 outbreak.
Explanation: The video was recorded in the US in 2011.

What did you fact-check?: New cases of coronavirus in Madrid linked to two universities and a club.
Explanation: Images of articles published by El Mundo related to Coronavirus were manipulated.

What did you fact-check?: Two cases confirmed of coronavirus in Huelva, Andalucía (February 26th)
Who said/posted it?: Sent via WhatsApp and Facebook posts
Explanation: Andalusian health ministry denied cases of Coronavirus in the Spanish region.

What did you fact-check?: Sevilla's university has suspended classes because of coronavirus (February 27th)
Explanation: The institution denied it on its Twitter account.

What did you fact-check?: A monkey is been infected with coronavirus in this photo.
Explanation: The photo is a capture of a video taken at least two months before the first symtoms of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Doctor Gerardo Dovakin found a vaccine agains coronavirus.
Explanation: He is actually an actor, not a doctor.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a person infected with coronavirus being detained by the police.
Explanation: This video of a person infected with Coronavirus being detained by the police is not real, it´s a drill. It was shot last February 21 at Henan Tongbai by the police and the emergency response team.

What did you fact-check?: A video of a Chinese epidemiologist saying that there are millions of infected.
Explanation: The video was longer than the version shared in Twitter. The epidemiologist said that if chinese Government had not taken action, there would be millions of infected by Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A man with a gas mask at a supermarket in Lugo (Galicia, Spain).
Explanation: The picture was taken in Austria, not Spain.

What did you fact-check?: Barcelona's council issued a notification of a new focus in two neighborhoods.
Explanation: The council denied on its Twitter account.

What did you fact-check?: The wife of a Chinese shop owner of Totana (Murcia) has coronavirus.
Explanation: She did not have the virus.

What did you fact-check?: CDC recommends men shave their beards to protect against coronavirus.
Explanation: A 2017 CDC infographic shows how facial hair could interfere with respirator masks. The graphic is unrelated to coronavirus protection and the CDC has not recommended people should shave their beards to ward off the virus.

What did you fact-check?: There is an alert of coronavirus in Madrid, Barcelona and Valencia (January 28).
Explanation: There are no cases of Coronavirus detected in Spain.

What did you fact-check?: WHO advises to avoid "unprotected sex" with animals.
Explanation: It is a manipulated imagen, WHO confirmed.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a doctor fainted on the floor after getting infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: The doctor was in the floor because the familiy of the patient punched him after he was not able to save him after he had a heart attack.

What did you fact-check?: Dr Zhong Nanshan said that saline solution can kill the virus.
Explanation: Several Chinese media outlets debunk that fake. Moreover, experts say it is not true.

What did you fact-check?: 86 clients of a brothel in quarentine after a prostituted tested positive in coronavirus.
Explanation: It was a satire from a web of humour shared as real news.

What did you fact-check?: Viral claims propogating UNICEF Message About coronavirus.
Explanation: UNICEF denied the organization issued this images.

What did you fact-check?: This Lysol desinfectant against coronavirus shows the virus is not new.
Explanation: The desinfectant refers to the other types of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A doctor called Lupita Yamamoto Lupercio found the coronavirus vaccine.
Explanation: The person in the picture is actually Sandra Oh, an actress from Grey's Anatomy. Also, there is no vaccine against coronavirus yet.

What did you fact-check?: Madrid's government has announced students will have to make-up classes during summer.
Explanation: Madrid's government hasn't announced the students will have to make-up classes during summer: the shared photo is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Galicia suspended classes because of coronavirus (March 10th).
Explanation: Galicia did not suspended clases on March 10.

What did you fact-check?: Empty supermarket in Madrid after measures announced against coronavirus.
Explanation: The images were recorded in Chile, not in Spain.

What did you fact-check?: Manuela Carmena, ex-mayor of Madrid, got infected of coronavirus.
Explanation: The tweet imitated El Pais official account and Más País denied she was infected.

What did you fact-check?: Thieves in Madrid pretending to be doctors to steal in people's houses.
Explanation: National Police of Madrid explained that there is no complaint that describes a similar case. "The note was made by the president of a neighborhood association that saw similar events on television but in a country abroad, not in Spain, so it is a hoax," they say.

What did you fact-check?: Seven ambulance workers infected with coronavirus in Catalonia.
Explanation: Health ministry of Catalonia explained that there are no ambulance workers infected.

What did you fact-check?: Neuroscientist Rodolfo Llinás says that if you can last 10 seconds without coughing and without discomfort it means that there is no fibrosis in the lungs and therefore no coronavirus infection.
Explanation: Rodolfo Llinás claims that he has not said that and there is no evidence that these recommendations are effective.

What did you fact-check?: Podemos spokesman, Pablo Echenique, is not in intensive care after getting infected with covid.

What did you fact-check?: Education Ministry announces all students are passing the actual course without making exams because of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A WhatsApp message suggests holding the breath during 10 seconds and drink water every 15 minutes are effective methods fighting coronavirus.
Explanation: No scientific proof.

What did you fact-check?: Madrid's government has announced students will have to make-up classes during summer.
Explanation: Madrid's government hasn't announced the students will have to make-up classes during summer: the shared photo is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Audio from WhatsApp in which the head of Cardiology at the Gregorio Marañón Hospital states that we are in a moment of uncontrolled coronavirus infection.
Explanation: It was denied by the hospital.

What did you fact-check?: Catalonia universities give all course credits to its students after clases being suspended.
Explanation: Education ministry in Catalonia denied it.

What did you fact-check?: La Paz, Gregorio Marañon or 12 de octubre hospitals are closing because the are over capacity.
Explanation: Madrid government denied it.

What did you fact-check?: Helicopters are going to spread 'medicines' againts the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Spanish politician Ortega Smith said "I prefer to get the covid-19 than being gay".

What did you fact-check?: Police have "free entry into houses and buildings" in Malaga to identify possible coronavirus infected people.
Explanation: Police denied it on its Twitter account.

What did you fact-check?: Niño Jesús hospital has been left without COVID-19 to care for children and young people in Madrid.
Explanation: The hospital denied it to newtral.es.

What did you fact-check?: Madrid enables 915038030 to request prescription drugs.
Explanation: The government denied it.

What did you fact-check?: Insurance companies stop covering traffic accidents because the coronavirus.
Explanation: The UNESPA Business Insurance Association deneid it.

What did you fact-check?: China has announced the sucess of Egyptian serum form Dr. Hala, Ealth Miniter of Egypt, against coronavirus
Explanation: WHO says there is no known cure of vaccine to the coronavirus for now.

What did you fact-check?: Holding your breath for 10sec can determine if you have COVID-19 and you should drink water every 15 minutes.
Explanation: There are no medical and scientific evidences

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin C and warm water with lemon are effective ways of preventing COVID-19.
Explanation: Vitamin C has no know effect on the novel coronavirus, and neither does warm water with lemon.

What did you fact-check?: Pedro Sánchez has a medical team of 14 people to take care of him since the coronavirus crisis.
Explanation: The medical team is in the presidential house since 1997, it has nothing to do with the covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: Spanish home office has not issued a statement announcing the complete closure of Madrid, the Basque Country and La Rioja.
Explanation: Home office denied the autentity of the document.

What did you fact-check?: Felipe Gonzalez, ex-Prime minister of Spain, says that the Spanish coalition government cannot face the covid crisis.
Explanation: The Twitter account is a parody.

What did you fact-check?: The current coronavirus has been "manufactured" in Wuhan.
Explanation: There is no scientifice reason to belive that.The international scientific community condemns conspiracy theories and recalls that the current coronavirus originated in wildlife.

What did you fact-check?: A message chain claim that a message from Stanford hospital gives advice to frink water every 15 mintes in order to prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: A statement from the Stanford hospital distanced themselves from the fake message.

What did you fact-check?: Drink water every 15 minutes to avoid cononavirus.
Explanation: It is false that drinking water every 15 minutes helps to avoid Covid-19 by "cleaning" your throat.

What did you fact-check?: They discovered that a whole floor of the main Peruvian hospital is infected with COVID-19 and the decided to close the place.
Explanation: It is false that Peruvian government decided to close a floor at the main national hospital due a general contagion of Covid-19

What did you fact-check?: Peru has just nationalized hospitals and clinics.
Who said/posted it?: Gustavo Petro, former mayor of Bogotá
Explanation: Peruvian government gave a temporary order for centralizing all the medical resources under the Ministry of Health authority during the emergency, but it's does not include the property of clinics and private services.

What did you fact-check?: There are one hundred children infected with COVID-19 in the main hospital in Lima.
Explanation: Authorities denied the information of one hundred children infectec with the virus in that hospital, the main public facility for the treatment of children in Lima.

What did you fact-check?: Italy is the first European Union country that has been able to isolate the coronavirus.
Who said/posted it?: Statment made by Nicola Zingaretti, italian politician and secretary of the Democratic Party
Explanation: France was the first country.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus in Cecina (city in Tuscany, Italy).
Explanation: At today's date (Feb 3), there are no coronavirus cases in the city of Cecina.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus in Arezzo (city in Tuscany, Italy).
Explanation: At today's date (Feb 3), there are no coronavirus cases in the city of Arezzo.

What did you fact-check?: 27 patients with coronavirus in an hospital in Rome.
Explanation: At today's date (Feb 3), there are no coronavirus cases at the Umberto I hospital in Rome.

What did you fact-check?: Ultimo (italian singer) has coronavirus.
Explanation: At today's date (Feb 6) in Italy we have only 2 case of coronavirus (2 chinese citizens).

What did you fact-check?: A case of coronavirus in Caserta.
Explanation: There is no case of coronavirus in Caserta (at 10 of February)

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates predicted coronavirus.
Explanation: Bill Gates didn't predict coronavirus 2019-nCoV

What did you fact-check?: In 2012 a Facebook user predicted coronavirus from China.
Explanation: The Facebook status wasn't the original one. It has been modified on the 27th of January 2020.

What did you fact-check?: Hand sanitizer form 2010 is labeled against coronavirus 2019-nCoV.
Explanation: The hand sanitizer marked in 2010 was against the general coronavirus. It wasn't related with the coronavirus-nCoV.

What did you fact-check?: A Facebook status from 2012 talked about the spread of coronavirus in 2020.
Explanation: The facebook status was updated on 27 Jan 2020.

What did you fact-check?: Years ago, there was a hand sanitizer active against Sars-Cov-2.
Explanation: The hand sanitizer is active against coronavirus in general. There is no specific sanitizer against Sars-Cov-2. Pagella Politica contacted the manufacturing company.

What did you fact-check?: 2 coronavirus Sars-Cov-2 cases in Bovalino (Reggio Calabria, Italy).
Explanation: No Sars-Cov-2 cases at that time.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus Sars-Cov-2 in Sant'Egidio (Abruzzo, Italy).
Explanation: No Sars-Cov-2 cases at that time.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus Sars-Cov-2 sites in Parabiago e Nerviano (Lombardia, Italy)
Explanation: No coronavirus Sars-Cov-2 sites there at that time.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus Sars-Cov-2 at Bosch company in Bari (Puglia) because Chinese people visited the week before.
Explanation: No Sars-Cov-2 cases at that time.

What did you fact-check?: Italian Red Cross gives the recipe for making amuchina (hand sanitizer) at home.
Explanation: Italian Red Cross has never shared any receipe. The receipe shared isn't the real one and could be useful only to disinfect vegetables.

What did you fact-check?: An American soldier has been paid to spread Sars-Cov-2 in Europe.
Explanation: The man is the sheriff's deputy Rick Grimes, the main caracter of The Walking Dead and the picture is a tumbnail of the 1st episode of The Walking Dead.

What did you fact-check?: Cristiano Ronaldo decided to turn his hotels into free hospitals.
Explanation: Cristiano Ronaldo has never decide to turn his hotels in to free hospitals.

What did you fact-check?: There is a Russian medicine that could be use against Sars-Cov-2.
Explanation: It is not the case.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus has been originated in a laboratory linked to China's biowarfare program.
Explanation: There is no evidence that the coronavirus 2019-nCoV was born in a China laboratory.

What did you fact-check?: This is an image of coronavirus 2019-nCoV.
Explanation: The image that has been shared is not a photo of the Coronavirus 2019 n-CoV. It's a graphic processing.

What did you fact-check?: A Chinese man has been lynched because he pretended to have coronavirus.
Explanation: The man was Philippine and not Chinese. He was lynched because other people thought that he could potentially start spreading coronavirus Sars-Cov-2 in their city.

What did you fact-check?: This picture showing lots of coffins was taken in Bergamo in 2020.
Explanation: The picture has been taken in Lampedusa in 2013.

What did you fact-check?: Italy from the space during a flash mob in March 2020.
Explanation: The picture has been taken 2014.

What did you fact-check?: Katy Perry, Madonna and Black Sabbath shared videos of Italy's flash mob with fake audio.
Explanation: All the videos have real images but fake audios. In the first case – Katy Perry – italians are singing the song Roar instead of the national anthem (real video). In the second case – Madonna and Black Sabbath – italians are singing I rise or War pigs instead of Macarena (real video).

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus 2019-nCoV is as dangerous as plague and cholera.
Who said/posted it?: Statment made by Matteo Salvini, italian politician and leader of Lega.
Explanation: At today's date, we are not able to consider Coronavirus 2019n-CoV as dangerous as other diseases

What did you fact-check?: There is a link between the coronavirus 2019-nCoV and irregular migration.
Who said/posted it?: Statment made by Matteo Salvini, italian politician and leader of Lega. The statment was published on official Salvini's Facebook, Twitter and Instagram account.
Explanation: There is no direct connection between the spread of Conornavirus 2019-nCoV and the irregular migration in the Mediterranean sea.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus in China: 2.8 million infected and 112,000 dead.
Explanation: It's not true that in Cina there are 2.8 million people infected and 112,000 dead.

What did you fact-check?: Warning: the virus is spreading in Italy (January 22).
Explanation: This news is not confirmed by any national or local newspaper nor by the Italian government.

What did you fact-check?: This video connected with coronavirus shows a wholesale market in China and its low–hygiene environment.
Explanation: The video is highly misleading: the market is located in Indonesia and not in China.

What did you fact-check?: Retirment benefits reduced by 50% in April.
Explanation: The public statment was fake. The national social welfare institution has never shared that document.

What did you fact-check?: The Italian department of civil protection has communicated that since the 16h of March there is the possibilty that will be introduce the bio-containment BSL-4
Explanation: The department of civil protection has never shared a public statement about the biocontainment BSL-4.

What did you fact-check?: The Italian Ministry of Interior ruled with a public statment that police will check all the people that will exit from their house.
Explanation: The Ministry of Interior has never shared any public statment about it.

What did you fact-check?: A blog post claiming that COVID-19 is the name of the vaccine against novel coronavirus.
Explanation: A blog post claiming that the World Health Organization has announced COVID-19 as a vaccine against the novel coronavirus has a false headline. There is no vaccine yet for the disease.

What did you fact-check?: Israeli scientists at the MIGAL Research Institute have developed a vaccine for COVID-19.
Explanation: Researchers at the MIGAL Institute in Israel have announced a breakthrough in research into the novel coronavirus, but they have not developed a vaccine as claimed.

What did you fact-check?: A team of medical trainees from JKUAT (a university in Kenya) have developed and tested a vaccine successfully.
Explanation: The university that the students allegedly attended has denied the claim. Additionally, a doctor contacted by PesaCheck has indicated that a vaccine cannot be developed within a month. An Australian lab is in the initial stages of developing a vaccine by recreating the virus.

What did you fact-check?: There is a patent for the 2019-nCoV coronavirus.
Explanation: A post claiming that the Pirbright Institute in the UK applied for a patent for the novel coronavirus outbreak, but uses documents showing a patent from 2015 that the institute holds for avian influenza virus, which is also a coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese government requests the Supreme People's Court for permission to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients to stop the spread of the disease
Explanation: China has not sought the permission of the country's Supreme People's Court to execute 20,000 coronavirus patients.

What did you fact-check?: An audio clip circulating on Facebook claiming that Kenya has recorded 63 cases of COVID-19.
Explanation: An audio clip claiming that Kenya has recorded 63 cases of novel coronavirus has been edited and taken out of context. The clip was part of a training exercise by the Ministry of Health to prepare for a likely outbreak ahead of the opening of a quarantine center in Nairobi.

What did you fact-check?: Two Chinese nationals in Kenya have been killed after allegedly escaping from quarantine at the Nairobi Airport.
Explanation: Reports that two Chinese nationals in Kenya have been killed over COVID-19 panic are false.

What did you fact-check?: A video claiming to show a coronavirus being extracted from a man’s upper lip.
Explanation: A video claiming to show a coronavirus being extracted for a man’s upper lip is of a botfly larva.

What did you fact-check?: Emirates has suspended flights to Johannesburg after South Africa announced its first case of novel coronavirus.
Explanation: A statement claiming that Emirates has suspended flights to Johannesburg due to coronavirus is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Four people have died in Zanzibar after handling a chicken infected with COVID-19.
Who said/posted it?: Fake page impersonating ITV, a Tanzanian TV station
Explanation: A post claiming that four individuals in Zanzibar died from COVID-19 after handling a diseased chicken is false. The post contains images of a diseased chicken that circulated in other countries claiming to show symptoms of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Uganda did not deport 19 passengers from high-risk COVID-19 countries.
Who said/posted it?: Facebook post from a Kenyan user
Explanation: Ugandan authorities did not deport 19 passengers on a KLM flight from Amsterdam to Entebbe. The passengers did not show 'severe' flu-like symptoms.

What did you fact-check?: Cristiano Ronaldo decided to turn his hotels into free hospital.
Explanation: Cristiano Ronaldo has never decide to turn his hotels in to free hospitals.

What did you fact-check?: A Facebok post suggests that China has created the new coronavirus in order to kill 1% of its population.
Explanation: There is no evidence that supports this claim.

What did you fact-check?: A video posted on Twitter shows a group of chinese people converting to islamism under the argument that islamics are imune to COVID-19.
Explanation: The claim is false. Islamic people are not imune to COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Event 201 “gave out stuffed souvenir coronavirus toys” to “commemorate” novel coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: Event 201 used a fictionalized coronavirus outbreak as its pandemic scenario but did not "predict" the outbreak of a strain that would be detected two months later in December 2019 in Wuhan, China.

What did you fact-check?: "CORONAVIRUS: Reports of 10,000 DEAD in Wuhan, China."
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: “Hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”
Explanation: The Food and Drug Administration has found no evidence that the virus is spreading via imports.

What did you fact-check?: “coronavirus: Florida man arrested for robbery using cough as a weapon.”
Explanation: This screenshot of “breaking news” is originally from a satirical news site. If you look closely, you’ll see a news generator watermark in the top right corner, meaning the image was created.

What did you fact-check?: “The Simpsons” predicted the coronavirus.
Explanation: An image from the show was altered to read “corona virus”.

What did you fact-check?: High levels of sulfur dioxide in Wuhan “may be a sign of mass cremations of victims of the coronavirus."
Explanation: The photo shows sulfur dioxide projections. It is not a real-time satellite image.

What did you fact-check?: 20 million Chinese people converted to Islam after it’s proven that the coronavirus doesn’t affect Muslims.
Explanation: Video claiming to show Chinese converting to Islam after the current coronavirus outbreak was published before the first reported case in Wuhan in 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Scientists "are shocked to discover that weed kills coronavirus”.
Explanation: The CDC still reports that there is "currently no vaccine to prevent" and "no specific antiviral treatment recommended" for the novel coronavirus, or COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: “Cocaine kills coronavirus, scientists is shocked to discover that this drug can fight the virus.”
Explanation: This “breaking news” image is from an online news generator and not based on any real news coverage.

What did you fact-check?: Says drinking a bleach solution will prevent you from getting the coronavirus.
Explanation: Officials have repeteadly warned consumers against injesting it, saying doing so could cause severe vomiting and liver failure.

What did you fact-check?: Says China "stole coronavirus from Canada and weaponized it into a Bioweapon."
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Says the Chinese Communist Party "will finally admit that the real source of the coronavirus is from ‘a lab in Wuhan’ linked to its covert biological weapon programs."
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: There’s a ‘coronavirus patent’, FEMA ‘proposes martial law’, Gates Foundation predicted virus, ‘funded group who owns virus patent’, coronavirus was ‘created in a lab’ as a ‘bioweapon for population control’
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Says the coronavirus can be slowed or stopped with the “immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C.”
Explanation: There’s currently no vaccine or medicine recommended to treat the current coronavirus, and there’s no evidence high doses of vitamin C has any effect.

What did you fact-check?: Says the CDC recommends men shave their beards to protect against coronavirus.
Explanation: A 2017 CDC infographic shows how facial hair could interfere with respirator masks. The graphic is unrelated to coronavirus protection and the CDC has not recommended people should shave their beards to ward off the virus.

What did you fact-check?: “The coronavirus is the common cold, folks.”
Explanation: The 2019 coronavirus is a new virus that had not been previously identified.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus patients are being "cremated alive" in China.
Explanation: The Chinese government has ordered the swift cremation of patients who die after contracting the coronavirus. But there is no evidence they are being cremated alive.

What did you fact-check?: Says the 2008 book “End of Days” predicted the current coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: Dean Koontz, not Sylvia Browne, wrote about “Wuhan-400”.

What did you fact-check?: “Breaking: UK Prepares For Full Lockdown After Hundreds Of New Cases — Wuhan Super Virus Updates.”
Explanation: Only about a dozen coronavirus cases have been confirmed in the United Kingdom.

What did you fact-check?: “When using a medical mask you’re supposed to use… white side out (this is the filter part) for when you’re not sick.”
Explanation: Global health agencies and medical mask producers agree that the colored side of the mask should always be worn on the outside.

What did you fact-check?: Says the 2019 coronavirus "causes sudden death syndrome."
Explanation: There is no evidence that the virus causes sudden death syndrome.

What did you fact-check?: Says the coronavirus is “a MILITARY BIO-WEAPON Developed by China's Army.”
Explanation: There is no evidence that the Chinese military developed the 2019 coronavirus as a bioweapon.

What did you fact-check?: Says "the coronavirus was engineered by scientists in a lab."
Explanation: There is no evidence that the coronavirus was created in a lab.

What did you fact-check?: Says the coronavirus isn’t new because “Lysol has it listed as one of the viruses that it kills.”
Explanation: Lysol says some of its surface cleaning products, including its disinfectant spray, have been effective against viruses “similar to” 2019 Novel Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Says a "Clorox bottle claimed it could kill (the 2019 coronavirus)... before it was developed."
Explanation: There is no evidence that the 2019 coronavirus was "developed" prior to the outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: A chain message circulated on Tuesday, January 14, warning people to avoid going to Shangri-La Plaza, a mall in Mandaluyong City, because of a supposed case of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) reported in one of the mall's medical clinics.
Explanation: The Department of Health (DOH) and Healthway Medical both issued advisories denying the claim in the chain message.

What did you fact-check?: “Confirmed cases” of the novel coronavirus or 2019 nCoV were recorded at the Philippine Bank of Communications (PBCom) Tower in Makati City, according to a message that circulated Friday, January 24.
Explanation: Speaking to reporters on January 24, Health Undersecretary Eric Domingo maintained that there is still no confirmed case of the 2019 nCov in the Philippines. The management of PBCom Tower also said there is “no truth” to the information.

What did you fact-check?: A screenshot of a text message that spread on Facebook claimed that there is a Chinese patient at the Hi-Precision Diagnostics clinic in Alabang who was tested positive for the novel coronavirus or 2019 nCoV.
Explanation: In a press briefing on Tuesday, January 28, the Department of Health (DOH) announced that there was still no confirmed case of 2019 nCoV in the country. The patient at Asian Hospital and Medical Center in Alabang, Muntinlupa City is among the 24 persons under investigation (PUIs) for the possible 2019 nCoV infection.

What did you fact-check?: The 2019 novel coronavirus (nCoV) is a "type of rabies" that can be contracted by eating bats.
Explanation: In a press briefing on Tuesday, January 28, Health Secretary Francisco Duque III clarified that the 2019 nCoV belongs to the Coronaviridae family of viruses. Meanwhile, rabies is from Rhabdoviridae.

What did you fact-check?: A message saying a “patient tested positive” for the 2019 novel coronavirus (nCoV) at the Makati Medical Center circulated on messaging apps and social media platforms on Monday, January 27.
Explanation: There is still no confirmed case of the 2019 nCoV in the Philippines as of January 28, according to the Department of Health (DOH).

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus arrived in the Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Explanation: Coronavirus has not arrived in the Balkan region, the article is about a man from Serbia who is in quarantine in India.

What did you fact-check?: Russian scientists have a cure for fighting the new Chinese virus.
Who said/posted it?: Sputnik, and then other media outlets in the Balkan region
Explanation: There has been no new information on Triazavirin drug testing or its results. By the date of publication of this analysis, Triazavirin had not been confirmed as a cure for the new corona virus. Because the title of Sputnik's article claims that the Russian drug Triazavirin for Covid-19 is "ready", although the article does not contain this claim, the article receives clickbait and misinformation ratings.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus appears in the Balkan region.
Explanation: A Serbian citizen has indeed been quarantined because suspicion of being infected with the 2019-nCoV virus, but he is quarantined in India, not in Serbia.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus was created in the lab in order to destroy the Chinese economy. The vaccine is already available.
Who said/posted it?: Serbian news agency, and then dozen of media in Balkan region
Final rating: Fake news, conspiracy theory, manipulation of facts, disinformation, clickbait
Explanation: Claims that the "mutation of the virus corona was caused artificially in the laboratory" and that it was a "biological war" and that the virus was "released to weaken the Chinese economy" are rated as conspiracy theories because there is no evidence or argument for them.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus arrived in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Who said/posted it?: Mainstream TV station, and then various online media
Explanation: Since the allegation that the corona virus arrived in Sarajevo is presented in the title as fact and that there are no confirmations in the text of the articles, all the articles are rated as misinformation and clickbait.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus was created in the lab in order to destroy the Chinese economy. The vaccine is already available.
Explanation: Claims that the "mutation of the virus corona was caused artificially in the laboratory" and that it was a "biological war" and that the virus was "released to weaken the Chinese economy" are rated as conspiracy theories because there is no evidence or argument for them.

What did you fact-check?: Simpsons predicted the coronavirus.
Explanation: Simsons did not predicted coronavirus, the episod was talkin about "osaka flu". Image was also photoshoped.

What did you fact-check?: China took advantage of the coronavirus crisis to buy back stocks of its technology companies belonging to foreign investors.
Who said/posted it?: Local online media published it, then local member on parliament said it on TV, then other media picked up the story
Explanation:
This is the story in full : Previously, stocks of technology companies, belonged to Europeans and Americans foreign investors.
Due to the situation in Wuhan, Juan began to decline, but the Central Bank did nothing to support Juan.
And when the price fell, below the allowable limit, XI JINPING gave the order, at one point, to buy ALL the shares of Europeans and Americans.
Not only has China made $ 20 billion, but these days it has returned the shares of its companies to China. The story is completely fabricated and there is no evidence for it. In fact, the story was published back in 2014 - but it was not the Chinese but the Russian president at the time, and the emergency was not because of the corona but because of the crime. The media only changed the name of the country, the president, the currency and the reason for the emergency and re-published the story.

What did you fact-check?: Someone from Bosnia and Herzegovina was captured on the Diamond Princess cruiser in quarantine. After receiving the results of being negative on coronavirus, he returned to BiH.
Explanation: This man was not on the cruiser, was not quarantined and was not tested for the virus. He personally said all this for several media in the region, but later said that he was scammed by his friends.

What did you fact-check?: China constructed an hospital for coronavirus in 48 hours.
Who said/posted it?: Mainstream website 24sata.hr , then 20+ media in the region
Explanation: The building has been in construction since 2018. What China has done is accomodate the building with 1.000 beds for coronavirus patients.

What did you fact-check?: Video of Wuhan market where the new coronavirus started to spread.
Who said/posted it?: Facebook page, then a mainstream media outlet, and then 40+ media in the Balkan region
Explanation: Video is not from China, but from Indonesia.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus hits 15% fatality rate.
Explanation: The 15% fatality rate from coronavirus (2019-nCoV) applied only to the initial cluster of 41 patients with confirmed infection and severe symptoms, as reported in The Lancet. Coronavirus infections can also produce mild symptoms, which likely went undetected. The mortality rate based on a group of more than 800 patients with laboratory-confirmed infection suggests that the fatality rate is closer to 3%.

What did you fact-check?: Novel coronavirus is not a new virus.
Explanation: Many coronavirus strains have already been discovered, but new strains regularly emerge due to mutations. The particular coronavirus responsible for the outbreak originating in Wuhan, China, provisionally named 2019-nCoV, is a new strain that was identified by scientists after sequencing its genome.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus contains "HIV insertions".
Explanation: This claim is based on a study which compared extremely short protein sequences between the 2019 novel coronavirus and HIV, a practice likely to give false positives. The study’s authors also overlooked checking for potential similarities between 2019-nCoV and other organisms. As it turned out, these short protein sequences were similar to many other organisms, not just HIV, thereby refuting the claim that 2019-nCoV contains DNA from the HIV virus.

What did you fact-check?: 2019 novel coronavirus contains "pShuttle-SN" sequence proving laboratory origin.
Who said/posted it?: Alex Jones, Info Wars; Mike Adams, Natural News
Explanation: The pShuttle-SN vector was designed by researchers seeking to develop a potential SARS vaccine. However, the 2019 novel coronavirus does not contain a sequence from the pShuttle-SN vector as claimed. There is no evidence supporting the claim that 2019-nCoV is man-made.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus pandemic can be dramatically slowed, or stopped, with the immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C.
Explanation: Maintaining an adequate intake of vitamin C is important for staying healthy. However, evidence from clinical trials shows that regular vitamin C supplementation does not prevent viral respiratory tract infections such as the common cold, which can be caused by coronaviruses, in the general population. Although some studies have shown a reduced incidence of the common cold in individuals undergoing severe physical stress, such as marathon runners.

What did you fact-check?: "[The coronavirus is] “new” yet it was lab-created and patented in 2015".
Who said/posted it?: Chris Kirckof and Jordan Sather on Facebook and Twitter
Explanation: The post references the Wuhan coronavirus, but the patent filed is clearly stated to be for the SARS coronavirus, which caused the 2003 outbreak. Neither the SARS nor Wuhan coronavirus is lab-created; evidence points to an animal reservoir as the source of infection.

What did you fact-check?: Every election year has a disease; coronavirus has a contagion factor of 2; coronavirus has a cure rate of 99.7% for those under 50 it infects.
Explanation: Every year in the U.S. is an election year, if taking into account midterm elections as well as presidential elections, and contrary to the claim, not every election year has had a disease outbreak, as implied in the claim. In addition, the transmissibility of the coronavirus, represented by the “basic reproduction number”, is still under study. Currently, the basic reproduction numbers reported for the virus causing COVID-19 range between around 2 to more than 6.

What did you fact-check?: Evidence indicates COVID-19 virus escaped a Chinese lab that was researching it, thus causing the outbreak.
Who said/posted it?: Steven W. Mosher, New York Post
Explanation: Overall, Mosher’s argument is based on unfounded speculation and scientific inaccuracies. Multiple scientific studies have indicated that the virus has a natural origin, not the result of human engineering.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus outbreak is not actually caused by a virus, but by 5G technology.
Explanation: There is no causal link between COVID-19 and 5G technology. The cause of the disease has been definitively identified in scientific studies as a novel coronavirus. 5G technology uses low-energy radio waves, which do not damage DNA or cells unlike ionizing radiation.

What did you fact-check?: Shanghai Government Officially Recommends Vitamin C for COVID-19.
Who said/posted it?: Andrew W. Saul, Orthomolecular Medicine News Service
Explanation: Intravenous high-dose vitamin C has been used to treat patients with COVID-19 in certain Chinese hospitals, but it has not been recommended by the Shanghai government as claimed. The OMNS article also cherry-picks the treatment’s potential benefits from two reports, leaving out the potential side effects, including nausea and kidney stones, and failing to mention contraindications for pregnant women and individuals with cancer and other medical conditions.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus outbreak linked to eating bats.
Who said/posted it?: Emma Parker, writer at the Daily Star (and many others)
Explanation: Bats are known natural reservoirs for coronaviruses. However, many other animals, such as civet cats and snakes, can also carry these viruses. There is currently not enough evidence to conclude that the 2019 coronavirus outbreak resulted from people eating bats in Wuhan, China.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus pandemic can be dramatically slowed, or stopped, with the immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C.
Who said/posted it?: Andrew W. Saul, Orthomolecular Medicine News Service
Explanation: Maintaining an adequate intake of vitamin C is important for staying healthy. However, evidence from clinical trials shows that regular vitamin C supplementation does not prevent viral respiratory tract infections such as the common cold, which can be caused by coronaviruses, in the general population. Although some studies have shown a reduced incidence of the common cold in individuals undergoing severe physical stress, such as marathon runners.

What did you fact-check?: On the ocassion of the coronavirus, users in social media relate the Umbrella Corporation, from the videogame Resident Evil, with a Chinese company RLSW.
Explanation: The chinese company RLSW is engaged in genetic testing and advanced scientific research. However, the address on Google Maps could not be corroborated and the official site does not offer much information.

What did you fact-check?: Woman eats bat soup contaminated with coronavirus in China.
Explanation: The video was recorded on the island of Palau, Micronesia in 2016.

What did you fact-check?: On the ocassion of the coronavirus, posts in social media ensure that there have been pandemics in the 20's for several centuries.
Explanation: The information in the post are innacurate because de pandemics mentioned in the posts ocurred years before of years after the 20's of those centuries.

What did you fact-check?: Videos of people infected with coronavirus in China.
Explanation: In both cases, it can't corroborate the origin of the material. Besides, does not exist an official pronouncement of any chinese authority in health matter.

What did you fact-check?: Doctor fainting durying surgery to a coronavirus patient.
Explanation: The video was published in the chinese social media WEIBO and it shows a fainting doctor during an open heart surgery. According to the post, the video gas recorded in a hospital of Zhotong in Yunnan, China.

What did you fact-check?: A doctor called Leslie Chow discovered the coronavirus and died due to contact with coronavirus patients.
Explanation: The portrait in the post corresponds to the american actor Ken Jeong. However, the doctor Lin Wenliang was the first to warn of the risk of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Label in disinfectant ensures that the new coronavirus strain is not new.
Explanation: The disinfectant can only eliminate other types of coronaviruses that are found on hard and non-porous surfaces. But it does not include the new strain 2019-nCoV

What did you fact-check?: People infected with coronavirus die in the street while doctors travel through the infection zone.
Explanation: Both images belong to different events. The first photo corresponds to a performance in Germany and the second photo portrays two doctors who care for Ebola sufferers in Uganda.

What did you fact-check?: A chinese pirate movie called "coronavirus" is sold in Mexico City.
Explanation: The video is actually a 2013 South Korean film called Gamgi.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese elderly couple infected with coronavirus say goodbye while they are in a hospital.
Explanation: The elderly couple hospitalized for other conditions such as lung cancer and respiratory failure.

What did you fact-check?: Secretary of Health in Mexico recommends taking vitamin C to prevent coronavirus.
Explanation: The information was disseminated by a brand of nutritional products, but it is false that taking vitamin C is a preventive measure.

What did you fact-check?: Don't take NSAIDs. This medicine worsens the symptom.
Explanation: The French health minister has made a similar statement while the health authorities of EU, UK, Taiwan said there is no enough evidence to support that claim.

What did you fact-check?: Wuhan Virus is named SARI. Steroid is the medicine to cure it. Acetic acid can be used to prevent it.
Explanation: 1."Wuhan Virus" is named as "2019n-Cov".2.Steroid is not used for curing it. 3. Spraying acetic acid in air can not help prevent it.

What did you fact-check?: Wuhan Virus is leaked from Wuhan P4 lab.
Explanation: The argument is based on unfounded speculation and quoted from an outdated study.

What did you fact-check?: Government of the Philippines gave free masks on streets.
Explanation: The government of the Philippines did donate face masks to several organizations but hadn't give face mask for free on the street at least by Feb. 7, 2020.

What did you fact-check?: Russian CDC admitted that COVID-19 is human-made.
Explanation:
The original document from the Russian health ministry only mentions that COVID-19 is
a recombinant virus. It doesn't suggest the COVID-19 is a human-made virus.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus dies at 56°C, so eat cooked food and turn on AC. Plus, Ethanol can kill Wuhan Virus.
Explanation: Turning on the heater can not kill coronavirus. Both alcohol and chlorine can be useful to disinfect surfaces, but they can not cure COVID-19 and need to be used under appropriate recommendations.

What did you fact-check?: Italy official Giulio Gallera: China lies to us. The date China provided is false. Italy has become Wuhan and the medical system has a breakdown.
Explanation: The Health and Welfare Regional Minister in Lombardy, Giulio Gallera, didn't give such statements in the interview.

What did you fact-check?: If you see a person wearing a white wristband, leave him alone. He is under quarantine.
Explanation: The measure of the electronic wristband is implemented in Hong Kong, not Taiwan. The picture is miscaptioned.

What did you fact-check?: The symptoms of the first nine days when one catches COVID-19.
Explanation: COVID-19 patients don't have the exact same symptoms. The most common symptoms are fever, tiredness, and dry cough. Some patients may have aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat or diarrhea.

What did you fact-check?: Many foreigners wiped their saliva onto the handle of Taipei's metro to spread COVID-19.
Explanation: The videos were filmed in Hong Kong and Brussels, not in Taiwan.

What did you fact-check?: The smell of tea tree oil can kill coronavirus in nostrils, according to a study of an Austrian university.
Explanation: It works in a lab, but there is no evidence to prove that smelling oil for 15 mins can kill coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Zhong Nanshan: shower may cause coronavirus infection according to cases in Hong Kong and Diamond Princess.
Explanation: Zhong said "sewer", but it was translated as shower in Chinese in one wechat account. Then Taiwanese media misunderstood as "shower" and interviewed Taiwanese officials and experts to command it.

What did you fact-check?: Environmental Enzymes can prevent 2019-nCov. Use them to wash vegetables, rinse your mouth, wash nostril and your hands.
Explanation: Post is a commercial ad with false health information.

What did you fact-check?: A person died of hematemesis in Beitou. He was then diagnosed with 2019n-Cov. Wear a mask in Taipei.
Explanation: There was no death case in Taiwan (1/28/2020).

What did you fact-check?: A confirmed case was dead in a hospital in Taiwan. His body was burned on 1/26.
Explanation: As to Jan. 30., the alleged hospital didn't have a novel coronavirus confirmed case, according to the health authority as well as the hospital.

What did you fact-check?: Strong garlic soup can cure "Wuhan Virus".
Explanation: There is no evidence that garlic soup cures new coronavirus (COVID-19). To date, there is no specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Don't wear clothes with fur collar or fleece material. It is easy to be contaminated the "Wuhan Virus".
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence.

What did you fact-check?: Bats are hidden in every households' rooftop in Wuhan.
Explanation: The film was filmed in Indonesia, not Wuhan.

What did you fact-check?: Dr. Kuo Yen-Jen suggested smearing sesame oil into the nostril. It can prevent flu and 2019-nCov.
Explanation: There is no evidence that smearing sesame oil into the nostril has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus. To date, there is no specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: People who have ACE2 easily to be infected with 2019-nCov. Especially people who have hypertension.
Explanation: The post is a commercial ad with false health information.

What did you fact-check?: The video has been taken at the Wuhan market.
Explanation: The video was filmed in Indonesia, not Wuhan.

What did you fact-check?: Japanese Professor: Taiwan doesn't need to join WHO.
Explanation: The man in the photo is a Japanese pornography star, Shigeo Tokuda.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese CDC: Tea can reduce the risk of getting coronavirus.
Explanation: Chinese CDC hasn't published such a study nor recommendation. To date, there has been no information nor evidence to suggest that tea has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Study indicated that black tea and Pu'er tea can help to prevent coronavirus
Explanation: To date, there has been no information nor evidence to suggest that drinking tea has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: When the first group of Japenese evacuated from Wuhan to Tokyo, each evacuee took one own ambulance.
Explanation: According to the Japanese media NHK, among 206 Japanese evacuees being withdrawn from Wuhan on January 29th, 199 evacuees took seven buses, and five evacuees took ambulances to the hospital for further examination.

What did you fact-check?: Share this post on Facebook, you can get free face masks.
Explanation: Taiwan FactCheck Center has shared that post following the instruction but didn't get any feedback. The posts had been neither deleted or revised afterward.

What did you fact-check?: WHO announced that among many medicines, the best coronavirus killer is nicotine.
Explanation: WHO hasn't published such a study nor recommendation. To date, there is no specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Doctor said: coronavirus can be alive in temperature 25-26C. Drinking hot water can help prevent it.
Explanation: Coronavirus can be active in temperature 25-26C. Drinking hot water does not prevent the new coronavirus disease.

What did you fact-check?: If you have a runny nose or cough, you don't have COVID-19.
Explanation: Runny nose and dry cough are among the symptoms of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Vietnam government gave free face masks on the streets.
Explanation: The film documented the charity event organized by motorcycle group, not Vietnam government.

What did you fact-check?: India scientists found: HIV gene is embedded in 2019-nCov, which is China's bio-weapon.
Explanation: Uncanny similarity of unique inserts in the 2019-nCoV spike protein to HIV-1 gp120 and Gag》.

What did you fact-check?: Singapore - Hong Kong People ran into supermarket panic buying toilet paper.
Explanation: The video was filmed in China and was already uploaded online on October 4th, 2019.

What did you fact-check?: An apartment in Wuhan was on fire since the owner over-sprayed ethanol. He turned on the heat, causing an explosion.
Explanation: The video was filmed in Chongqing, not in Wuhan.

What did you fact-check?: Overseas Chinese bought flights to ship medical supplies from Melbourne to South China.
