Explanation: To ship the medical supplies donated by Chinese entrepreneurs in Kenya, the Chinese airline upgraded passengers to business class and used the economic class to place all donation goods.

What did you fact-check?: In the Chinese city of Shandong, no one gets COVID-19 because it's full of garlic.
Explanation: There is no evidence that garlic has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus. Plus, there was a confirmed case in Shandong. (Feb. 11, 2020)

What did you fact-check?: Russian doctor taught: washing your nostril with soap can prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence that rinsing nostril has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus. To date, there is no specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Putting an onion in your room can help prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: No evidence that placing onions in the room has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: China scientist Ms Shih generated coronavirus.
Explanation: A SARS-like cluster of circulating bat coronaviruses shows potential for human emergence.

What did you fact-check?: Hold your breath for 10 seconds. If you are able to do this, you are not infected with COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support this claim. People must have a test conducted by hospitals or legitimate labs to determine the infection with COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Miles Kwok: China military admitted that Conoravirus is made by China. It is a human-made bio-weapon.
Explanation: Miles Kwok didn't mention nor suggest that COVID-19 is human-made bio-weapon.

What did you fact-check?: The Windy diagram of sulfur dioxyde emission level over Wuhan indicated massive corpses burning down there.
Explanation: Fa-lun Gong media published several news about this topic. It also was reported or cited by the other mainstream media.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking much hot water can prevent getting COVID-19.
Explanation: There has been no information nor evidence to suggest that drinking hot water has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Nan-shan Zhong said there is no vegetarian getting COVID-19.
Explanation: Nan-shan Zhong hasn't had such a comment. There is no evidence to support this claim, either.

What did you fact-check?: Cloud and rain from Wuhan brought the virus to Taiwan.
Explanation: COVID-19 spreads from person to person through small droplets from the nose or mouth which are spread when a person with COVID-19 coughs or exhales. Plus, coronavirus can't survive in clouds.

What did you fact-check?: This is a video of the late Chinese doctor Li-wen Liang's wedding party
Explanation: The video is about the wedding of a Taiwanese couple filmed in Taiwan.

What did you fact-check?: Dr. Chao Chien Kuo from Wuhan Central hospital said: drinking alcohol can prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: Dr. Chao Chien Kuo had had such a comment, but it was a joke in his private chat group, not an official recommendation. There is no evidence that drinking alcohol can prevent or treat COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Having 14 face masks is enough. You can reuse them every 14 days since the incubation period is 14 days.
Explanation: 14 days of incubation doesn't mean that the coronavirus can be alive for 14 days. People should not reuse single-use-mask.

What did you fact-check?: This is Dr. Li-wen Liang's funeral ceremony.
Explanation: Dr. Li died on Feb. 7., 2020. The video was uploaded on Nov. 19. 2018.

What did you fact-check?: The amount of ACE2 East Asian people have is 4-5 times more than non-East-Asians. That is why they get infected easily.
Explanation: The claim quoted a 2005 study regarding SARS, not COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: TV news said: Ketamine can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence that Ketamine can prevent or treat COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Many corpses from South Taiwan were sent to Taichung to burn. Taiwan has serious communuity infection.
Explanation: The number of cremation in Taiwan hasn't increased significantly since the COVID-19 outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Taiwanese manufacturing is awesome. One machine can produce 2.5 million face masks per day.
Explanation: According to the Taiwanese Economy Ministry, each production line of face mask produces around 100,000 masks per day. The claimed video is miscaptioned as well.

What did you fact-check?: It is a weird and unusual year. An ice tunami occurred on Xingkai Lake in Heilongjiang.
Explanation: The video of the ice tsunami was filmed at River Yenisey in Dudinka, Russia, in June 2019. Not in China.

What did you fact-check?: An armored vehicle was so full of corpses so that it slipped off a trailer.
Explanation: It is a picture of an armored vehicle accident in Taichung. It has been miscaptioned.

What did you fact-check?: The DPP (Democratic Progressive Party) politician Wang Shijian said that Taiwan has more than 500 confirmed cases.
Explanation: The DPP councilor Wang Shijian has denied making such a statement. As to Feb. 25., 2020, Taiwan has 31 confirmed cases, one death toll

What did you fact-check?: Many corposes floated in the river in Tainan, Southern city in Taiwan.
Explanation: They are stage photos from Korean movies "Deranged" and "Train To Busan".

What did you fact-check?: "DDP (Democratic Progressive Party) legislator Kao Chia-yu gave my mom two boxed of face mask since DDP has plenty and said that the outbreak is out of control."
Explanation: Legislator Kao denied making such a comment. There are several factual inaccuracies in the claim.

What did you fact-check?: My son, who works as a public servant in the Central government, got one box of face mask while the public is restricted to two per week.
Explanation: All public officials of the central government whose duty are not related to disease control are not allowed to apply for official face masks.

What did you fact-check?: Singapore government said the confirmed case no. 12 is a prostitute. As a result, many of her clients are under quarantine.
Explanation: According to the Singapore health ministry, case no. 12 showed symptoms during the family trip in Singapore. The department hasn't released the occupation of case no. 12.

What did you fact-check?: Honduras's first confirmed case has traveled to Taiwan earlier, which means there is a severe community transmission in Taiwan.
Explanation: As to Feb. 27., 2020, Honduras had zero confirmed case of COVID-19. A Taiwanese traveler had once suspected infection, but she has tested negative afterward.

What did you fact-check?: Taiwan has severe community transmission. Many people died.
Explanation: As to Feb. 27, there is no evidence indicating the Taiwan government has hidden real COVID-19 figures or information. The Taiwan Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) has a daily press conference to update the latest confirmed case number and has been considered reasonably transparent.

What did you fact-check?: The outbreak in Taiwan is out of control. President Tsai ordered to burn a corpse in front of the presidential office.
Explanation: It's a picture of a self-immolation incident in 2015 in front of the presidential office.

What did you fact-check?: Taiwanese president and the former president were infected. The former president died.
Explanation: The imagines of screenshots of news outlets and official documents are either doctored or forged. As to the date, the claim appeared online, President Tsai had a public speech at 228 memorial event.

What did you fact-check?: Zhong Nanshan's tip to rinse the mouth with salty water to prevent 2019n-Cov.
Explanation: Nan-shan Zhong hasn't had such a comment. There is no evidence that rinsing the mouth with slaty water can prevent COVID-19, either.

What did you fact-check?: Pope Francis and two of his aides have infected with COVID-19.
Explanation: The Vatican and the embassy said the pope recently fell ill with a common cold.

What did you fact-check?: Japanese Asahi Shimbun TV: USA caught COVID-19 before Wuhan, according to American CDC
Explanation: The original news clip suggested that there could be some COVID-19 cases being misdiagnosing with flu in the USA. But it didn't mention that the COVID-19 is originated in the USA.

What did you fact-check?: A study published by two Chinese research institutions suggested that human semen can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: The screenshot of the report circulated online was digitally manipulated. The original report suggested another medicine could be the cure, not human semen.

What did you fact-check?: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi: China has no faith, no election, and no freedom. China has only GDP but is losing it. Besides, nothing left in this country but violence and lies.
Explanation: According to Narendra Modi's official social media account and Indian media, Modi didn't make such a statement.

What did you fact-check?: There is an anti-Chinese protest in Italy due to COVID-19.
Explanation: The demonstration was to an anti-Fascist event to commemorate the victim of racism, Valerio Verbano. It was filmed on Feb. 22 in Rome.

What did you fact-check?: One prostitute caught COVID-19. Her 86 clients have been quarantined in the brothel in Spain.
Explanation: The claim initially came from a fictional content outlet. Spanish government and mainstream media didn't release such a statement.

What did you fact-check?: Pier Luigi Bersani: None of the confirmed cases are related to China. coronavirus might have occured in Italy before China.
Explanation: In the interview, Bersani didn't say that the virus is originated from Italy. In contrast, he emphasized that the virus is from China. His point is to bring up the assumption that the virus came to Italy prior to the time WHO declared the emergency.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus stays in throat for four days before arriving lungs. Gargling with salt water or vinegar kills coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no evidence that rinsing the mouth with slaty water or vinegr can prevent COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: A magic remedy to prevent COVID-19: mix brown sugar, ginger, garlic, and Chinese leek, boil them and drink it.
Explanation: There is no evidence that the recipe can prevent or cure COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Remedy recipe: (1) boil tea with Bitter melon. (2) Lemon juice with salt or Chinese Mesona
Explanation: There is no evidence that the recipe can prevent or cure COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows how American soldiers spread coronavirus during 7th CISM Military World Game in Wuhan.
Explanation: The video happened in Bruxelles on march. It is not happened in Wuhan or Taipei.

What did you fact-check?: Italians played the Chinese national anthem to thank China. People yelled "Grazie Cina".
Explanation: It's a video of Italian expressing gratitude to medical staff. The soundtrack of "Grazie Cina" and the Chinese national anthem was edited into the original video

What did you fact-check?: The spokesman of Chinese Foreign Ministry Zhao Lijian: American CDC admitted that COVID-19 patients were misdiagnosed as flu. US Army is responsible for the outbreak in Wuhan.
Explanation: China's Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian tweeted and commanded.

What did you fact-check?: Academia Sinica, Taiwan research institute developed antibodies for rapid testing as China representative of WHO took the credit.
Explanation: A Facebook page and YouTuber conducted this fake news. They tend to produce falsehoods against China.

What did you fact-check?: A fighter aircraft crashed in Tenjin, China. It failed to defect from China
Explanation: The video was an other inccident.

What did you fact-check?: Tens of thousand Korean asked for expelling Chinese. The anti-Chinese bandwagon swept across the world.
Explanation: It is the video of a rally to pressure the Korean president to resign on Feb. 22., not an anti-Chinese protest.

What did you fact-check?: American CDC admitted that coronavirus originated in the USA. Many COVID-19 patients were misdiagnosed as coronavirus.
Explanation: It is another piece of false information based on the unfounded claim that the coronavirus came from the United States.

What did you fact-check?: Water company: more chlorine has been added to Tap water to prevent coronavirus. Let the water rest for two hours before using it.
Explanation: Water company didn't release any statement like this. They didn't add additional anti-coronavirus chemicals.

What did you fact-check?: Councilor Pen White-Chung said that coronavirus is from the USA based on a Chinese academic study.
Explanation: It is another piece of false information based on the unfounded claim that the coronavirus came from the United States. This one is more subtle and shared by China officails.

What did you fact-check?: Trump admitted the flu cases in the USA are actually infected with the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is a clip of Trump's speech, but the subtitle and caption are false.

What did you fact-check?: The Minister of Defense of Japan posted a tweet to thank Taiwan for donating 500,000 face masks.
Explanation: It is a fake tweet.

What did you fact-check?: Is the Corona Virus Really Relating to Chinese Treatment of Uighur Muslims?
Explanation: The claim that the emergence of the Corona 2019 virus is related to Chinese treatment of Uighur Muslims is a misleading claim. There is no link at all between the emergence of the Corona virus with how China treats Muslim Uighurs. The spread of the Corona virus has become a global health challenge after the advent of SARS in 2002 and MERS in 2013.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese panic video over Corona Virus.
Explanation: The video shows that Yulin residents working in Guangdong returned to their hometown to celebrate the spring festival.

What did you fact-check?: Corona Virus Has Been Discovered Since 2012 by Ali Mohamed Zaki?
Explanation: The Corona virus discovered by Zaki is the MERS-CoV type, not the 2019-nCoV type. The Corona 2019-nCoV virus was first reported in Wuhan, China, not in Saudi Arabia.

What did you fact-check?: Corona Virus Can be Transmitted Through Free Fire Game and Xiaomi Mobile Phones?
Explanation: The 2019-nCoV virus cannot be transmitted through inanimate matter. To survive, the virus needs a host or cell that is also still alive.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese President Visits Mosque and Prayers for Corona Virus Outbreak?
Explanation: The video was taken in 2016, before the Corona virus was first reported in Wuhan in December 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Can Dettol Cleaners Kill the Corona Virus?
Explanation: Corona virus in question is a type of Corona virus MERS-CoV, SARS-CoV, and Human Coronavirus that refers to the common cold

What did you fact-check?: Chinese citizens join Muslim prayers because of fear of coronavirus?
Explanation: The video was taken during Eid prayer at the Yiwu Mosque, China, in June 2019, before the Wuhan Corona virus outbreak occurred.

What did you fact-check?: The people in this video show the coronavirus patients in China?
Explanation: The video of initiation activities at a secondary school in South Africa.

What did you fact-check?: Was Corona Antivirus Discovered by Israeli and Chinese Doctors?
Explanation: Remdesivir as novel Coronavirus antivirus is being carried out in collaboration with various institutions, not related to specific ethnicity or religion.

What did you fact-check?: This Burned Building Is a Place of Corona Virus Patient Isolation
Explanation: The burning building was an apartment in California Park, Yubei District, Chongqing City on January 1, 2020, not a hotel where COVID-19 patients were isolated.

What did you fact-check?: Spices can ward off Corona Virus
Explanation: Spices can increase endurance but there is no evidence that they can prevent and cure corona virus.

What did you fact-check?: Can garlic cure patients infected with the coronavirus?
Explanation: There has been no research or evidence that garlic can cure patients infected with the Corona virus.

What did you fact-check?: Prevent coronavirus by drinking warm water.
Explanation: The message did not come from the Indonesian Ministry of Health. And there is no research that supports that drinking warm water can prevent transmission of the virus.

What did you fact-check?: Death toll in Wuhan due to coronavirus reaches 10 thousand people?
Explanation: Death toll from the 2019-nCoV virus in China reached 132 people at the time of publication.

What did you fact-check?: Wuhan Corona Virus crosses from the Bat Virus and the Pig Virus?
Explanation: The current analysis indicate that there is no pig element in the virus. The Wuhan Corona virus originated mostly from SARS and bats, not from pigs.

What did you fact-check?: The video is claimed as the Wuhan market, China
Explanation: The wildlife market in the video is not the Wuhan Market in China, but the Langowan Market in Indonesia.

What did you fact-check?: People lying on the streets claimed to be victims of the coronavirus in China
Explanation: The photo is an art project created in Frankfurt, Germany, on March 24, 2014 to commemorate the victims of one of the Nazi concentration camps, Katzbach.

What did you fact-check?: There are 5 Corona Virus Suspect Patients in Indonesia, one of whom died.
Explanation: Video of a simulation activity of handling the Wuhan Corona virus at RSUP Dr. Kariadi, Semarang on January 30, 2020 ago.

What did you fact-check?: Corona Virus Victim Secretly Cremated.
Explanation: The photo of the pile of boxes at Tianhe International Airport in Wuhan contains protective clothing bought by the Zall Foundation to help control the Coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Corona Virus Can be Transmitted Through Sweat of Chinese Canned Food Factory Workers
Explanation: Transmission of the Corona Wuhan virus is only possible through close unprotected contact with sufferers, through snot or saliva splashes when sneezing and coughing.

What did you fact-check?: There are 40 thousand Chinese foreign workers in Morowali that are quarantined with Corona Virus?
Explanation: There are only 5,390 foreign workers employed at the company.

What did you fact-check?: WHO Calls for Isolation of China due to the Corona Virus?
Explanation: WHO states that they do not recommend restrictions on travel or trade with China.

What did you fact-check?: Is this the Biohazard Container Discovery Photo at the American Consulate General in Wuhan?
Explanation: No news was found from the Xinhua news agency or other media related to the findings of the biohazard container.

What did you fact-check?: Is Thailand Successfully Cure Corona Virus Patients with Marijuana?
Explanation: Antiflu and anti-HIV drugs used by doctors in Thailand to treat patients with the coronavirus do not contain cannabis.

What did you fact-check?: Is Chinese Government Requests Court Permission to Kill 20 Thousand Corona Virus Patients?
Explanation: There is no credible source that states this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Are Chinese Really Converting Islam to Avoid Corona Virus?
Explanation: The video is a religious activity carried out by ICDO in the Philippines which circulated on the internet before the Corona virus was first reported in December 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Is It Really the Video of Crow Attack and Jumbo Mosquito in China when Corona Virus Plague?
Explanation: The video is edited by combining several different videos and images.

What did you fact-check?: Really Chinese Citizens Cram For Friday Prayer After Corona Virus Plague?
Explanation: The video is a video of Chinese citizens carrying out Friday prayers taken in 2016, before the Corona virus was first reported in December 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Is It Really That Mosques Across China Reopened After Corona Virus Plague?
Explanation: a video of worship activities in the Dongguan Mosque, China. However, no news was found that the mosque was ever closed or reopened.

What did you fact-check?: Is Jackie Chan really quarantined because of Corona Virus?
Explanation: Jackie Chan has stated that he was not quarantined.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus can be transmitted through imported goods
Explanation: The virus cannot be outside the human body for a long time.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus dies in temperatures 26-27 degrees and when exposed to sunlight?
Explanation: None of the studies that mention the Coronavirus linked with COVID-19 can die in temperatures 26-27 degrees Celsius and when exposed to sunlight.

What did you fact-check?: Lonely Ka'bah from Tawaf after Saudi Arabia makes policy on Corona Virus?
Explanation: Activities around the Ka'bah located in the Grand Mosque, Mecca, proceed as usual at time of publication.

What did you fact-check?: Masks from Wet Wipes Effectively Prevents Corona Virus Transmission
Explanation: Wet tissue material makes dust, dirt and bacteria more easily stick.

What did you fact-check?: Consumption of Pig Causes Corona COVID-19 Virus Entry into Indonesia
Explanation: Covid-19 spreads in Indonesia because there are Indonesian citizens who have contact with foreign citizens who have previously been exposed to the Corona 2019 virus. So far, research results show that pigs only carry one virus that can be transmitted to humans, namely the H1N1 virus that causes swine flu.

What did you fact-check?: Prince of the United Arab Emirates Positive Infected Corona Virus in Early March 2020
Explanation: The Prince of the United Arab Emirates, Mohamed bin Zayed, is still active and not quarantined. The Twitter account that first spread the false information has now been closed.

What did you fact-check?: Indonesia Only Prohibits Migrants from Iran, Italy, and South Korea and Allow the Entry of Chinese Citizens
Explanation: Restrictions on the entry of migrants from China have been done earlier by the government, namely on February 5, 2020. In addition to stopping flights to and from China, the government has also temporarily suspended the issuance of Visa and Arrival Visas for Chinese citizens.

What did you fact-check?: Is this COVID-19 Virus Prevention Information Really Originating from UNICEF?
Explanation: The post was not from UNICEF. UNICEF has denied this information circulating in a number of countries, including in Indonesia.

What did you fact-check?: Cow Urine and Feces Can Treat Corona Virus 2019
Explanation: Until now, there has been no health organization that states that there are drugs or vaccines to prevent and treat Covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese kill their pets due to epidemic anxiety.
Explanation: The photo of a dead dog was verified. Others not. There is no evidence that there is a massive pet killing in China.

What did you fact-check?: The photo shows the aid crew from Cuba to Italy.
Explanation: Cuba has sent aid to Italy but the photo is not new. Taken in 2015.

What did you fact-check?: Ibuprofen is not good for possible COVID-19 treatment.
Explanation: University of Vienna denied the research. The relation between Ibuprofen and Covid-19 is not clear yet.

What did you fact-check?: Grape vinegar is the antidote of the coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence the benefits of vinegat to fight with the disease. The virus is not poison, an antidote would not be useful at all.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus firstly appeared in June 2019.
Explanation: The virus was detected in Wuhan, China in late December, not in June 2019 according to Lancet paper, WHO and other sources.

What did you fact-check?: The studies initiated by the "Military Research Institute" transformed the form of virus in 2018.
Explanation: The claim that the virus was developed by a "military institute" is based on an article authored by Dan Hu, who works for Third Military Medical University in China. However, the article does not mention the experiments changed the genetics of the virus. Again, the examples used in the article are stored in the gene bank with a code and these codes are also included in the study. This allows scientists to work on the virus.

What did you fact-check?: The animals in the list in the photo were served at a meeting for 40 thousand people in China, and the virus spread after that day.
Explanation: The animal list, which presented with the prices in the photo, belongs to the list of animals sold in live animal markets in China. And there is no information regarding a meeting of 40 thousand people in this city.

What did you fact-check?: Turkish doctor allegedly found coronavirus vaccine.
Explanation: There is no doctor called "Tamer Yirmiüçoğlu." The doctor in the photo is gynecologist Op. Dr. Tamer Gültekin who became famous in 2016 with the vagina bleaching operations.

What did you fact-check?: 25 million infected and 40 thousand died in coronavirus epidemic.
Explanation: The figures in the claim can't be found in any official announcement.

What did you fact-check?: The virus is entirely different all the known virus forms. It activates all bacterias and other viruses in human body.
Explanation: The nCOV virus is genetically related with the other coronaviruses detected before. All infections can activate other infections in humans. In this epidemic only four case reported as secondary infections.

What did you fact-check?: The Simpsons predicted the epidemic in advance.
Explanation: Osaka flu came from Japan in the related Simpsons episode with a package, not from China.

What did you fact-check?: The movie Venom predicted the epidemic in advance.
Explanation: The movie is not based on an epidemic at all. The character is not infected after eating snake in a marketplace and attack people.

What did you fact-check?: China constructed an hospital for the epidemic in 48 hours.
Explanation: The construction started in 2018 and it can be seen on Baidu maps.

What did you fact-check?: A coronavirus case diagnosed in Atasehir hospital, Istanbul
Explanation: The announcement was put on the entrance of the emercency service just in case. But the Facebook post indicates the diagnosis. There is no diagnosed case at this date in Turkey.

What did you fact-check?: One case infects other 14.
Explanation: It's not clear that the girl in the video indicates R0. But, by now, the R0 value is quite lower than the claim according to WHO

What did you fact-check?: A case was confirmed in Istanbul Medical School Hospital.
Explanation: A patient was isolated in the hospital on inspection but not diagnosis. There is no confirmed case by now in Turkey.

What did you fact-check?: Gates Foundation was the real agent behind the epidemic.
Explanation: The simulation Gates Foundation funded was based on another corona virus in the same family.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a doctor falling down due to coronavirus disease.
Explanation: The video is old. The doctor in the video was on the floor because some of the patient relatives punched him on the face.

What did you fact-check?: The claim that a photo shows the infected people in China.
Explanation: The photo is taken for the commemoration of holocaust victims in Frankfurt in 2014.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows an infected baby with a doctor.
Explanation: Video uploaded on 14th of January. There was no reported case on that time. It does not fit the Covid-19 quarantina protocol.

What did you fact-check?: China seeks approval from the court to kill over 20 000 coronavirus patients.
Explanation: Source is not reliable and zero credible news platforms have published. There is no such a hearing in supreme court's schedule.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows coronavirus patients and doctors
Explanation: The original video is from South Africa, not China.

What did you fact-check?: SO2 map proves the massive human cremation in Wuhan.
Explanation: Calculations about the possible sulfur burning and certain degree of air pollution are not consistant.

What did you fact-check?: Massive live-pig burials after COVID-19 outbreak.
Explanation: The burial is not new. Chinese goverment decided to kill pigs after African swine fever in 2018.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese businessman Guo Wengui's multiple allegations on coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation:
- The outbreak was not a disaster in the mid of December. 
- The disease did not spread in US quickly after 18th of Feb. 
- Death rate is being updated day by day; not always same. 
- Wuhan's hospital capacity rise doesn't show the real number of infected. 
- Isolation centers in Wuhan are not concentration camps.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows the suspected infected people in eastern Turkey, Van.
Explanation: Video is not new. There is no proved Covid-19 case in Turkey by now.

What did you fact-check?: Author Dean Koontz foresaw the outbreak in his book.
Explanation: There is nothing common between the fictional virus in the book and current Covid-19 rather than Wuhan.

What did you fact-check?: Vaccine for covid-19 has been found.
Explanation: Chinese ambrassador to Russia announced that they are making progress. No vaccine for Covid-19 yet.

What did you fact-check?: Multiple allegations around how coronavirus was produced by China.
Explanation: The alleged connection between tha spies is fictional. No scientific evidence shows the virus is produced as a bioweapon.

What did you fact-check?: Iranian clerics wearing masks after outbreak.
Explanation: The photo is old-dated and manipulated. It was taken in the funeral of Kasem Sulemani.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking water every 10 minutes can send the virus into stomach and kill it.
Explanation: Digestive system can not stop the respiratory system's work and the course of infection.

What did you fact-check?: The Pope has COVID-19.
Explanation: Vatican's press office announced that the Pope just has a common cold. He is continuing his schedule. If he had the virus, his age would make it difficult for him to do so.

What did you fact-check?: Turkish raki is prevents COVID-19.
Explanation: Clipping was doctored on online app. There is no evidence shows raki prevents the disease.

What did you fact-check?: Videograph shows COVID-19 is more dangerous than former outbreaks.
Explanation: The video is cut at the beginning and the end. The whole video shows covid-19 is not as dangerous as the former outbreaks, also other couses of death.

What did you fact-check?: Whatsapp message contains multiple health advises.
Explanation: The text message is based on the advices lacking scientific evidences. WHO advices does not include any of them.

What did you fact-check?: Turks are not gonna be infected by COVID-19 due to their genes.
Explanation: The distrubution of the ACE2 protein, possible Covid-19 receptor among nations is not clear. Referred antropologist was a Nazi and classified people by measuring the body parts; not by genetic analysis.

What did you fact-check?: A COVID-19 case has been diagnosed in Yedikule Hospital, Istanbul.
Explanation: The lab report is old-dated and shows other mild coronaviruses were found in the case

What did you fact-check?: Quarantine video allegedly from different cities in Turkey.
Explanation: The video is from Sakarya, not Istanbul and the patient was isolated on inspection, not diagnosis. No case in Turkey so far.

What did you fact-check?: A COVID-19 case has been diagnosed in Umraniye Hospital, Istanbul.
Explanation: There is no confirmed case in the hospital. Tests were negative. No case in Turkey so far.

What did you fact-check?: 37 died in a day in NY (March 10).
Explanation: Translation was not correct. 37 new cases found in NY, not died.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 medicine was found in Ghana.
Explanation: The herbal product image was manipulated.

What did you fact-check?: The map shows the first covid-19 case diagnosed in Kayseri, Turkey.
Explanation: The Johns Hopkins map shows the geographical centers of the countries, not the places in which case are diagnosed. Metadata shows the details.

What did you fact-check?: UNICEF published health advices on COVID-19.
Explanation: UNICEF did not publish the text. The medical advices in the text are not scientific-based.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese people prayed with Muslims due to fear of COVID-19.
Explanation: The video is shared in 2019, June, before the outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Asterix comics in 1981 mentioned coronavirus, French people knew the outbreak in advance.
Explanation: Coronaviruses had been known for a while and are not only referring to Covid-19. 1981 Asterix comic books did not mention coronavirus. The issue from 2017 did refer to coronavirus, but it has nothing to do with the current outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: A Turkish citizen in Yozgat ate yogurt and soap together to get rid of the virus.
Explanation: The news first published in an parody site. There is no such a guy in Yozgat nor the doctors mentioned.

What did you fact-check?: Turkish President Erdoğan said that curfew is to declare due to COVID-19.
Explanation: The clipping of the Hurriyet newspaper is manipulated. President Erdoğan's speech did not cover such a measure.

What did you fact-check?: Two COVID-19 patients were executed in North Korea.
Explanation: Content belongs to a parody account. There is no declared Covid-19 case in North Korea.

What did you fact-check?: Italian airforce's airshow to motivate the public under quarantine.
Explanation: The video is shared in 2019, september, before the outbreak. The plains do not belong to Italian army.

What did you fact-check?: Turkish Ministry of Health issued a document shows radical measures against COVID-19.
Explanation: The document is fake and the signature in the document belongs to famous boxer Vitali Klitschko.

What did you fact-check?: Women's inhouse gatherings are banned due to the outbreak.
Explanation: The ministry of family did not issue an order bans women's gatherings.

What did you fact-check?: New virus stays at the throat level for four days.
Explanation: The virus attaches human cells and does not wait to replicate itself. It is not possible to push the virus into stomach by drinking water.

What did you fact-check?: Cristiano Ronaldo donated his hotel to be turned into an hospital.
Explanation: Ronaldo did not announce this and his partners denied.

What did you fact-check?: New coronavirus is being spread via Coca-Cola.
Explanation: No evidence shows the virus transmission via food. Coca-Cola products are inspected.

What did you fact-check?: New coronavirus can survive 9 days on the road; you should keep your shoes out, a doctor from Milan says.
Explanation: No Milanese doctor says that. No evidence shows the exact survival time of the virus on the road.

What did you fact-check?: A dog in Hong Kong died of COVID-19.
Explanation: Vets shared the test results with Teyit. Dog's tests were negative for Covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a balcony party in the Turkish capital Ankara due to quarantine.
Explanation: The video is originally from Spain and manipulated with a Turkish song on top of it.

What did you fact-check?: Korean series My Secret Terrius predicted the outbreak in advance.
Explanation: The series was about an international conspiracy, not a outbreak. The fictional virus was quite different from the current one.

What did you fact-check?: Dr. Yavuz Dizdar's multiple allegations around the COVID-19.
Explanation: Dr. Dizdar is an oncologist, not an expert in the field. The allegations are based on the interpretation, not scientific evidence.

What did you fact-check?: Sitting in the sunlight will help cure coronavirus.
Who said/posted it?: Minister of State, Health, Ashwini Choubey
Explanation: The answer to this statement, according to doctors, is more than just true or false. Professor Ramanan Laxminarayan, Director of Centre for Disease Dynamics, Economics and Policy (CDDEP) said that, “We do not know how heat will affect this coronavirus as of yet. Usually, respiratory pathogens disappear in the summer and in the heat, but we have seen many cases in tropical countries too.”

What did you fact-check?: Russia has allegedly unleashed over 500 lions in order to ensure that people stay inside their houses.
Explanation: The bulletin has been created using a template called 'Break your own news'. Secondly, the image of the lion dates back to 2016 and was taken in South Africa’s Johannesburg

What did you fact-check?: An audio clip suggests that the WHO has advised a lockdown.
Explanation: A source in WHO confirmed that the organisation has not put out any such information as heard in the viral audio clip.

What did you fact-check?: The Ethiopian Airlines flight from Italy this evening to Addis Ababa airport. Most of the passengers are infected with the virus, and there is no strength except in God.
Explanation: The visuals actually pertain to a mock rescue drill that took place at Blaise Diagne Airport near the town of Diass, Senegal. The incident dates back to 28 November 2019 and was a simple simulation aimed at evaluating the capacity to respond to various crises that may arise during airport operations.

What did you fact-check?: Saddam Hussein in 90s talking about coronavirus to his cabinet and army that America has threatened him to spread this virus if he doesn't follow their command.
Explanation: The viral video is a doctored version of the original video shared by Associated Press in 2015. The audios of both the videos are different not only in terms of their content but voice as well. In the original AP video, Saddam Hussein does not mention the word ‘virus’ or ‘coronavirus.’

What did you fact-check?: Worst affected countries for coronavirus are along the same latitude.
Explanation:
1. The fact that large countries cannot be represented by a single latitude is conveniently ignored.
2. Further, all of the aforementioned cities and countries are not situated along Latitude 40 degrees.

What did you fact-check?: Janta Curfew in India will help break the chain of transmission.
Explanation: The World Health Organisation has maintained that it is not certain how long the virus that causes COVID-19 survives on surfaces, but it seems to behave like other coronaviruses.

What did you fact-check?: Can garlic water cure coronavirus?
Explanation: In the absence of any study or concrete proof, it is hard to claim that garlic water or any such home remedy can help cure coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Does chicken cause coronavirus.
Explanation: There has been no official confirmation of a link between chicken and nCov - and no source for nCov has been found as yet. However, WHO has said that they are looking into animal sources to find the origin but there is no clarity on what the animal is.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus was created in a lab in Wuhan.
Explanation: No scientific evidence exists to assert that the coronavirus was created in a lab. According to the WHO, “Both Chinese and external expert groups are working in trying to identify the animal source of this new virus.”

What did you fact-check?: Cow dung and cow urine can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Unicef recommandations: coronavirus is large in size where the cell diameter is 400-500 micro and for this reason any mask prevents its entry so there is no need to use pharmacists to trade muzzles. The virus does not settle in the air but is grounded, so it is not transmitted by air.
Explanation: The message is miselading and has the potential to cause fear amid the outbreak of coronavirus in India.

What did you fact-check?: Can weed (cannabis) cure coronavirus.
Explanation: In the absence of any evidence, the claim is found to be misleading.

What did you fact-check?: Tencent claims that over 24,000 patients have died in China.
Explanation: We have only proved that the screenshots can be manipulated using HTML but whether the number is actually that much and the govt is hiding it is not known.

What did you fact-check?: Turmeric and lemon can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: Medical practitioners and even WHO has rubbished this claim and has said that there is no evidence to prove that turmeric and lemon can be used to cure coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Coronil drops can help cure coronavirus.
Explanation: Leading homeopaths say that very little is known about the composition of this medicine and it will be careless to recommend this medicine for coronavirus

What did you fact-check?: Chinese Prime Minister Offering Namaz Amid coronavirus Scare.
Explanation: The video is actually from July 2015 when the former Malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi visited Beijing’s Nan Xia Po Mosque and took part in Friday prayers, on his five-day trip to China.

What did you fact-check?: China is planning to kill coronavirus patients.
Explanation: A hoax website, which has been called out multiple times by various fact-checkers for spreading fake news, has published an article without any source of information to claim that China is planning to kill over 20,000 patients who have been infected by coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Central government has announced blanket holiday fro schools/colleges in 4 states in India.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Photographs of the Army in Dublin city centre show that the country is about to go into lockdown.
Explanation: The photographs show the Army setting up mobile testing centres in Dublin city centre, not preparing for the country to go into lockdown

What did you fact-check?: Police asked shops selling alcohol to restrict opening hours on St Patrick's Day to lower the risk of house parties where coronavirus could be spread.
Explanation: Police make an annual request of shops not to sell alcohol before 4pm on St Patrick's Day - but it has nothing to do with coronavirus

What did you fact-check?: Drinking water every 15 minutes will protect you from getting coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no medical evidence to support the idea that drinking water every 15 minutes will help protect you from coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: You can check for coronavirus by holding your breath for 10 seconds.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support the claim that holding your breath for several seconds is an effective way to test for coronavirus

What did you fact-check?: The health service in Ireland is asking people to stockpile food.
Explanation: The claim was untrue. The health service is not urging people to stockpile food - in fact, the opposite is true - and the supply chains in Ireland remain robust

What did you fact-check?: Ireland is going into a 'Status Red' lockdown with the military patrolling the streets.
Explanation: The claim was untrue. Ireland has not gone into lockdown

What did you fact-check?: Ireland is going to go into a full lockdown.
Explanation: Despite two messages which were widely shared on WhatsApp, the country did not go into a full military lockdown with the army patrolling the streets. Shops have not been restricted in their opening hours and public transport has not been cancelled.

What did you fact-check?: Four young people have been hospitalised with coronavirus which has been exacerbated by the use of ibuprofen.
Explanation: The message, which was widely shared, had no basis in fact. It did not match the description of any patients in the hospital in question, and it misrepresented the dangers of ibuprofen

What did you fact-check?: Hospitals are advising people to wear gloves at petrol pumps.
Explanation: The hospital named in the message confirmed that it did not issue this advice, and health authorities, including the Chief Medical Officer, said that the public is not being advised to do this.

What did you fact-check?: Somebody took patent on coronavirus and vaccine in 2004
Who said/posted it?: Several - fx the Danish facebookpage "The Truth"
Explanation: The claim has been fact checked by several IFCN-members who all have reached the same conclusion. The mentioned patent concerns SARS.

What did you fact-check?: YouTube channel published a radio-show-style report with false headline saying novel coronavirus is in the Philippines
Explanation: Kabisnes’s false and clickbait headline does not reflect its content. In the video’s first 10 seconds, the show host reads the phrase “Coronavirus, nasa Pilipinas na (Corona virus, already in the Philippines)” then proceeds to say that it was a claim circulating on social media, currently being debunked by Malacanang and DOH.

What did you fact-check?: A FB post giving information and safety precautions about coronaviruses is misleading readers by falsely claiming in its premise that a positive case of the 2019 novel coronavirus was “confirmed” to be found in Cebu province.
Explanation: The Department of Health announced on Jan. 28 there remains to be no positive case of the 2019 nCoV in the country, only that there are 27 people under investigation for suspected infection.

What did you fact-check?: 2019-nCoV is officially found in bats.
Explanation: The content of both The Daily Mail and Verter News did not say bats were “officially” the source of the 2019-nCoV, only that they were “likely” to be its source.

What did you fact-check?: A FB user published a collage of tweets claiming novel coronavirus has reached Cebu province and Boracay Island, which are popular tourists destinations.
Explanation: There is no confirmed positive case of the newly-detected 2019 nCoV in the Philippines at this time. This was clarified by Health Secretary Francisco Duque III in a Jan. 27 interview with CNN Philippines. He emphasized this in a separate press conference in Malacanang, where he also reported that the five-year-old boy suspected of having the disease tested negative.

What did you fact-check?: The "proper" way of wearing a surgical mask is blue side out if you are sick and white side out if you do not want to be infected by the virus.
Who said/posted it?: City of Manila Vice Mayor Honey Lacuna
Explanation: The World Health Organization, the Philippine Red Cross, the country's Department of Health, San Francisco’s Department of Public Health: Disease Prevention and Control, and the Hong Kong government are all one in saying there is only one way to wear surgical masks: have the blue color on the outside and the white on the inside.

What did you fact-check?: Alibaba Group founder Jack Ma gave US$5 million to a Filipino student who developed a vaccince for novel coronavirus.
Explanation: No vaccine has been developed to stop the recently discovered virus. There are also no news reports saying Jack Ma made a special separate donation to a Filipino student in China Medical University.

What did you fact-check?: A video of domesticated and exotic animals are being sold in a wet market in "Wuhan, China".
Explanation: The video currently being spread on social media is a composite of two different clips, one of Langowan Traditional Market and the other of Tomohon Traditional Market, both in Indonesia.

What did you fact-check?: Japan has sent a 1000-man medical team to Wuhan.
Explanation: The image circulating on social media is over 11 years old, taken on May 20, 2008, of a 22-member medical team at Japan’s Narita International Airport before flying to Chengdu city in China, then been hit by an earthquake.

What did you fact-check?: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte orders state hospital to accept COVID-19 patients from Wuhan.
Explanation: Duterte’s speeches prior to the publication of City News’ false report have made no mention of PGH being used for Chinese patients with COVID-19. Neither have legitimate news media organizations reported on this.

What did you fact-check?: Upon approval from Supreme People's Court, China will kill 20,000 patients with novel coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no such case being tried at the Supreme People’s Court of China. The high court’s record of scheduled hearings on its official website does not show that it was set to decide on such a case on Feb. 7, and neither is there a record of it on the resolved cases tab and press releases.

What did you fact-check?: Police in China have started killing COVID-19 patients, killing 25,000 so far.
Explanation: None of the four clips spliced together shows cops “shooting” COVID-19 patients. In fact, one of the clips is actually of a road crash. Another one features not the sound of gunshots, but the explosion of Lunar New Year Fireworks in the background.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 came from Chinese people eating human babies, which they supposedly do to get good skin.
Who said/posted it?: Netizen's post in an FB group
Explanation: The netizen’s claim about COVID-19 coming from eating babies is false and baseless. The photos used are also all over a decade old, some of which show a Chinese man "eating babies" as a protest art in 2000.

What did you fact-check?: The video shown shows effects of coronavirus and avoid icecream, cold drinks for 90 days.
Explanation: Video shown in the viral post showing a person removing larvae from the lips using a pair of tweezers is old and unrelated to coronavirus. The claim in the viral post is also refuted by medical professionals.

What did you fact-check?: Post On coronavirus Outbreak Attributed To Health Ministry Advisory.
Explanation: The viral notification post on Coronavirus outbreak is falsely attributed to Health Ministry.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus Discovered In Broilers Chicken.
Explanation: Unrelated images of ailing chicken shared with the claim that coronavirus has been discovered in broilers chicken. The viral post is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Garlic Water Can Cure Novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Garlic is a healthy food that may have some antimicrobial properties. However, there is no evidence from the current outbreak that eating garlic has protected people from the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: China Seeks Court’s Approval To Kill 20000 coronavirus Patients.
Explanation: Post claiming China seeks court’s approval to kill 20000 coronavirus patients is fake.

What did you fact-check?: This image is related to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: This image has nothing to do with coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus found in broiler chicken.
Explanation: Post claiming coronavirus found in broiler chicken is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Image of Pakistani Prime minister Imran Khan and Chinese president Xi Jinping in which Imran Khan is wearing mask.
Explanation: Edited image of Imran Khan and Xi Jimping viral with wrong claim.

What did you fact-check?: China Seeks Court’s Approval To Kill 20000 coronavirus Patients.
Explanation: Post claiming China seeks court’s approval to kill 20000 coronavirus patients is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Gargling With Warm Salt Water Can Save From coronavirus.
Explanation: Post claiming gargling with warm salt water can save from coronavirus is fake as per health organizations and experts.

What did you fact-check?: Sanitizer manufacturer Dettol knew about 2019 Novel coronavirus before it was actually reported.
Explanation: The label of Dettol mentioning that it kills coronavirus is not the recent strain of coronavirus. They have not tested its products for the recent noval coronavirus. Misleading post is getting viral.

What did you fact-check?: Clorox Already Knew About coronavirus And coronavirus Isn’t New Virus.
Explanation: The post claiming that the new coronavirus was known beforehand as Clorox label shows that it kills human coronavirus’ is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: Weed kills coronavirus.
Explanation: Weed doesn’t kill coronavirus. Fake post getting viral.

What did you fact-check?: Chicken Infected From coronavirus Found In Bangalore.
Explanation: Post claiming chicken infected from coronavirus found in Bangalore is fake. The image is old and is not related to 2019 novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Cocaine kills coronavirus.
Explanation: Post claiming cocaine kills coronavirus is fake.

What did you fact-check?: This coronavirus-infected patient reached to Dr. Vinod Kumar but he wasn’t given the treatment. He was later referred to Bhagalpur. It further states that one should avoid meat and fish for 3 months and wear mask to protect yourself from coronavirus.
Explanation: The post claiming that coronavirus infected patient reached Bihar and is not given treatment is fake. Health authorities dismiss the hoax report. Further, WHO has also not recommended to avoid fish and meat. It recommended thoroughly cooking meat and eggs. Wearing mask is, however, advisable.

What did you fact-check?: WHO Has Issued Advisory Against Buying Of Holi Colors From coronavirus-Hit China.
Explanation: WHO hasn’t issued advisory against buying of Holi colors from Coronavirus-hit China. The viral post is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Man Critical With Novel coronavirus In Barhalganj, India.
Explanation: There is no confirmed case of the novel coronavirus in Barhalganj, a town in Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh. And the man did not get infected with coronavirus in Barhalganj by consuming chicken. The viral post is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Alcohol kills coronavirus
Explanation: Post claiming alcohol kills coronavirus is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Consuming Large Doses Of Vitamin C Can Stop The Spread Of coronavirus.
Explanation: Consuming large doses of Vitamin C cannot stop the spread of coronavirus. there is no evidence that the spread of coronavirus can be stopped by consuming large doses of Vitamin C.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus dies at a temperature above 26 – 27 degrees Celcius as per UNICEF.
Explanation: The viral message on novel coronavirus is NOT issued by UNICEF.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 Breeds Rapidly In Toilet Paper.
Explanation: Post claiming COVID-19 breeds rapidly in toilet paper is fake. The post is taken from an unauthentic website.

What did you fact-check?: Turmeric And Lemon Help Fight Against coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no evidence to prove that turmeric and lemon help fight against coronavirus. The viral post is fake.

What did you fact-check?: WHO Has Issued Advisory Against Buying Of Holi Colors From coronavirus-Hit China
Explanation: WHO hasn’t issued advisory against buying of Holi colors from Coronavirus-hit China. The viral post is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus patient arrested in Punjab
Explanation: Mock drill video of Mansa, Punjab viral with false claim

What did you fact-check?: In Ukrainian media, it was written about a confirmed case of a Chinese coronovirus strain.
Explanation: We have described that this is not the case and indicated that there are several strains.

What did you fact-check?: An Image is being shared on social media claiming; this italian doctor couple in the picture worked day and night and saved the lives of 134 patients, but on the eighth day, they caught coronavirus and died after an hour.
Explanation: The couple in the picture is not Italian but a couple from Spain. The photograph was taken at Barcelona Airport on March 12, 2020.

What did you fact-check?: Riots in London due to the unavailability of food items. The United Kingdom will be locked down by tonight. Army soldiers take to the UK streets.
Explanation: The video is not related to Coronavirus but with London riots that happened in 2011. The 2011 England riots, more widely known as the London Riots, were a series of riots between 6 and 11 August 2011, when thousands of people rioted in cities and towns across England, saw looting, arson, and mass deployment of police, and resulted in the deaths of five people.

What did you fact-check?: A WhatsApp forward has gone viral which claimed that a vaccine for coronavirus has been discovered. The viral forward also claims that the treatment for coronavirus is mentioned in India's Intermediate Zoology book. The viral forward reads, “It is not a new disease as it is already mentioned in the Intermediate zoology book along with its treatment. It happens sometimes that many great scientists and doctors do not focus on lesser-known books as they are mostly busy with famous books. Book name: Zoology, Writer: Dr. Ramesh Gupta, Page No. 1072.) Friends, this is not fake news so I request you to kindly share it maximum so all coronavirus patients are treated in time.”
Explanation: The virus being talked about in the viral claim is not the novel coronavirus(Covid-19) but SARS. WHO has clearly negated the discovery of any vaccine that can cure Covid-19. In an answer to the question, “Are there any medicines or therapies that can prevent or cure COVID-19?”, the WHO replies, “While some western, traditional or home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of COVID-19, there is no evidence that current medicine can prevent or cure the disease.

What did you fact-check?: Russia has unleashed over 500 lions to ensure that people stay inside their homes amid the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: the image of a bulletin viral on social media has nothing to do with Russia or Russian President. The image is from South Africa’s Johannesburg, and the lion seen in the viral image was brought for film shooting by the production crew.

What did you fact-check?: A WhatsApp forward is doing the rounds claiming that the Covid-19 vaccine is ready and as announced by US President Donald Trump, it will be launched next Sunday. It also claims that the vaccine discovered by the US scientists can cure a Covid-19 infected patient within 3 hours. With the WhatsApp forward, the alleged image of the vaccine is also being shared.
A Video of Chinese People Fighting for Muslim Scriptures to Not Get Infected by Corona Virus?
Explanation: The video has been circulating since 2014, before the Corona Covid-19 virus was first reported in late December 2019. The video of Christians in China opening their Bibles for the first time

What did you fact-check?: Singapore checks the Saliva of Indonesian arrivals at Changi Airport
Explanation: The Covid-19 swab test is only intended for tourists who have symptoms such as fever or other respiratory ailments.

What did you fact-check?: Corona Virus Detection Can Be Done by Holding Your Breath 10 Seconds
Explanation: Whether someone is positive or not is infected with the Corona virus can only be known through laboratory tests. In addition, no health organization, such as the US CDC and WHO, and also the Ministry of Health have included fibrosis as a symptom of Covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking Alcohol Can Kill Corona Covid-19 Virus
Explanation: According to WHO, when the virus has entered a person's body, spraying alcohol or even drinking it will not be able to kill the virus.

What did you fact-check?: Cristiano Ronaldo Turns Hotel into Hospital for Corona
Explanation: The manager of the hotel owned by Ronaldo has denied the rumors and stated that the hotel was and will remain a hotel.

What did you fact-check?: Indonesian President Joko Widodo locked down 10 cities
Explanation: the Indonesian President Joko Widodo has not yet chosen the option to quarantine or lockdwon as a way to deal with the Corona Covid-19 virus pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: The People In This Video Are Falling Because Of Infection With Corona Virus
Explanation: The people in the three videos fainted due to other causes, such as epilepsy and fatigue. Two of the four videos also did not occur in Jakarta, but in Bali and Singapore.

What did you fact-check?: Novel The Eye of Darkness Predicts Corona as Biological Weapon from China
Explanation: There is only one similarity about the virus in this novel with the Corona Covid-19 virus, namely the name Wuhan, where the Corona Covid-19 virus was first reported in Wuhan, China. The rest, regarding the incubation period, death rates, and so on, is very different from the pandemic that is happening now.

What did you fact-check?: China recognizes Palestinian doctor as discoverer of Corona Covid-19 virus vaccine
Explanation: Not a single report was discovered about the discovery of the Corona vaccine by Palestinian doctors. Even the doctor who claimed to be the inventor of the vaccine, Manar Saadi Al-Sheenawi, was not found in the Google search engine. In addition, until now, the WHO has not announced the discovery of any vaccine that can treat Covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: The original form of the Corona Covid-19 virus after being enlarged 2,600 times
Explanation: The small creature in the photo is a weevil, a beetle that comes from the Curculionoidea family.

What did you fact-check?: The video of the American Army that Distributes Corona to China
Explanation: The man in the first video is a train passenger in Belgium who is drunk. While the man in the second video is a company manager in Hong Kong who intentionally made a parody video. The narrative that contains the conspiracy theory "the American army is the spreader of the Corona Covid-19 virus to China" comes from one Chinese official who has not been able to prove the truth.

What did you fact-check?: Poison Spray for Corona from Malaysia and Singapore by Air?
Explanation: Indonesian Minister of Communication and Information Johnny G. Plate, Malaysian Army, and Head of Batam City Health Office Didi Kusmaryadi have denied the rumors.

What did you fact-check?: Inhaling Water Into The Nose Can Prevent Corona Transmission
Explanation: Numerous studies show that water alone is not enough to kill the Corona virus.

What did you fact-check?: Vladimir Putin Released 800 Tigers and Lions for Forced Residents to Stay at Home
Explanation: Photos of the lion have been circulating on the internet since April 2016, long before the Corona COVID-19 virus first appeared in Wuhan, China, in December 2019. The lion in the photo is named Columbus, released on the streets of Johannesburg, South Africa, for the purpose of filmmaking.

What did you fact-check?: WHO Call Ibuprofen Drugs Can Make Corona Live Longer
Explanation: WHO does not mention that the ibuprofen drug can make the Corona COVID-19 virus live longer. In fact, WHO does not recommend against using ibuprofen based on information available so far. The reason, WHO did not find reports about the negative effects of ibuprofen on COVID-19 patients, beyond the known side effects that limit their use in certain populations. The WHO also did not find any clinical or population-based data published on the claim.

What did you fact-check?: Peeled Onions Can Suck Corona Virus
Explanation: The chain message is a modification of an old myth that developed in society that is not supported by scientific research.

What did you fact-check?: Videos of Passenger Plane from Italy to Ethiopia which are All Positive Corona
Explanation: The video is a video of a terrorist hostage-taking at the Blaise Diagne International Airport, Senegal, on November 28, 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Malaysia Dismiss Residents Outside the Home with Drones that Shoot Fireworks
Explanation: The events in the video are part of the action carried out by a Brazilian influencer, Lucas Albert. The video was uploaded on Instagram on July 14, 2019, before the Corona COVID-19 virus was first reported in Wuhan, China, in December 2019. Even in the original video, there was no Malay-speaking male voice asking people to disperse.

What did you fact-check?: Photo of Italian PM Giuseppe Conte who cried for regretting the late lockdown
Explanation: The photo is a photo of Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro who gave a speech during an evangelical service at the Planalto Palace on December 17, 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese Government Accuses Indonesia of Spreading Corona Covid-19 Virus
Explanation: In its official statement, the Shaanxi Health Commission, China, only announced that there was one case of Covid-19 in its territory which was an import from Indonesia. No sentence was found from the Shaanxi government accusing Indonesia of spreading the Corona virus in the statement.

What did you fact-check?: Doctor Li Wenliang and Hospital in China Suggest Drinking Tea for Corona Patients
Explanation: There is no evidence to suggest that doctor Li Wenliang examined the effects of chemicals in tea, such as methylxanthine, on Corona patients. Li Wenliang was an ophthalmologist, not a virus expert. In addition, an article from Zhejiang CDC that claims that drinking tea can help prevent Covid-19 has been removed.

What did you fact-check?: Former French Health minister rated chloroquine as a "poisonous substance"
Explanation: She wasn't the one who decided. It was the French Agency for drugs, based on a request of the laboratory that produces the drug.
The movie does not feature a pandemic of any sort. The WHO is never mentioned in the movie.
Blood donors don’t get a coronavirus test if they donate blood.
Older Americans and those with chronic conditions are advised to reconsider all travel plans to avoid COVID-19. The State Department is advising all citizens to reconsider travel abroad.

An infectious disease expert presenting to the American Hospital Association estimated there could be as many as 96 million cases of COVID-19 in the U.S. in a year. But there is no indication that hospitals are preparing, covertly, for an outbreak of that magnitude, as this headline suggests.
Holding your breath for 10 seconds isn’t a way to test that you don’t have COVID-19.

During the 2009 swine flu outbreak, Biden said he would advise his family against traveling in confined places and said when one person sneezes “it goes all the way through an aircraft.” Scientists say that’s not how germs spread. Biden’s comments were met with backlash and his spokesperson issued a clarification.

The website Information is Beautiful published a chart showing that 80.9% of novel coronavirus cases are "mild." But reports from the World Health Organization and the U.S. CDC found that mild cases account for 75-to-80% of all cases.

What did you fact-check?: A blogpost about professor Didider Raoult, champion of chloroquine, was censored.
Explanation: The user himself deleted his post.

What did you fact-check?: A video showing young people juming on a Police car, supposedly shot during shutdown
Explanation: The video dates at least from August 2019.
